summary: Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was substituted on with only seven minutes remaining in their 0-0 draw with Burnley on Sunday. Merson initially angered Townsend by writing in his Sky Sports column that 'if Andros Townsend can get in (the England team) then it opens it up to anybody.' Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, and he duly accepted Merson's apology. However, Merson couldn't resist taking another dig at Townsend after Tottenham's draw at Turf Moor.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to the Japanese club's president Naoki Ogane. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge this summer. The offer is not connected to the £200 million sponsorship deal Chelsea signed with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber in February. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree two weeks ago, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and has earned 11 caps for Japan, scoring once. A £4 million deal for the youngster has been mooted, but Muto has not yet decided whether he will join Chelsea despite being pleased with their bid.

A large-scale study conducted by Finnish researchers has found a link between antibiotic use in infants and childhood obesity. The study, which involved more than 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, found that children who had been given antibiotics in the first six months of life were more likely to be overweight or obese by the age of two. Boys were particularly prone to weight gain after being given antibiotics, and repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being a fat toddler. The researchers suggested that antibiotics may be contributing to the obesity epidemic by killing off gut bugs that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study did not prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but the researchers warned that the extended use of antibiotics could be an additional contributing factor to the development of excess weight problems.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, much to the shock and amusement of the hundreds of tourists present. The embarrassed soldier quickly scrambled to his feet and continued with his duties, but not before realizing how many people had seen his mishap. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist, who later shared the footage. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E networks are remaking the epic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and had a staggering audience of over 100 million viewers. The new version, set to air in 2016, will be a simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History (formerly the History Channel). LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new miniseries. The remake will draw more from Alex Haley's classic novel, "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," and will consult scholars in African and African-American history for added authenticity. The new version is described as "original" and "contemporary" and will tell the story of Kunta Kinte, an African who was captured, shipped to America, and sold into slavery to work on a Virginia plantation. The remake will encounter a new generation of viewers who have witnessed Barack Obama make history as the nation's first African-American president and "12 Years a Slave" win the Oscar for Best Picture, but also widespread racial unrest over police treatment of black suspects in many U.S. cities.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claimed that he was sexually assaulted on his first day working at Clarence House in 1978. He alleged that he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member, and that he was threatened to keep quiet. Lawler reported the incident to palace officials, but his complaint was ignored for months before the police were finally notified. The police are now investigating the claims, and the Royal Household has stated that they will cooperate fully with the investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which features the couple rapping in a car, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The Meeks shared the news with loved ones living far away and were surprised by the video's unexpected success. They plan to make another video after learning the gender of their child.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett encounters Rhett Butler and is attacked in the shanty town. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over the years. It was part of a collection amassed by James Tumblin, who bought it for $20 in the 1960s. Other top-selling items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh, trousers and jacket from a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The boy's mother was holding him and another child when he slipped and fell between 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises and was in stable condition at the hospital. His leg was injured in the fall, but he was not attacked by the animals. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the boy's mother.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been turned to face a house after being out of service for two years due to outdated technology. The camera, one of around 300 decommissioned in 2013, is being investigated by Birmingham City Council, which plans to remove it.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, expressed his excitement to be part of the team and his readiness to run. He also praised the atmosphere of the event and emphasized the importance of representing Jamaica with pride. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending a Euro League match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Neymar, who had just led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile, was joined by his sister Rafaella at the game. Despite the victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their division. The Barcelona players will return to La Liga action on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they continue their pursuit of a treble of trophies.

Italy is grappling with a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East seeking to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued, with the Italian coast guard receiving SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. On Tuesday, Save the Children reported that 400 migrants could be missing, citing survivor testimony of a ship carrying 550 people capsizing 80 miles off the Libyan coast. However, the Italian coast guard has not found evidence to confirm this incident. The recent increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy has led to a rise in rescues performed by the Italian Coast Guard. The IOM reports that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued at sea during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join the Gunners over Liverpool, despite the Reds' interest in the Chilean forward. Sanchez, who has scored 19 goals this season, was courted by several elite clubs last summer but ultimately decided to continue his career under Wenger's guidance. Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to a new environment proves he is one of the best around and has revitalized the team's strengths and dynamics. The Arsenal boss also played down speculation linking him with Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling, who has rejected a new contract offer.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the UCI Hour Record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, who will be 35 on April 28, will attempt to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. Wiggins, whose track pedigree includes three Olympic gold medals, is expected to set a mark that will last for some time. The current Hour record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins will hope for a capacity 6,000 crowd to spur on his attempt, with tickets going on sale from April 19. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams expressed that her struggle to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday was a real 'eye-opener' as the claycourt season gets into full swing. The US were beaten 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske being thrashed 6-0 6-3 in the doubles rubber by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams, who has won 19 singles grand slams, said the tough weather conditions made it difficult for both players, and she realized she was not as ready for the claycourt season as she thought she was. She said she has to be ready to hit a thousand shots if necessary. The US captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, said they have to work harder and need to just keep plugging away.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009. Falcao has struggled during his loan spell at Old Trafford, scoring only four Premier League goals, and it is uncertain whether United will exercise the option to keep him or whether he will return to Monaco. River Plate vice president Matias Patanian expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, stating that the doors are open. Falcao has been in good form for Colombia recently, scoring three goals in two games to equal the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the X Factor finalist and pop star, has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles, including a glossy, wavy style and a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership between Henderson and Batiste, the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand, was facilitated by the MILES agency. The international campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson has expressed her excitement about working with Batiste, a brand she uses regularly. The campaign images showcase Henderson in glamorous outfits, including a black lacy dress with sheer panels.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler, has sparked outrage among Siler's family and friends in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, expresses gratitude to the community for its support. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and are calling for its removal. The shooting occurred after Siler, who was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant, armed himself with a weapon following a vehicle and foot pursuit. The investigation into Siler's death continues, while the investigation into Torres' shooting of Terry Knight, a suicidal man armed with two knives, was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan, with three militants also killed. The incident occurred in the southeastern town of Negur, with the militants reportedly crossing into Iran from Pakistan. The Sunni Muslim group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack, which targeted Shiites and aimed to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian authorities have asked Pakistani authorities to catch the surviving assailants, with the Pakistani government condemning the attack and pledging to apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan.

The classic video game "Space Invaders" was developed in Japan in the late 1970s, and now its real-life counterparts are the topic of an earnest political discussion in Japan's corridors of power. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani revealed that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. However, former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki claims to have seen a UFO with his own eyes, although he admitted that he didn't know personally if aliens existed. Inoki also asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. In 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba pondered the legal ramifications, under Japan's pacifist constitution, of a defense against an invasion from outer space.

A man in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China broke a toilet he was squatting on, resulting in deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. The man, Jin Pai, was worried about the cleanliness of the toilet seat and chose to stand on the rim, which caused the toilet to tip over and shatter, leading to his injuries. He initially told his friends he was squatting, but later changed his story to avoid paying compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and have reminded people to sit on the toilets instead of standing on them.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The investigation began when the girl found a hidden camera under the sink in a bathroom in her home. She told investigators that Rebbie had been watching her for years when she was undressing and when he believed she was asleep. She also said that Rebbie had been molesting her since she was nine years old until she was 13. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and had purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered. He is being held on a $500,000 bail, and his preliminary hearing is on May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The daughters are shown in casual clothing, standing po-faced, while their fathers, dressed in sharp suits, perform energetic poses, often with expressions of pain. The images are part of Aoyama's latest book, roughly translated as Daughter and Salary Man, and are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks. The series allows fathers to express their fun side, embodying the role of a hero jumping through the sky with excitement and hope. The photos have garnered significant online interest for their curious and unique nature.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has raised the possibility of Kevin Pietersen's return to the England cricket team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up. The batsman was in a jovial mood as he posed for the Surrey team photo before the start of the County Championship season, but also took a moment to reflect ahead of the new campaign. Pietersen's last appearance for England was during the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia last year, where he suffered a whitewash series defeat. With England hoping to regain the urn this summer on home soil, Pietersen's return to the international set-up is a potential step closer.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, have dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, was initially fired on Wednesday after a poor run but was reinstated the next day. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday, he angered owner Angelo Massone again, leading to his dismissal. Ze Maria, who replaced Florin Marin in January, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco team-mate, Nabil Dirar, believes that Falcao must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to hit the heights he achieved before suffering a serious knee injury. United will have to pay £46 million to make Falcao's transfer permanent, but having only scored four goals all season, it is unlikely that they will take up that option. Dirar revealed that Falcao was not happy in France but thinks he would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, making off with the till and about $1500 in cash. The offender, described as being very tall, was captured on security footage wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and an oversized mask. Police were called to the Union St dairy at about 12.30pm after receiving reports of a masked man demanding cash from the owner's daughter. The robber threw the cash register to the ground and fled with the till drawer. Police are appealing to the public for information that may help to identify the person responsible and are asking anyone with information to call Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or to message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice in March 2022 for inappropriate relationships with underage students. The first arrest occurred on March 19, 2022, after she admitted to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail but was arrested again on March 24, 2022, for having sex with another 15-year-old student on two consecutive nights in January. Both incidents allegedly took place in her car late at night. Granado was suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave by school officials. She posted a $50,000 bail and was released from jail. The school district has reassured families that they took immediate and appropriate action to address the situation.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws has gone viral, amassing over half a million views. The large crocodile calmly carried the lifeless dog, which belonged to the owner of a local bike shop, for hours before taking it to a nearby crocodile sanctuary. The incident occurred when the dog approached the water's edge, and the crocodile seized the opportunity to attack. Social media users have expressed horror at the video, with some calling it 'horrible' and others expressing hatred for crocodiles. However, crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta, as the resort is built among mangroves that have been home to the creatures for centuries.

Hull City, under manager Steve Bruce, are battling to avoid relegation from the Premier League. Despite a strong start to the season, they have managed just six wins and are now relying on nine or eight points to secure survival. Key players have been sidelined with long-term injuries, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, Bruce remains confident that Hull can stay up, citing the team's positive attitude and the return of injured players.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he altered the answers on his students' SATs exams, invalidating the entire school's results. Guffick, who taught at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, allowed students to change their answers after the exam session had ended and also altered some answers himself. The school's results were annulled by the Department for Education after an investigation by the local education authority. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. He was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United's goalkeeper, is enjoying a happy personal life despite limited playing time. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year, and they have a son together. Lindegaard, who has struggled for minutes at United, posted a photo of himself and Beqiri on Instagram, calling her his "sunshine." Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, regularly posts modeling photos on Instagram, where she has over 17,000 followers. Despite his limited playing time, Lindegaard has been linked with a move to FC Midtjylland, but the two clubs could not agree on a price.

Reggie Jackson, a Hall of Famer for the New York Yankees, purchased the iconic 13-letter signage that once hung over Yankee Stadium in 2008. He hoped to sell the letters at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday to a new generation of owners. However, the only bid was from a Sotheby's employee, who offered $260,000, well below the estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000. The letters, which were installed in 1976, the year before Jackson joined the team, were taken down in 2008. Despite the lack of bids, the auction also featured a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, which sold for $112,500, far exceeding its estimated value of $20,000 to $30,000.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after pictures emerged of them inhaling nitrous oxide and using shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to the players but decided not to discipline them, urging them to learn from the incident. He emphasized the importance of understanding the responsibilities that come with being a professional athlete. Rodgers also spoke about the team's recent setbacks, including the title race and the Capital One Cup, and highlighted the importance of learning from losses to improve. He did not reveal whether he would recall Steven Gerrard for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, focusing solely on steering the team to the final.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil enjoyed his home comforts after returning to London following the international break, posting a picture of himself relaxing with his dog. The German star impressed on international duty, helping Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier on Sunday. Ozil missed Arsenal's last game against Newcastle through illness but is expected to start against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium. He has been in fine form since returning from injury, racking up four assists and scoring three goals since January. Ozil says he is finally adjusting to English football and prefers playing in many matches, which is why he fits perfectly in the Premier League.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has dismissed rumors that the club plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, expressing satisfaction with his performance. Enrique, who joined the club last summer, is on the verge of winning the La Liga title and has a contract until 2016. The president praised Enrique's focus and dedication, highlighting his preparation for the Champions League game against PSG and the subsequent league match against Valencia, which Barcelona won comfortably with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Liverpool midfielder Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract, worth around £100,000-a-week, that will run until the summer of 2020. The England international, who was signed by Kenny Dalglish in June 2011 for £16million from Sunderland, has been one of the most improved players under Brendan Rodgers' watch. His form this season has been excellent and he has contributed 13 assists as well as seven goals from midfield. Henderson, 24, is the third big player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to agree a contract extension, following on from Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season but Ian Ayre, Liverpool's Chief Executive, last week said he expected the England forward to be at Anfield for 'a long time'. Henderson could replace Steven Gerrard as Liverpool captain when the 34-year-old departs this summer.

Filipe Luis, a Chelsea defender, has expressed his desire to stay with the club until the end of his contract, despite interest from Atletico Madrid. Luis, who signed a three-year contract with Chelsea last July, has struggled to secure the left back position but remains committed to the team. He played in Brazil's friendly wins against France and Chile during the international break and is now focused on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is urging his team to stay focused and concentrate on winning each game, as they face a challenging schedule with nine difficult games ahead.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal. The Wasps No. 8 was initially suspended for three matches after a disciplinary panel ruled he had been 'reckless' for failing to prevent his knee from colliding with North's head as he scored a try for Northampton on March 27. Hughes was shown a red card for the offense, but that dismissal has now been officially rescinded. Although it was accepted that there had been no intent, the Fiji-born player with England ambitions received a further sanction at the original hearing. Yet, in a stunning twist, the ban was thrown out as the appeal lodged by Wasps was upheld. The appeal panel concluded that no act of foul play took place, as the incident occurred accidentally.

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers burning grass in their fields, grew out of control due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. The resulting smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, creating intense red sunsets in Washington, Oregon, and British Columbia. The red and orange colors are caused by smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from the sunlight, with more atmosphere for the light to travel through during sunrises and sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve, and the fiery sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. A few weeks later, she was surprised to learn that the police had found her car, thanks to a tip from a man who recognized it and returned it to her. However, the car had been modified with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Despite the changes, Schoenig took to Facebook to thank the car thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle and posted a photo of her and her new ride. She also created a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who located her car and notified the police.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The team is currently in fourth place, just four points ahead of main rivals Liverpool, and could miss out on a big payday if they finish fifth. In total, the City squad has around £12 million resting on reaching their European target. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted that the team has let their season disintegrate after starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea, and they now face a battle to sign world-class players like Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba, who is also of interest to Manchester United.

The Manchester United Under 18s secured a 1-0 victory over Manchester City in the 'mini-derby,' with Callum Gribbin scoring the decisive goal from a free-kick. The match, played at Altrincham's Moss Lane, saw a strong local presence with 13 of the 22 players being English, and 10 from Manchester. The game was free to enter, attracting close to 1,000 spectators. United's approach mirrored their senior team's tactics, with three at the back and supporting wingbacks. Despite missing opportunities, United's win keeps them two points behind Middlesbrough in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-offs, while City faces challenges with injuries and losses in both play-off matches.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italy's Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after the veteran reached 147 caps. Hart, who earned his 50th cap, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity and performance at 37 years old. Hart, 10 years younger than Buffon, aims to continue learning and accumulating caps for both club and country.

Chipotle has partnered with the Postmates app to offer delivery services for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. The fast-casual chain will add a 9% service charge to delivery orders, with Postmates delivery fees starting at $5 and varying based on distance and demand. The collaboration with Postmates, which hires independent contractors who use their own cars, marks a new venture for Chipotle, which had previously turned down offers from third-party delivery services. The move comes as the $70 billion food delivery market continues to grow, with other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King also exploring delivery options.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an opinion piece in The Boston Globe urging the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings. They argue that the continued pursuit of the death penalty could prolong reliving the most painful day of their lives and bring years of appeals. They believe that now is the time to turn the page, end the anguish, and look toward a better future for themselves, Boston, and the country.

A Boeing 747-8 has been converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, costing £400 million and taking three years to customize. The plane, which can hold up to 600 passengers, features a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a lounge, a state room, an aeroloft with eight full beds, a master bedroom with a huge bed, an armchair, and a sofa, a conference room, a lounge with hotel-like decor, an office or guest bedroom, and a dining room attached to a kitchen. The plane can carry several dozen passengers and includes spaces for guests to relax and watch television. The luxury interior is far more glitzy than first class on commercial flights, with the traditional rows of seats completely discarded in favor of a hotel-like ambiance.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station on Tuesday. The rocket successfully reached orbit, but SpaceX's attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket landing too hard for survival. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker, to the space station. After about five weeks, the Dragon will be loaded with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments, trash, and other items for return to Earth, where it will splashdown in the Pacific Ocean off California. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the International Space Station.

Priscilla Presley collaborated with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for a couple to win the "ultimate wedding" at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The winning couple will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite for two nights, airfare, and concert tickets. Priscilla, who was married to Elvis in 1967, emphasized that the wedding chapel is not a joke and will feature first-class amenities. The chapel, part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of the singer's artifacts outside his iconic Memphis, Tennessee, home, will host its first wedding on Thursday, April 23.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his side can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a tough season at Anfield. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both equaled the record for appearances by any player in the top five European leagues this campaign. Liverpool defeated Newcastle United 2-0 on Monday night, with Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scoring. Liverpool are four points behind Manchester City, who have been faltering and lost 4-2 at Manchester United. Henderson believes Liverpool can put pressure on City and come the end of the season, you never know.

Roma secured a crucial 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A, ending a four-month winless streak at home. Miralem Pjanic scored the decisive goal in the 25th minute after a swift counter-attack. Roma goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis was instrumental in the win, making several key saves in the second half. The victory moved Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, who were yet to play. Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, and they remained in fifth place. Security was tight due to the recent history between the two clubs, but the match passed without incident.

Doncaster Rovers' match against Fleetwood Town in League One ended in a goalless draw, with the two teams playing out a dull game that tested the patience of even the most ardent fans. The match highlights video on the club's YouTube channel was just 27 seconds long, with only 14 seconds of match action, including the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man, Roland Giroux, has a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, which he regularly strokes and massages in its tank. The fish, initially shy, eventually becomes sociable and enjoys the interaction, even becoming frustrated if ignored. The fish swims around Giroux's fingers and towards the surface as he removes his hand, showing a clear bond. The blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, was first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character, has returned to the England cricket team after a year of ups and downs, including a wrist injury from punching a locker. He has shown aggression on the field, notably in clashes with Marlon Samuels and Mitchell Johnson, but has also received guidance from coach Peter Moores to channel his aggression positively. Stokes's natural exuberance and desire to take on opponents are valued, but his aggression must be controlled to ensure a balance of highs and lows. The team aims to help him reach his full potential, with a focus on runs and wickets, while also considering the inclusion of a second spinner in certain matches.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium has sold out, with 33,000 tickets sold. Wales is in its best position to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup, currently tied with Belgium at the top of Group B with 11 points from five games. The comprehensive 3-0 victory over Israel last weekend has increased expectations that Wales can secure one of the two automatic qualifying spots for the finals in France. The match was never going to be moved to the Millennium Stadium, as UEFA rules prevent a venue change within 120 days of the scheduled date. Additionally, the Wales squad prefers to play at the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium, where they have not played since a Euro 2012 qualifier against England in March 2011.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where they will defend their title. The Young Lions have been placed in Group D alongside Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, and will open their campaign against Italy on May 7. The squad includes talented young players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo of Chelsea, and the Arsenal duo Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, who is called up for the first time. Liverpool pair Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have also been recalled after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers last month.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents to emerge from the club's youth set-up. Patoulidis rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy when he was 12 to continue his studies. City have held discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock in the hope of agreeing a compensation package. Manuel Pellegrini is looking to build for the future by signing Patoulidis.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead in a Fulham flat, having been strangled and beaten. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and told to return for further questioning. The police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward, as they are keen to understand the circumstances surrounding her death. The investigation is ongoing, and the police are determined to solve the case.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, accused her long-term friend Jamie of stealing £207 set aside for her baby's grave stone. Jamie, who lives with Dawn and her partner Jamie, initially denied the accusation but was later revealed to be lying through a lie detector test conducted by The Jeremy Kyle Show. The stolen money was intended for a £500 grave stone, with the remaining £293 saved by Dawn and her partner Jamie. Dawn expressed her devastation and betrayal, stating that the stolen funds were meant to honor her baby Daniel James with a proper grave stone.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, a minority group whose members were killed, captured, and displaced when the Islamist terror organization overtook their towns in northern Iraq last summer. The freed Yazidis, mostly women and children, were received by Peshmerga and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The reason for the release is unclear, but Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate it. Since attacking the Yazidis' towns last year, ISIS has released scores of other Yazidis, largely children and the elderly. The Sunni Islamist militant group has been extraordinarily cruel to the Yazidis, who are of Kurdish descent and whose religion is considered a pre-Islamic sect that draws from Christianity, Judaism, and Zoroastrianism.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham and England striker, has had a remarkable season, breaking into the first team and being nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation by Copa90 features some of Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and the moment he came on and scored on his England debut. The video is titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and has been released ahead of the awards ceremony, where Kane is up against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher expressed his support for Brendan Rodgers as the right manager for Liverpool, despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher emphasized the importance of identifying areas for improvement in the squad and making the right signings to make a difference. He also highlighted the significance of community work and his efforts to help underprivileged areas through his 23 Foundation.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport. The toy, a brightly colored plastic Nerf gun that fires sponge darts, was packed in his hand luggage for a flight to Lanzarote. Security officers, described as "over-zealous" by the boy's father, Phil, took exception to the toy, which was picked up on the X-ray machines. They demanded James hand it over and performed a thorough patting down and inspection of the primary school child. Phil Hayward, a software engineer, criticized the security checks as "ludicrous" and the staff's reaction as over-the-top. The family did not have time to argue and missed their flight. After returning from their holiday, the family bought a replacement toy gun on eBay. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but pointed out that they had offered to post the toy back to the family's home in Doncaster, South Yorkshire. The airport defended the decision, stating that no items may be permitted through security that resemble a prohibited item.

A 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. The advertisement outlined his requirements for the ideal partner, including being fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, a good cook, and great in bed. The successful applicant must enjoy the outdoors and be a princess when needed. In return, the man promised to provide accommodation, a company car, phone, and laptop, and to be generous with money. He described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, and successful, with a love for cars, bikes, and the outdoors. The advertisement also stated that former partners need not apply.

The passage outlines the Football Association's (FA) proposal to increase the number of home-grown players in top-flight clubs' squads and the opposition from the Premier League. It also highlights the support of five former England managers for the proposal and the challenges faced by the English national team in producing top young talent. The former managers warn that failure to support the proposals risks England falling further behind leading football nations and makes it harder to end the long wait to win the World Cup. The passage also mentions the current state of English football, with only 36.8% of Premier League starters eligible for England selection, and the emergence of promising young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane.

The passage describes the rapid progression of Demelza Poldark's pregnancy and the birth of her child in the TV series "Poldark." It highlights the quick timeline from the announcement of the pregnancy to the birth, noting the lack of a clear passage of time. The passage also mentions the fast-paced nature of the relationship between Demelza and Ross Poldark, and how it has garnered attention from fans. Additionally, it references a similar situation with another character, Elizabeth, who also experienced a rapid pregnancy timeline in the show.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own performances and not be distracted by the struggles of their relegation rivals. Despite being bottom of the Premier League, Leicester have won their last two games, including a crucial 3-2 victory over West Bromwich Albion, and are now just three points from safety. Pearson emphasized the importance of maintaining their own form and not being overly optimistic, as the team's fate is still in their own hands.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest migration of a mammal, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from her primary feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. Varvara's journey surpassed the previous record set by a humpback whale that swam a 10,190-mile round trip between warm breeding waters near the equator and colder food-rich waters of the Arctic and Antarctic regions. Varvara's journey also revealed that she may be an eastern gray whale, not a western gray whale as previously thought. This discovery could mean that some western gray whales are actually eastern grays, which would have significant implications for the conservation of this endangered species.

A 1,000-foot stretch of seabed near Rausu on Hokkaido Island, Japan, was forced to the surface overnight, likely due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The new stretch of land, which measures roughly 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide, rose as high as 50 feet above sea level in some places. Local residents reported no tremors or sounds indicating movement, and authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further. Marine organisms such as seaweed and sea urchins are still attached to the landmass.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors that he will leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent falling out with manager Laurent Blanc, Van der Wiel is happy at PSG and wants to sign a new contract. However, the club is reportedly interested in signing Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could impact Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, the former Manchester City striker, has reportedly told Juventus he wishes to leave this summer to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Although his contract with Juventus does not expire until the end of next season, the club has accepted his decision and is identifying potential replacements. Boca Juniors has confirmed they are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old, but club president Daniel Angelici has stressed that Tevez must terminate his contract with Juventus first. Tevez's international manager Tata Martino has said that any potential move would have no bearing on the player's Argentina future.

Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his trousers during an exciting 6-1 Champions League win against Porto, revealing his underwear. The Spanish tactician's left trouser leg gave way as he celebrated his team's dominant performance, which saw them overturn a two-goal deficit from the first leg. Bayern's goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Guardiola also ditched his suit blazer during the latter stages of the match.

A multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, Brisbane, has resulted in ten people being injured, including four children. The crash involved three vehicles, and one person was trapped and had to be freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue crews using hydraulic cutting gear. The injured were taken to hospitals in Brisbane and Ipswich. The highway has been closed, with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil is eagerly anticipating the upcoming Premier League match against Chelsea, which could significantly impact the title race. Ozil, who has been in good form this season, received a new Apple Watch and expressed his excitement on Instagram, comparing it to the gadget used by Michael Knight in the hit action show Knight Rider. Meanwhile, Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere, who has been sidelined with injuries for much of the season, is nearing a return to the first team. Club legend Ray Parlour believes that Wilshere's fitness record is the only thing holding him back from reaching his undoubted potential in the Arsenal midfield. Parlour also compared Wilshere's situation to that of Abou Diaby, who has struggled with injuries in recent years.

Mark Clattenburg, one of the Premier League's leading referees, has been appointed to officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. He has sent off three players from both teams this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany during Belgium's Euro 2016 qualifier against Israel. Clattenburg has courted controversy during his career but is generally regarded as one of the Premier League's leading referees alongside Michael Oliver. The champion's shock 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace on Monday saw United move a point above their local rivals, adding extra incentive for both sides ahead of the derby at Old Trafford, which could ultimately decide who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea. While Manuel Pellegrini's side have struggled since the turn of the year, turning from title challengers to fourth place chases, United are coasting on confidence having won their last five consecutive league games. Clattenburg will be joined on Sunday by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, while Jonathan Moss will serve as the fourth official.

Bob Katter, an MP of Lebanese descent, has accused the Queensland Government of believing Billy Gordon, an embattled MP, was 'a little black puppet on a string'. Katter, who has faced racist attitudes in the past, sympathizes with Gordon's position and criticizes the Government's assumption that Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and concealing his criminal history. Katter uses the term 'black puppet' to highlight what he perceives as racial overtones and vows that Gordon will not become a puppet for the government.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using dance to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and stares, she hopes her videos will encourage people to think before judging and see her as just one of them. Dayna, who has defied doctors' predictions that she may never walk, is now a motivational speaker and has created several dancing videos, including one to Taylor Swift's Shake It Off.

Orlando City, a Major League Soccer (MLS) side, is interested in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who is currently on loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a popular figure among Latin-American fans, would be a commercial draw for Orlando, which has a large Latin-American fanbase. However, eight European sides, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also interested in the player. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has a host of clubs across Europe interested in signing him if he does not agree to terms with United.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a car at a South Los Angeles gas station and set it on fire while there were two passengers inside. The driver, who has not been identified, said he got into an argument with the suspects while he was pumping gas at a 76 Station around 12:15 am on Saturday. The suspects attempted to carjack the man before the fire, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson. The car's entire front end was torched, but no one was injured during the incident. The suspects remain at large, and surveillance video of the incident is being used in the investigation.

A chiropractor in Iowa has surrendered his license after admitting to exchanging services for sex and performing exorcisms on some patients. Despite this, he has received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires him to prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state. The disgraced chiropractor received a perfect five out of five stars in patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com.

A U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner," according to the Pentagon. The incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew reporting aggressive maneuvers and a high rate of speed. Russian state news agency Sputnik reported that the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder switched off, but this claim was denied by a U.S. official. The Pentagon and State Department will file a complaint with Russia through diplomatic channels. This is not the first time the U.S. has complained about an incident involving a RC-135U and a SU-27, with a similar incident occurring a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was ripped out of the agent's car window, likely by breaking the handle with a rope tied around it and using another vehicle for momentum. The thief also stole the agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, but it has not been recovered. The theft occurred at the Marriott Springhill Suites, a hotel next to the city's airport and down the street from the state's FBI office. The hotel does not have surveillance cameras.

Luigi Costa, a 71-year-old man, is accused of killing his neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012. The jury heard that Costa, who is believed to have dementia and alcohol abuse issues, allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times in the dining room of Freebody's home. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa's mental state was compromised by dementia and alcohol at the time of the incident, leading to a confused state. Mullen also stated that Costa's mood fluctuated and Costa made triple 0 calls during the attack. The jury can return a not guilty verdict if Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines' superior penalty-taking record. Barkley, who has been untried, took the penalty in the 10th minute, which was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Fortunately for Barkley, Mirallas scored the only goal of the game after 29 minutes. Martinez stated that Barkley was within his rights to request penalty-taking duties and that he was happy to have multiple players who can take penalties. Baines has scored 15 penalties from 16 attempts in the Premier League.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship, which was docked in Puerto Rico. The cruise line, Holland America, reported that the deaths appeared to be the result of a murder-suicide. The cabin was secured, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cleaning staff discovered the deceased passengers after knocking on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland forward and assistant coach, has made a winning start as the coach of Curacao in the World Cup qualifying matches. Curacao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament after drawing 2-2 in a second-leg match at Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team won 2-1 on Saturday in Willemstad. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup losing semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and last year as an assistant coach to Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, an experienced midfielder who has won numerous major European competitions, joined Leicester City in the summer and is determined to help the team avoid relegation from the Premier League. Despite being seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with only eight games remaining, Cambiasso believes that Leicester can still stay up and that achieving this would be as significant as winning a trophy. He has quickly established himself as a key player for the team and is happy in the East Midlands, indicating that he may stay beyond his current one-year deal.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her two children, aged under five, due to her partying and drinking habits. Her mother, Debbie, has been raising the children since they were four months old and is now threatening to prevent Gemma from seeing them after discovering her penchant for legal highs and suspicions of theft. Gemma has admitted to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past but denies stealing an iPad from one of the children. Debbie, who appeared alongside her daughter on The Jeremy Kyle Show, has been left to bring both children up alone and is at the end of her tether, preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children.

During Chelsea's 1-0 win over Manchester United, a controversial foul occurred in the build-up to Eden Hazard's opening goal. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao, sending the Colombian to the ground. The Sky Sports pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed that Terry's challenge was a foul and should have resulted in a free kick for United. Despite this, the goal stood, and Chelsea went on to win the match.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway Thursday morning, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. The fire started after a rear tire blew out, and the bus burst into flames after everyone had gotten off. Scott posted on Instagram that the fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except her Bible. The band's two other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not traveling on the bus. Lady Antebellum is set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is exploring the potential of space lasers to convert sunlight into energy and transmit it to Earth, with initial successful trials in Scotland. Unlike the powerful lasers seen in science fiction, these beams are not capable of causing harm on a large scale. However, Dr Quarterman acknowledges the potential for misuse if the technology falls into the wrong hands.

Stephen Munden, a convicted paedophile with a history of sexual offences against children, has gone on the run after vanishing from a psychiatric unit in Hook, Hampshire. Munden, 54, was last seen leaving the hospital at 6.15pm on Tuesday and is described as 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, with dark hair. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and was convicted of sexually touching a child under the age of 13. Munden, who has learning difficulties, was also found with children's clothes, books, and dolls at his home and was convicted of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. He is considered a high-risk individual and officers are urging anyone with information on his whereabouts to come forward.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts after Shelly Sterling, Donald Sterling's wife, sued her. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting extremely wealthy older men and claimed that Donald Sterling used the couple's money to buy Stiviano a Ferrari, two Bentleys, and a Range Rover, and that he helped her get a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano countered that there was nothing wrong with Donald Sterling giving her gifts and that she never took advantage of the former Los Angeles Clippers owner. Shelly Sterling was thrilled with the court decision, her lawyer told CNN affiliate KABC. The judge's decision sets a precedent that the injured spouse can recover damages from the recipient of these ill-begotten gifts. Stiviano's gifts from Donald Sterling didn't just include uber-expensive items like luxury cars; the list also includes a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 two-speed blender, and a $12 lace thong.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged his former side to purchase four top players in the summer. The Frenchman believes Arsenal need a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker to have any chance of winning the Barclays Premier League title. Henry also hit out at Olivier Giroud, claiming that Arsenal will struggle to win the league if he remains the club's first-choice striker. Henry suggested that Arsenal needs to sign players of the same caliber as Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa.

A young woman has detailed the severe impact of years of sexual abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who cannot be named, said she didn't understand why she had been targeted and was scared for her future relationships. She attempted to take her own life after learning of Van Ryn's arrest and has suffered from depression and self-harm since the age of 14. The hearing continues.

Arsenal midfielder Serge Gnabry, who has been out for over a year due to a knee injury, is feeling "better and better" as he prepares to return to action. The 19-year-old played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21s against Reading on Monday, his second 90-minute appearance in a week. Gnabry, who impressed for the Gunners last season before his injury, is now over his injury worries and looking forward to the next game.

A young accountant, Jacob Phillips, fell to his death from a 70ft cliff after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. The 23-year-old had been out drinking in Cardiff with friends before catching a taxi home. When they realized they didn't have enough money to pay the fare, they decided to trick the driver by running off in different directions. Mr. Phillips ran into the pitch-black darkness and fell down a cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. His body was discovered the following morning by a dog walker. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting that Mr. Phillips likely became disoriented and had no idea of the danger he faced.

The passport agency faced a significant backlog last summer, with 3.6 million Britons applying for passports and over half a million stuck in the system by mid-June. Despite making a £42 million profit during this period, the agency only approved 2,191 compensation applications, totaling £203,066, with the largest payout at £5,463 and the lowest at £1. Ministers rejected a demand for blanket refunds, citing the risk of setting a precedent.

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, which has remained unchanged since the 1930s, is up for sale. The semi-detached property, with a guide price of between £200,000 and £250,000, boasts original features including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and retro jars of popular food. The house has an unimposing exterior but is a treasure trove inside, with features such as beautiful stained glass windows, a dated bathroom with mint and black color schemes, and original tiles, wooden floor, yellow wallpaper, and green sink. The wood-panelled hall is lit by quirky stained-glass windows depicting ships in full sail, while the living room's windows are patterned with coats of arms on the glass. The three-bedroom home also comes with all the original 1930s cupboards in the kitchen, a brick open-face fire, and a dated kitchen sink. While some features have been upgraded, such as double glazing, the cost of renovations may deter developers. The historic house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick, a backup to Alex Smith, became the 49ers' starter in the middle of the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion. Kaepernick remained the team's starting quarterback for the rest of the season and led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45 mi freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, that connects the New Jersey Turnpike (Interstate 95, I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, formed Blur with Graham Coxon, releasing their debut album, Leisure, in 1991. Blur's self-titled album in 2001 achieved worldwide success. Albarn's solo debut, Everyday Robots, was released in 2014, co-produced by Richard Russell, and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, with samples from Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It serves as the seat of many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails from their 1992 EP, Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter, born on August 14, 1964, known for his BAFTA-nominated work.

Shooter is a 2007 film and a TV series that follows Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran and expert marksman. In the film, Swagger is framed for murder by a rogue secret private military company unit. In the TV series, Swagger is coaxed back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
House (also known as House, M.D.) is an American medical drama television series that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, and received additional first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald Shea. After his conviction, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television with a brief appearance in Little House on the Prairie in 1974, directed by his father Leo Penn. Penn's film debut was in the drama Taps in 1981, and he gained critical attention for his roles in crime dramas such as At Close Range in 1986, State of Grace in 1990, and Carlito's Way in 1993. He became known as a prominent leading actor with the drama Dead Man Walking in 1995, for which he earned his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations for Woody Allen's comedy-drama Sweet and Lowdown in 1999 and the drama I Am Sam in 2001 before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for Mystic River and a second one in 2008 for Milk.

Sir Donald George Bradman, AC, known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.
L.A. Reid has held prominent positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000, 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He started his career with Greta in 1990 and helped co-found Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he is playing with Prophets of Rage, which includes Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015. It ran for 34 episodes over two seasons before being canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, after four episodes into the second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas and delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and was noted for her outspoken feminism and one-liners. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush.
Drake Bell released an EP titled A Reminder independently in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, born Jeanette Helen Morrison, was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author. She wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in the establishment of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states, independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely-defined region in the western part of the North Atlantic Ocean where a number of aircraft and ships are said to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Alex Smith suffered a concussion. He led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, losing to the Baltimore Ravens. In 2013, his first full season as a starter, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, losing to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a marketing communication tool that uses sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas. It is distinct from personal selling in that the message is not directed at a specific individual. Advertising is disseminated through various media channels, including traditional outlets like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and outdoor advertising, as well as modern platforms such as search engines, blogs, websites, and text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward, and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, Chalkidice. At 17 or 18, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens, where he stayed until he was 37 (c. 347 BC). After Plato's death, he left Athens and tutored Alexander the Great in 343 BC at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Mordechai Packouz is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented a guitar pedal drum machine called the BeatBuddy and is currently the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson, a point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, won championships in high school, college, and the NBA. He was selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft, won a championship and an NBA Finals Most Valuable Player Award in his rookie season, and won four more championships with the Lakers during the 1980s. After protests from his fellow players, he retired for four years but returned in 1996 at age 36 to play 32 games for the Lakers before retiring for the third and final time. Named by Ebony magazine as one of America's most influential black businessmen in 2009, Johnson has numerous business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is a comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). The band gained popularity in 1997 after starring in their eponymous television series and supporting large rock acts.

James VI and I was King of Scotland as James VI from 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 1603 until his death in 1625. He was a major advocate of a single parliament for England and Scotland, achieving most of his aims in Scotland but facing great difficulties in England, including the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and repeated conflicts with the English Parliament.
Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality television series Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest state in Germany, with an area of 18,413 km², and the sixth most populous, with 4 million people. Saxony is a region for quality wine in Germany, located in the German federal state of Saxony, and is one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park located in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, USA.
Mel B. Brown began her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra (1994) is an Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It became the second highest-grossing Indian film of 1994 and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. The film is also known for its chart-topping songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure, and "Hourglass" is also the title of James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is known for writing the 1987 action film hit Lethal Weapon and his directorial debut with the film Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film and the last to feature Roger Moore as the iconic MI6 agent.
Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, located in western New Guinea. It was formerly known as Irian Jaya and West Irian or Irian Barat.
Augustus likely died from natural causes, although there were rumors that his wife, Livia, poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez is a multifaceted entertainer who has made significant contributions to the music, film, and television industries. She began her music career in 1999 with her debut album "On the 6," which featured the number-one single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she simultaneously released her second studio album "J.Lo" and starred in the film "The Wedding Planner," becoming the first woman to have a number-one album and film in the same week. Following her second divorce, Lopez had a high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck, which influenced her third studio album "This Is Me... Then" (2002). Her marriage to Marc Anthony and subsequent box office successes, including "Shall We Dance?" (2004), marked a rebound in her career. In 2008, she gave birth to twins and returned to prominence in 2011 with her role as a judge on "American Idol" and her most commercially successful single to date, "On the Floor," which is one of the best-selling singles of all time.

A working animal is a domesticated animal, often trained to perform tasks such as providing tractive force, milking, or herding. They may be close members of the family, such as guide dogs, or animals trained for specific tasks. Wild animals may also be trained for work, though this is rare and typically for novelty or entertainment purposes.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Top Latin Albums is a record chart published by Billboard magazine, considered the most important music chart for Spanish-language, full-length albums in the American music market. Regional Mexican Albums is a genre-specific record chart published weekly by Billboard magazine in the United States.

Vedam is a 2010 Telugu drama film directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
Men in Black II (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Don Quixote, a novel by Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra. He serves as the squire to Don Quixote and provides commentary throughout the novel, known as sanchismos, which are a combination of broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
Ibsen's play "Hedda Gabler" premiered on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen in attendance.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director born on May 14, 1961.

Juventus Football Club, founded in 1897 by a group of young Torinese students, is a professional Italian association football club based in Turin. The club is the second oldest in the country and has traditionally worn a black and white striped home kit since 1903. It has played its home matches in several grounds, with the latest being the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis began her career in the late 1990s and early 2000s, playing supporting and minor roles in films such as Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), as well as in the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress. She is known as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." Jameson began her career in the adult entertainment industry in 1993, after working as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a professional basketball team that competes in the National Basketball Association (NBA) as a member club of the league's Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was traditionally broadcast via closed-circuit and pay-per-view television. The event was originally produced by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the NWA banner. The 1985, 1987, and 1997 editions were the third, fifth, and fifteenth annual events, respectively.
Jack Ryan Falahee is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh on ABC's How to Get Away with Murder and Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS's Mercy Street.

Seohyun, a member of the South Korean girl group Girls' Generation, released her debut mini album, "Do n't Say No," on January 17, 2017, making her the third Girls' Generation member to debut as a solo artist. Apart from her group's activities, she has established herself as an actress, notably through her participation in the original and Korean versions of stage musicals including Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputer products, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak.
