The passage describes a NATO exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities in response to increased Russian submarine activity. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, as well as anti-submarine warfare helicopters and underwater drones. The focus is on locating a German U-boat, U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf, which is tasked with avoiding detection and targeting a command ship and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights the challenges of anti-submarine warfare, particularly for NATO members like the UK, which lacks maritime patrol aircraft and relies on allies for aerial surveillance. The passage also underscores the growing concern over Russia's military strength, particularly its advanced submarine fleet and significant investment in defense, in contrast to European nations that have been cutting their defense budgets.

South Sudan, the world's youngest country, is on the brink of genocide and ethnic cleansing, with violence spreading from Juba to previously peaceful southern Equatoria states. Over 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, the largest refugee influx this year, surpassing Syria's 200,000. Daily, an average of 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees, with reports of killings, rapes, and ethnic targeting. Nelson Ladu Thomas, a refugee, described the violence in his hometown of Yei, where Dinka tribesmen killed his brother and targeted Equatorians and Nuer. Despite the challenges, Uganda, with aid agency support, is providing refugees with land and resources to start anew. However, the influx is straining resources, particularly water supply. The international community is urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to end the violence.

McKenzie, a former professional footballer, became a boxer in 2013 and has a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights. He will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to receive £33 million in funding as part of the coalition's £330 million investment in new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is cramped and outdated, and the new facility is expected to be completed by autumn 2014. The remaining balance will be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, Sheffield, close to the city center. Witnesses reported that the victim was either in or near a black Mercedes car he had been driving when the incident occurred. The man was taken to the Northern General Hospital but succumbed to his injuries. The shooting took place in a residential area where a family celebration was happening, and many relatives came out to help the victim after hearing the shot. The incident occurred in an area that has not been previously affected by the recent spate of shootings in Sheffield, which have mostly occurred in the north of the city.

The passage describes the activities of three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukrainian conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their extensive use of DDoS attacks and hacking into Russian servers and email accounts. They also monitor public CCTV systems in rebel-held areas and have hijacked network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, on the other hand, is a staunchly anti-Western group that hacks Ukrainian government websites and spreads propaganda. They claim to have retrieved confidential documents from a member of Joe Biden's team and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems in Ukraine. Anonymous International, known for leaking Kremlin documents, also covers Ukraine and has published letters and emails that provide insights into the conflict. The passage highlights the diverse tactics and objectives of these hacker groups, from spreading propaganda to gathering intelligence and disrupting operations.

The passage describes the emotional farewells of three MSPs—Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie—as they prepare to leave the Scottish Parliament. Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, used his final speech to highlight the need for accountability and scrutiny in the parliament, drawing lessons from Westminster. Alex Salmond, the former First Minister, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's diversity and the need for greater responsibility in governing Scotland. He also joked about the competition from the UK budget announcement and wished good luck to those standing in the forthcoming election. Annabel Goldie, a Scottish Conservative MSP, joked about her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney and expressed her fondness for the political process. Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved by the speeches, particularly those of Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is seeking experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people and those who care for them, highlighting the positive impact of high-quality care and expressing concern about unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While the review is supported by Care Forum Wales, its chair, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that the advisory panel does not include a provider expert.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to the end of June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates a network of 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, attributed the profit growth to international sales growth in Europe and new markets. The company also noted the challenging agricultural industry and the uncertain impact of Brexit, but expressed confidence in its position to navigate future challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. The investigation is still in its early stages, but the death is being treated as murder. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft (1.8m) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, highlighted the risks to the global economy in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington on Tuesday. He noted that the IMF's latest assessment of the global economy indicates a weakening baseline and a delicate juncture. This follows weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, where exports plunged by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it releases its next economic predictions in April. This dismal picture has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that have bet on China's growth story.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing at Cowes would be free until July 2 to acknowledge the issues and gather feedback. A review of the project has been ordered by auditors due to the problematic start of the ferry service, which has included breakdowns, groundings, training issues, and vehicle damage. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on local businesses, asking if they would receive compensation similar to that provided for damaged vehicles. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the challenges but emphasized that the ferry is a prototype and that teething problems are expected. He noted that electrical issues have been resolved, ramp extensions have been authorized to prevent vehicle scraping, and seamanship issues have been addressed.

A 32-year-old man was killed in a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at about 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while officers investigated the scene.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, has faced criticism for its discriminatory hiring practices. The agency advertises for roles based on physical appearance, such as a personal assistant with "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver" to drive a Porsche Cayenne. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has called these practices "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women" and plans to write to Matching Models to clarify their hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners have also criticized the agency, with Sam Smethers of the Fawcett Society stating that the ads are "straight out of the 1970s" and a "timely reminder" of the ongoing battle for gender equality.

The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practices, stating that "looks are important" to their clients and that they understand the importance of having the right people representing a company. However, employment lawyer James Lynas has stated that the use of phrases such as "beautiful and attractive" could be interpreted as code for "young" and discriminatory against older women. He also pointed out that a male driver who genuinely wanted the job could sue for sex discrimination if rejected, with compensation being unlimited.

Matching Models' clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods. Jansen also mentioned that MTV wanted models with tattoos and piercings, highlighting the agency's willingness to cater to specific client requests.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to a private school in Bangalore city, India, where an office assistant named Mahesh allegedly shot and killed an 18-year-old student named Gautami and severely injured another student named Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and is currently remanded until April 12. The motive for the shooting is unclear, and incidents of gun crime at schools and colleges in India are rare. India has strict gun control laws, although a large number of feuds are settled with firearms.

Glaad's Where We Are on TV study found that there were 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters on shows aired between June 2016 and May 2017. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off or met violent ends, including Poussey Washington in Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth. The study also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis said it was "heartening to see progress being made" but emphasized that numbers were "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The BBC reported that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished. Mackintosh, who was the leader of the borough council at the time, was criticized over the loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land. About £10.25m of that money is now missing and the loan is subject to a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities". The football stand remains half built. When contacted by the BBC last week, a majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him. Mackintosh had previously said he intended to stand for re-election but in a statement, he said, "It has been a huge honour to be the member of Parliament since 2015, but I now feel it is the right time for my constituents to have a new representative."

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was charged with murder and aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official after fatally shooting 15-year-old Jordan Edwards and injuring four other teenagers with his rifle. The incident occurred in Balch Springs, Texas, when police responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Oliver was fired from the police force for policy violations. The case is being prosecuted by the Dallas County District Attorney's office, and no trial date has been set. If convicted, Oliver could face up to 99 years in prison, which would make him the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. The Edwards family's lawyer expressed caution about the outcome, citing the rarity of police officer convictions in Texas.

The passage discusses the decision of Melania Trump, the incoming First Lady, to delay moving to the White House until her son, Barron, finishes the school year. This move is unusual, as most First Ladies have moved into the White House immediately after their husbands' inaugurations. The article also explores the historical context of First Ladies and their roles, highlighting that only two other First Ladies in U.S. history have not lived in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. It also mentions the responsibilities and public roles of First Ladies, including their support for various initiatives and causes. The article concludes by noting that the White House can be a "normal" family environment, as seen with previous First Families.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October, and the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been asked to investigate the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is fully cooperating with the investigation and awaits its findings. A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) in due course.

A yellow warning of wind has been issued, with gusts of up to 75mph expected locally, particularly to the west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction could add to the impact of the winds, with disruption to travel on roads and at sea likely. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree was brought down by gusts overnight in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing one of the main routes into the town. The council said Telford Road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday to allow clean-up work to be carried out.

The Giants secured a short-handed opener through player-coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal to make it 2-1, with Andy Bohmback equalizing. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle, and James Desmarais made it 4-2 before Nottingham's David Ling got one back. The teams will meet again on Saturday night in the second match of their double-header. Nottingham leads the league on 28 points, with Sheffield Steelers on 27 and Belfast on 25.

The Chinese Grand Prix saw a dramatic start with multiple collisions on the first lap, leading to the introduction of the safety car. World champion Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one and had to make five pit stops. Despite colliding with his team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, Sebastian Vettel finished second. Raikkonen fought back to fifth place, passing Hamilton in the closing stages. Hamilton expressed confidence in eroding Rosberg's points lead but faces an uphill battle to stop Rosberg from winning his first world title this year.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, becoming the most prominent footballer to do so. His announcement was met with widespread support from fellow players, football administrators, and politicians, who praised his courage and called it an important step in the fight against homophobia in football. Hitzlsperger's decision is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football remains a significant issue. The German Football Association is now urged to encourage active players to follow Hitzlsperger's example and break down the taboo surrounding homosexuality in football.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played a key role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League, making 32 Championship appearances this season. With his contract expiring at the end of the campaign, he is hoping to sign a new deal to continue contributing to the team's success in the top flight. Sidwell has previously played in the Premier League with several clubs and believes he deserves another opportunity to play at the highest level. He has expressed confidence in Brighton's ability to stay in the Premier League and is eager to secure a new contract to be part of the team's future.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in a match that saw both teams have their chances to win. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized from a corner just five minutes later. The game was evenly matched, with both teams creating several opportunities. Blackpool should have won it late on, but Tom Aldred missed a free header from a corner. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The 29-year-old player, who has had spells with Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. They could make their debut for the U's in the EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5m towards the construction of a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, to honor the courage and sacrifice of over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial, expected to be completed by 2019, will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to the families of fallen officers, with the names of loved ones as a personal memorial. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial, which is intended to become a lasting tribute to the vital contribution of policing to society and the courage and sacrifice of those who have paid the ultimate price.

Manchester United maintained a 15-point lead at the top of the Premier League table with eight games remaining after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on the upcoming matches, particularly the derby against Manchester City, despite their commanding lead. The club has won 50 of the last 54 points in the Premier League and is aiming to surpass Chelsea's record of 95 points in a season. Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea. Despite these setbacks, Ferguson expressed confidence in the team's ability to handle the challenges ahead.

Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, which it claims was the legally required amount. The company routes most of its UK sales through Ireland to minimize its tax liability. Google Chairman Eric Schmidt has argued that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are conducted, rather than where products are consumed. He has also called for a debate on international tax reform and suggested that politicians, not companies, should set the rules. The European Union has agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities.

NHS Improvement is urging the NHS to make more progress in reducing its agency bill, which reached £3.6bn last year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far, limiting non-senior staff pay to 55% above normal shift rates. However, the NHS is 10% short of its target, and it's unclear if spending on other parts of the pay bill has increased. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of trust performance and investigate high agency staff earnings, including examples of hospitals being quoted double the capped rates.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a hub of commerce during Ireland's economic boom, now symbolizes the downturn following the Celtic Tiger's collapse. Local businesses, such as Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop, have faced significant challenges, including a 30% drop in revenue and staff layoffs. However, O'Brien reports a recent uptick in business, attributing this to diversifying offerings and adapting to market demands.

The opposition party, Fianna Fáil, criticizes the current government's handling of the midlands, particularly regarding a half-billion euro investment in water meters that won't be operational for years. They advocate for redirecting these funds to improve broadband infrastructure, arguing that such investments are crucial for attracting foreign direct investment.

In response, the government points to the planned Center Parcs development in Ballymahon, expected to create 1,000 jobs, as a positive step for the region. Despite this, traders like O'Brien emphasize the need for additional measures, such as eliminating parking charges, to further stimulate local commerce. The midlands region is cautiously optimistic about its economic recovery, though it underscores the necessity for continued and targeted efforts to ensure sustained growth.

The passage provides information about a cricket competition featuring eight teams, with fixtures and results, leading run-scorers, most sixes, highest scores in an innings, most wickets, and England players participating. The competition starts on 25 April and finishes on 29 May, with the top four sides qualifying for the play-offs. The passage also mentions that there are four current or former England players taking part in the tournament, including Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The passage provides a detailed schedule of fixtures and results, with all matches starting at 15:30 BST unless stated otherwise.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs has reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013. These bags are often non-recyclable and end up in landfills and rivers, causing environmental harm. To address this issue, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October, following the lead of Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar charges have led to a decrease in bag usage. Campaigners hope the charge will reduce the number of bags being discarded, thereby benefiting the environment.

A school roof was ripped off in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, Gwynedd, and hundreds of homes across Wales experienced power cuts due to high winds. The day saw train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and power cuts for hundreds of homes. Irish Ferries canceled six of its fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin due to "adverse weather conditions" on the Irish Sea, transferring passengers to their cruise ferry services. Arriva Trains Wales warned of "speed restrictions and possible delays" for all services between Llandudno Junction to Holyhead due to the winds. The National Trust also closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the expected high winds. Winds eased into Friday evening, with earlier restrictions on both the A55 Britannia Bridge in north Wales and the M48 Severn Bridge in Monmouthshire lifted. However, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend has seen at least one festive event postponed - Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in the sea in Denbighshire will now go ahead 24 hours later, on Tuesday, 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan will star in the upcoming film Black Panther, reuniting with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. He expressed excitement about the project and working with Coogler again, as well as with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the Fantastic Four reboot, while Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. Black Panther is set to be released in February 2018.

Alexandra Palace's east wing, including its historic theatre and BBC studios, is undergoing a £26.6 million restoration to transform it into a new cultural destination. The project, funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, Haringey Council, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, aims to reopen the theatre in 2018. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, still retains much of its original decor and stage machinery and was originally designed for opera, musicals, plays, and other forms of entertainment, including early cinema screenings.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England. He made his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a devastating house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, thanks to her son David, who noticed the flames while on FaceTime with his father. The entire house was engulfed in flames within seconds, and the kitchen disappeared while they were standing in it. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, a routine action for Marcy. The family had nothing but pyjamas on when they fled, but the community has provided clothing, shoes, and even a bike for David. Marcy is proud of her son and plans to remind him of his heroic actions for the rest of his life.

The energy drinks giant is considering a £200m offer for West Ham, which was bought by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 for £105m. Sullivan and Gold now own more than 85% of the club. West Ham has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan said last year that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intend to pass ownership on to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards featured a mix of fan-voted awards, promotional content for upcoming blockbusters, and emotional moments. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking home best movie, best female performance for Shailene Woodley, and best kiss for a scene with Ansel Elgort. Woodley dedicated her speech to the book's author, John Green. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, while Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street. Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award and brought his kids on stage to accept it. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, with fellow Avengers stars presenting it to him. The show also featured clips from upcoming films, including Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Ultron.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 cap, has been loaned to United by Aberdeen, where he has scored five goals this season. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, expressed his delight at acquiring Smith, describing him as a "really good player" and a "mature boy" who will provide another option in the attacking area.

Northumberland County Council is addressing potholes and drainage issues. With warmer weather, their Jetpatcher machines will fill approximately 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will repair drainage systems and clear debris from gutters damaged by heavy rain.

In December 2016, six workers on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. The exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but the workers were not provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE). The workers, employed by Wood Group, were downmanned from the platform for medical assessments, and EnQuest and Wood Group conducted a joint investigation. The workers now face cancer fears, and blood tests are ongoing. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was made aware of the incident but did not carry out an investigation as it was not reportable under the present RIDDOR system.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. In 2012, the dealer's manager confessed to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the sculpture, which is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. Following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the ACM decided to return the sculpture. The museum will take legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence, with no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Several aftershocks of lower magnitude were felt across a large area, and phone lines were down and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools in the immediate vicinity were evacuated and were to be checked for any damage. In Milan, the top floors of tall office blocks shook, and the quake was also felt in the cities of Bologna and Modena. The INGV described the latest tremor as a classic earthquake for the area - "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow."

A 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, Austin Grant, had doubts about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruit. However, he has now seen some results and is thrilled with the outcome.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of Grand Theft Auto V until 24 March, citing the need for additional testing and polish. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release, and released screenshots of the PC version, promising even greater levels of detail. The game became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever when it was released in 2013, generating $1 billion in revenue in just three days.

The 76-year-old artist, who received the £25,000 prize for Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, was one of the shortlisted artists in 1991. Simpson, who has also made the prize longlist on three other occasions, said finally winning was "very nice indeed". Judge Ansel Krut said Squint (19) was "quite extraordinary", even though it was a "difficult painting to look at". The work depicts a leper squint, which Simpson said were "holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service and somehow take part". He said it was one of a series of paintings he has been working on, some of which were "much bigger". The relatively small size of Squint (19) - which is about 7ft (2.1m) in height - was one of the reasons Simpson entered it into the competition, though he also admitted that it "seemed to be a good idea to send one that I was conversant with and was working with". He said the prize money would be spent on "stretches, canvas and - particularly - good quality paints". "I spend a lot of money on materials, so this money is going to go to a good cause." Krut said Simpson's piece was "a little bit like a tone poem - when you spend some time with it, it gradually starts to build a picture". "Technically, it's very subtle and his language is very minimal, very reduced, but when you enter into it, you get into this broad field of great sympathy, because of the subject matter. "We couldn't have asked for a better painting." Established in 1957, the biennial John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards. Previous winners include David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, who is now the prize's patron, won the junior title in 1961.

The offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit in Istanbul were attacked by masked assailants who shattered windows with gunfire. No casualties were reported, and firefighters quickly extinguished the blaze at Yeni Safak. Both papers support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously, and police are now hunting the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

A 24-year-old player, previously on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, has been signed by Marcus Bignot's side on a free transfer. The player, who was under contract with the Stags, will officially join on 1 January and becomes Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has been linked with the England manager's job, but he said he is focused on his current role. Southgate, who has been in charge for two games, is looking to impress the Football Association with his decisions and competency. Wenger also confirmed that defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract, despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. Meanwhile, midfielder Aaron Ramsey is expected to miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. The Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, with the company fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on board two freight boats, Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck on behalf of Serco Northlink. The RMT union had claimed that some workers were paid less than £4 an hour, a claim Seatruck disputed, arguing that the national minimum wage did not apply to their non-UK resident crew. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap, but Seatruck declined. The new charter arrangement will see contracted services return to Serco Northlink from next month, subject to financial and regulatory details being finalized. All crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage going forward.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, Samantha, 57. The court heard that Jamie Mitchell had pleaded guilty to common assault and attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the course of events. The jury at Winchester Crown Court found Jamie Mitchell guilty of the charges. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter and keyboardist, passed away at the age of 66 in London after a brief battle with cancer. He was known for his work with Michael Jackson, including the hits "Off The Wall," "Baby Be Mine," and "Rock With You," as well as his contributions to Jackson's album Thriller. Temperton also wrote songs for Heatwave, including "Boogie Nights" and "Always & Forever," and collaborated with artists such as Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Aretha Franklin. His songwriting approach was to create music that he loved first, and he won a Grammy Award in 1990 for his work on Birdland. Temperton's private funeral has taken place, and his family has requested total privacy during this time.

A team of researchers, including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, have discovered ancient earthworks in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. The geoglyphs, over 450 large geometrical structures, were hidden for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. The function of these sites is still not fully understood, but they are thought to have been used sporadically for ritual gatherings, similar to the Maya pyramids of Central America or Britain's Stonehenge. The researchers also found evidence of human influence on the Amazonian forests, with a wide variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, suggesting that people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees such as palms. The team likened it to a prehistoric supermarket of useful forest products.

Nick Kyrgios, the 21-year-old Australian tennis player, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, currently ranked 12th in the world, won the Japan Open on Sunday and is closing in on the top 10. He attributed his subdued demeanor during the match to fatigue, stating that he was tired and just wanted to get the job done. Kyrgios cited his success in Japan and the travel involved in playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium, an hour from Shanghai city center, as contributing factors to his exhaustion. He also mentioned that he didn't have the greatest sleep the night before and got in late the day before. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 (£984) for a foul-mouthed outburst, describing the tournament as a "circus."

The human papilloma virus (HPV) jab is being called for to be rolled out to boys in Wales, as the number of head and neck cancer cases is increasing. HPV is a sexually transmitted virus that can cause cervical cancer in women, and head and neck cancer in men. The vaccination program was rolled out in schools in 2008, with 85% of girls in Wales being vaccinated. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes to the vaccination program. Charities and organizations are urging the Welsh government to take a progressive step and vaccinate boys now to stem the tide of these cancers.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare form of blood cancer, briefly attended a school prom held in his honor on Saturday but had to leave due to illness. His mother Allison announced his death on his Facebook page, expressing her pride and love for him. Jak had been documenting his life and treatment on social media since his diagnosis last August, attracting over 28,000 likes on his Jak's Journey page. Despite his illness, Jak managed to make it to his prom for 10 minutes, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. He also received his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity at the event. Jak's family collected the awards on his behalf. The Jak's Journey website highlighted Jak's stay at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh and Yorkhill Hospital in Glasgow, where he was visited by players from various sports teams and the cast of the musical Wicked. Jak and his family also shared personal moments, including him playing his tuba and visiting his classmates and teachers at school. On January 23, Jak and his family learned that his cancer had spread throughout his body, and doctors decided not to pursue any further treatment. Jak expressed his gratitude to the doctors, nurses, and everyone who had helped him over the past six months. In the days after receiving the news, Jak's family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. A special football match is being held at the Energy Assets Arena, home of Livingston FC, on Sunday to raise more money for charity.

Egypt secured a late 1-0 victory over Uganda in their Africa Cup of Nations Group D match, with Abdallah El Said scoring the decisive goal in the 89th minute. The win keeps Egypt in contention for the top spot in the group, while Uganda is eliminated from their first tournament since 1978. The game was marked by a lack of clear chances, with Uganda's Joseph Ochaya having a goal disallowed for offside. Egypt will face Ghana on Wednesday, with the outcome of that match determining the group winner.

Lancashire County Council has identified two potential sites for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, following a comparative study by Network Rail. The sites include the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus, both of which are currently unused. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The preferred site is large enough for future expansion and has good highway access and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The authority will now begin the process of acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station.
Police discovered a grow house in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, where they found plants and arrested a man in his late 40s.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries on a pavement in Hamelin, Germany, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. The suspect, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, turned himself in to authorities. The motive for the attack is not yet clear, and police have secured the area and called for witnesses to come forward.

The study found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are 25% less likely to receive one. This challenges the popular theory that women are less likely to ask for a pay rise due to reticence or fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The study, conducted by the Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzed 4,600 workers and found no evidence to support the idea that women are less likely to ask for a pay rise. The study also found that women and men under 40 both ask for and receive pay rises at the same rate, which could indicate that negotiating behavior is changing. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey and took into account factors such as the size of the employer, industry, parental status, and qualifications.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has been unable to find a suitable location. Two cemeteries, in Wolvercote and Botley, still have space but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. After these cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature allows visitors to trigger online information from signs and posters on the site, including videos and band interviews, on their phones and tablets. The app will also enable people worldwide to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere remotely. The app will be updated before and during the event, providing instant access to information, interviews, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival's unique atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary hemorrhage, a rare incident that can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite showing symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, Many Clouds had never collapsed before and had shown no symptoms on Saturday. The horse had won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime."

A 34-year-old woman, Davina Ayrton, has been convicted of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, who identifies as a transgender woman, has denied the charge and will be sentenced on March 4. Judge Ian Pearson has remanded her into custody, noting the risk she poses to herself and the likelihood of her failing to attend court. Ayrton will be held at a male prison in Winchester, as per the judge's decision. The court heard that Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer and has since changed her name. The jury was told that Ayrton raped the teenager while two others were asleep in the garage, and the victim shouted and swore at Ayrton to stop the attack. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of Foster's, clearly recalled the events. Ayrton informed a worker at the care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, about the attack in 2014.

The Serbs, led by world number one Novak Djokovic, lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This defeat came a day after Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. The loss adds to Djokovic's recent struggles, including a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon and a return to claim his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The Carving in the Cairngorms event in Carrbridge features over 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, Canada, the US, and continental Europe. The carvers can only use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Pete Bowsher, last year's winner from Moffat, will return to defend his title and retain the Claymore Trophy.

Gareth Webb, a Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a foot injury sustained in September during a World Cup warm-up match against Italy. He is expected to return to play in early February, in time for the Six Nations tournament. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region despite other offers. He is currently in a pre-season training phase and is optimistic about his recovery progress.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near the Canadian border in Washington. One of the men fled and fired a weapon at the agents, while the other was taken into custody. The backpacks contained a total of 58 pounds of ecstasy. A woman and her boyfriend were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs. The fugitive was later arrested in British Columbia. The wooded area near the border is a known smuggling route for drugs and firearms. The three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 children counselled in the past year compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The total number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher. Some children as young as seven have reported being tormented, abused, and scared to go to school. The charity has highlighted the misery and humiliation caused by online trolls, with thousands of children affected. Dame Esther Rantzen, president of Childline, has called for a wake-up call, emphasizing that cyber-bullying can follow children home and become a persecution they cannot escape. She stressed the importance of adults, parents, and teachers intervening to protect children, as bullying does not stop on its own. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem. One young person who contacted Childline shared their experience of being told to kill themselves by peers online, highlighting the emotional impact of such abuse. Advice from young people on dealing with bullying includes seeking help and not suffering in silence.

The Israeli government has postponed a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. The move comes ahead of a speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by US Secretary of State John Kerry and after the US chose not to veto a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction. The resolution, which passed on Friday, stated that the establishment of settlements "has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law and a major obstacle to the achievement of the two-state solution and a just, lasting and comprehensive peace." Israel rejected the resolution, and the BBC's Yolande Knell said it was particularly angry about the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem - which it sees as part of its capital, but which the Palestinians want as the capital of their future state.

The Queen, who is Britain's longest-reigning monarch, celebrated her 90th birthday on April 21st. She was praised by her grandson, Prince William, who described her as a "guiding example" of what a good monarch should be. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited the Royal Mail delivery office in Windsor and attended a ceremony to officially open a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens. She will also light a beacon to start a series of over 900 beacons across the UK and around the world to mark the milestone birthday. The Queen's birthday has been criticized by some, with the BBC being accused of failing to report the birthday in a fair, balanced, and proportionate way.

West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory over Cheltenham Town in the EFL Cup, with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. The Premier League side made seven changes from their previous league games, while Cheltenham remained unchanged after a 3-0 league defeat. The hosts had opportunities, including a volley from Harry Pell and a header from Jordon Forster, but West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian was rarely tested. The match saw several chances for both teams, with West Ham's James Collins and Byram both coming close to adding to the scoreline.

Aiden McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old from Leipzig, failed to spot McNicholl as he turned his VW Transporter, causing the fatal crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to go to jail, accepting it was a momentary lapse.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, is facing a possible life sentence for his role in the Syrian conflict. Khawaja, who called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, left the UK last January to join the warzone via Kurdish territory. He documented his experiences on social media, including videos and pictures of his personal jihad, such as a fellow fighter being shot and his amateur weight-lifting skills. Khawaja was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group of British fighters affiliated with Islamic State, and was involved in appeals for donations, video diaries, and "through the keyhole" tours of fighters' quarters.

Khawaja's intentions upon returning to the UK are unclear, but he was considered so dangerous that he was held in a special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's maximum-security Belmarsh prison while on remand. He has admitted to four offenses, and the most serious charge against him, soliciting to murder, will lie on file. Khawaja's cousin, Tahir Bhatti, has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

Wrexham's 22-year-old forward, Kayden Jackson, has joined Barnsley after scoring four goals in 36 appearances last season. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham for next season.

Bottles of 'Vanish' have washed up on Cornish beaches, believed to have been lost from a container ship during stormy weather in May. The National Trust, which owns Poldhu Cove, is clearing the bottles away as they pose a risk to wildlife and could leak detergent into the marine environment. Other nearby coves have also been affected, and Cornwall Council is monitoring the situation. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency has stated that there is no evidence linking the bottles to the lost container, but the National Trust believes it is likely.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at around 2 PM, resulting in one fatality and minor injuries to several others. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is still investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a French center-back, joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. He made 14 appearances last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite for his excellent contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite has signed a new contract with Bolton, following David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in doing so.

The passage describes a political conflict between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour in the UK Parliament, focusing on their differing stances on Brexit and their history of cooperation on other issues. The Lib Dems accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything" and giving people "false hope" regarding the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. Labour, in turn, criticized the Lib Dems for "grandstanding" and building up "false hope" among constituents. Despite their past alliances on various issues, the two parties have now clashed over Brexit, with Labour predicting "residual tensions" and a continued business-like approach to their relationship.

The passage discusses the declining importance of defense in UK politics, the challenges faced by the UK military, and the political parties' positions on defense issues. It highlights the public's waning interest in defense, the significant cuts to the armed forces, and the UK's reduced global defense spending. The passage also explores the political parties' stances on defense, including the commitment to renewing Trident, the challenges of maintaining a credible nuclear deterrent, and the difficulties in sustaining a robust military force amidst budget constraints.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of Neymar, including signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and this latest tax payment, is £106.8m. Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money, and a judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona denies any tax-related crime and has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56. The case has not been dropped, and Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a motorway crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way. Mr. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for older drivers, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older drivers to maintain their independence. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) maintains that there is no evidence to suggest that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents and that all drivers over 70 must renew their licenses every three years and report any medical conditions that may affect their driving.

The Scottish government commissioned an independent review of transvaginal mesh implants, which concluded that these procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse. Instead, patients should be given a range of treatment options and information to make informed choices. The report also recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the health secretary confirmed that the recommendations would be implemented, as the government does not have the power to ban the procedures. The chairwoman of the review apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the controversial final report. The review process will now be examined by an independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, to assess the process and identify lessons for the future.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Eilish McColgan's 25-year-old Scottish indoor 5,000m record at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow on Wednesday, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan raised concerns about whether Muir's race had met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan said Muir had what it took to win world medals and predicted that she could run a 5K in around 14 minutes and 30 seconds. Muir previously broke her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris in August and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won the event, with Astier Nicolas taking silver and Phillip Dutton winning bronze. William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, despite a disappointing cross-country performance that dropped him from 1st to 21st place. Fox-Pitt, who was competing just 10 months after being placed in an induced coma following a fall, produced a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase. Jonty Evans finished 9th on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini in a four-set match that lasted two hours and 39 minutes, with the final set point clinched at 20:57 BST. Murray won 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. Fognini, the 29th seed, had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row to seal a place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray looked like avoiding a long, drawn-out contest when he moved ahead early in the third set but a Friday night drama would develop as the light faded. Fognini showed both his talented and temperamental sides as he got within sight of a fifth set, which would have required the roof to be brought across or both men to return on Saturday. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday.

A sudden death occurred at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. O'Neill, the license holder, had an "appalling record" and was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched the party's manifesto with the statement, "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." The manifesto includes calls for action on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community, and guaranteeing that no group is worse off because of Brexit. Nesbitt also addressed the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle, stating that the election should be a referendum on how it was handled. He emphasized the need for partnership and collaboration, particularly with the SDLP, in the aftermath of the election. Despite criticism from some party colleagues, Nesbitt expressed confidence in his position and the party's platform.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will go before the Northern Ireland assembly for approval, bringing the region in line with England and Wales. The motion will allow for posthumous pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses, as well as allow living men convicted of such offenses to apply for a pardon. The minister secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offenses. The motion is expected to contain the same provisions as those announced in England and Wales last month, dubbed 'Turing's Law' after World War Two code-breaker Alan Turing. The minister said arrangements would be brought in "as soon as possible to ensure that there is equal treatment for gay and bisexual men here as for their counterparts in England and Wales."

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, Scotland, set a new Scottish record in the mile with a time of 4:19.12, surpassing Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60. Muir's performance also placed her second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd's 4:17.57. Muir, who finished fifth in last year's World Championships, expressed her excitement about the achievement and her hopes of securing a spot on the British Olympic team for Rio. She started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and plans to compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm next week. Muir fits her training around her veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
The passage provides a list of Scotland's "most excellent" beaches for water quality, featuring 26 locations.

The inquiry into the 2006 poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in London concluded that the Russian state was likely responsible for the murder. The two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive to kill Litvinenko, who had defected to the UK in 2000 after accusing the FSB of political assassinations and corruption. The UK officials believe that the two suspects poisoned Litvinenko with a fatal dose of radioactive substance polonium-210 during a meeting. Litvinenko died in hospital nearly three weeks later. The fact that polonium caused his death indicates some form of Russian state participation, according to Richard Horwell QC, the Met Police barrister. However, Horwell stressed that this did not mean that Russian President Vladimir Putin was involved or gave the order, and that there were many possible motives for the murder. The risk to the general public in London from polonium radiation will never be known, and Litvinenko had been poisoned twice in the run-up to his death. The two suspects left a "trail of polonium" behind and had "no credible answer" to the scientific evidence against them. Attempts to extradite the two men have failed, and they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke, 34, who retired after the Ashes series. Smith, who has played 32 Tests and scored 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66, has already captained the side in three Tests against India last summer. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain, despite a history of disciplinary problems. The selectors believe that Warner has matured and developed into an important senior figure in the team and will respond well to the added responsibility of leadership.

Tim Farron, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, has expressed his support for LGBT+ rights and equal marriage. He refused to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin but emphasized his belief in the sinfulness of all individuals. Farron voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, which he said were not adequately addressed in the bill. He is committed to defending equal marriage and extending marital rights for transgender people, particularly addressing the spousal veto that currently prevents equal access to marriage for transgender individuals.

Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Now, Accord Healthcare plans to use the plant for pharmaceutical production, with the hope that many of the jobs will be filled by ex-Sanofi staff. The company is confident that the investment will have a very positive impact on the area. Councillor Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council, said the announcement is fantastic news for Newcastle and the North East, and helps strengthen the region's reputation as a home for the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes more than 130 pharmaceutical products to about 60 countries worldwide.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions. Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract. Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, attributed the departures to the council's inability to retain senior staff and predicted further departures in the coming months. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for the trio's dedication and professionalism.

Guy Martin, an English rider, crashed at this year's TT and experienced mechanical issues with the Fireblade bike. He initially announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified that he would not be racing on Hondas this year. Martin missed the North West 200 due to his team-mate's crash and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a disaster and expressed a desire to race classics and oddball stuff in the future.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The APC's victory includes key northern states and Lagos, Nigeria's commercial hub, but the party failed to win in any of the five oil-producing states. The PDP retained control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The elections were more peaceful than in previous years, but violence and ethnic differences still marred the process in some areas. The PDP's decline is attributed to voter fatigue after 16 years in power, widespread allegations of corruption, and failure to address the Islamist-led insurgency in the north-east. The APC's victory presents challenges for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari, as the party does not control any oil-producing states, potentially complicating efforts to rein in militants.

The passage discusses allegations made by Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, against Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, a Singapore state-owned investment company. Mighty accuses Olam and Temasek of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the haze caused by slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia. Olam and Temasek deny the allegations.

Olam sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and accounts for less than 1% of the global market. The company has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy and has released the names of its 14 suppliers. Temasek has dismissed the allegations, stating that it does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies, including Olam.

The passage also highlights concerns about Olam's operations in Gabon, where Mighty alleges that Olam is responsible for vast forest clearings through its joint ventures with the Gabonese government. Olam denies these allegations and states that its plans and progress for developing sustainable palm oil plantations have been shared transparently with stakeholders and put in the public domain.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters after a new law was introduced allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, as long as they were outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee injury, while David Nugent could return from a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield is pushing for a recall after scoring a late equalizer against Huddersfield.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator has lifted the ban on YouTube, imposed in 2012 after the US-made film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded. The ban was lifted because Google, which owns YouTube, has now launched a Pakistan-specific version. Google has provided an online web process through which requests for blocking access to offending material can be made by the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to Google directly. However, a YouTube spokeswoman said that government requests for the removal of content would not automatically be granted and that YouTube has clear community guidelines. Pakistan's ministry of information technology said that Google/YouTube will accordingly restrict access to the said offending material for users within Pakistan.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as is one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections due to sharing nationality with a candidate, Swiss Sepp Blatter. Musa Bility, head of the Liberian Football Association (LFA), has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which states that any committee member with a conflict of interest must be replaced. Scala withdrew in 2015 due to the incumbent president also being Swiss, but Andreas Bantel, a spokesman for Scala, argues that there is no conflict of interest this time as there is no incumbent president. The election, which will be voted on by Fifa's 209 members, will take place at the organization's headquarters in Zurich on February 26th.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday. The men were believed to have been working in a paint-spraying area when the explosion occurred, causing a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is investigating the incident, and forensic inquiries and witness statements are being gathered.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until apologizing to Caf for complaints it lodged against the organization during this year's Nations Cup. Morocco, meanwhile, was only able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on its participation. Both countries are now preparing for a future full of good things for both Africa and Morocco.

Morocco was punished in February after being replaced as 2015 Nations Cup hosts last November, just two months before the competition began. The North Africans refused to stage the tournament in January 2015, citing fears over importing the Ebola virus, and asked for a postponement of either six or twelve months instead. Earlier this month, Cas overturned Caf's ruling and reduced a fine imposed on Morocco's FA from $1m (£675,000) to $50,000 (£34,000). Equatorial Guinea stepped in to stage the 2015 finals, despite having just 64 days to prepare.

The host nation was also at the center of the incident that led to Tunisia's row with Caf, which the local federation (FTF) says is now over. Tunisia was leading 1-0 in the 90th minute of their quarter-final against the hosts when they were awarded a highly contentious penalty. The spot-kick was converted and Equatorial Guinea went on to win 2-1 in extra-time, as the Tunisian players and bench largely lost their heads as tempers flared. The Tunisians wrote a furious letter to Caf in response, which prompted African football's ruling body to demand an apology by 31 March 2015 or face disqualification from the next Nations Cup. Contrary to media reports, the Tunisia Football Federation insists it never accused Caf nor Mauritian referee Rajindraparsad Seechurn of corruption.

Tunisia's 2017 participation seemed in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou and others in Senegal in mid-March led to a rapprochement. "Luckily, with the strong pressure of Issa Hayatou, with whom I had a meeting in Dakar where we discussed our difference, we've managed to turn the page," said Snoussi. "We are very happy to be playing the (2017) Nations Cup and I feel this difference has been now completely ironed out." Following last week's draw in Cairo, Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A while Morocco will Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. Should the Tunisians reach the 2017 finals in Gabon, they will reach their thirteenth straight Nations Cup - which would be a record.

Following a 3-1 win for Chelsea over Manchester City at Etihad Stadium, a mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute of the game. City's Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, while Chelsea's Fabregas will not face further action. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, and Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales, along with other parts of the UK, has some of the highest cancer rates despite being a developed country. A pilot program in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd is focusing on patients whose GPs suspect cancer but show no clear signs or symptoms. This initiative comes a year after doctors visited Denmark to study their diagnostic systems, which have improved cancer survival rates. Concerns have been raised that patients in Wales without clear symptoms are waiting too long for a diagnosis due to the need for multiple referrals and tests, which can take weeks. The pilot program aims to address this by enabling GPs in Cwm Cynon to refer suspected cancer patients directly to the Royal Glamorgan Hospital in Llantrisant for rapid assessment and diagnosis. If successful, the program could be expanded to other areas.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, winning by an innings and 55 runs to level the four-match series. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook contributed with 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan struggled with their batting, scoring only 198 in the first innings and 234 in the second, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq reaching 50. The third Test is set to take place at Edgbaston on August 3rd.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has named Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. McBryde expressed his honor and excitement at leading the team again, and the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches to assist him on the summer tour. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips stated that discussions are ongoing with other individuals about the summer tour, with the full management team to be confirmed next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies, who is also on the Lions' selection panel, believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, providing them with valuable experience and inspiration for future campaigns.

Hull City secured a 2-1 victory over Southampton, marking their first win in the league since August. The game saw Hull's strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, leave the field due to injuries, but Robert Snodgrass's return from injury proved pivotal. Snodgrass scored a goal and assisted another, helping Hull overcome a 1-0 deficit from Charlie Austin's early penalty. The win ended Hull's six-game losing streak and lifted them out of the bottom three, at least temporarily.

A motorcyclist from the local area was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa at about 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was unharmed, and the police have appealed for witnesses. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia canceled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, citing a desire to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who deemed it illegal and a threat to the country's EU membership ambitions. The crisis was sparked by recordings that appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder, with opposition leader Zoran Zaev accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people, including politicians, journalists, and religious leaders. The government denies the accusations and has accused Zaev of trying to "destabilize" the Balkan nation.

Swansea City, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, is currently facing relegation and has recently sacked manager Bob Bradley. Assistant manager Curtis and Paul Williams will take charge of the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club is looking to appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as the top choice. Curtis believes that the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local area. He also highlights the need for stability and the loss of the 'Swansea Way' since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014.

Dagenham & Redbridge's 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient confirmed their relegation from League Two, ending their nine-year stay in the Football League. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona gave Dagenham hope after Jay Simpson's early brace, but Armand Gnanduillet's winner sealed their fate. Dagenham reached League One in 2010 under John Still, who returned for his third spell in December. The Daggers have the worst goal difference in League Two and have conceded 20 more goals this season than last. Leyton Orient's victory keeps their play-off hopes alive, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler taking over after Kevin Nolan's removal.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain and England international, is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998, has won the Champions League, Uefa Cup, FA Cup, and League Cup on multiple occasions. He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching license and has expressed a desire to become a manager in the future. Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp described Gerrard's appointment as "wonderful news" and praised his potential as a future manager.
