The sale, which is expected to fetch around £100,000, includes a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow made from yew with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding the bow. The auction also features paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and a fine collection of crystal chandeliers. The actor, who is a keen military historian and has written two books on the history of the longbow, is selling the items to downsize his home. The auction will take place on Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a Florida man wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead in their shared home in Winter Garden on Saturday. He is on the run from police after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. Shemansky is already on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His estranged wife has filed a domestic violence injunction against him and is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home. Authorities have the murder weapon but will not yet confirm how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Anyone with information as to his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene, USA, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, who bypassed the usual bidding process due to what they saw as a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council emphasized the importance of this opportunity to access a key market and develop the sport globally. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, targeted professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, after spotting him flashing a roll of £50 notes at a casino in London's West End. She used her good looks to befriend Hassan, who showered her with gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. Granger, from Gillingham, Kent, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter, while co-defendants Kyrron Jackson, 28, and Nicholas Chandler, 29, were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years. The court heard that Granger and her accomplices tied up Hassan and kicked him to death as they ransacked his home to find his hidden winnings. Granger's phone records were examined, leading to the arrest of the killers.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season. Despite a strong start, his form has dipped, and he has only managed one assist in his last five games. Fabregas captained Spain in their recent 2-0 defeat by Holland, but he was given a low rating by a Spanish newspaper. His former club, Barcelona, released a statement pointing out his traditional post-Christmas slump. However, with nine games remaining, Chelsea still has to face six opponents against whom Fabregas has laid on goals. If he can find his form again, he could help Chelsea secure the Premier League title.

West Ham United is in talks to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, a 17-year-old from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from clubs in Belgium. Additionally, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will be priced as low as £289 to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium when they move there for the 2016-17 season.

Wiltshire Police have dropped their investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of a suspected attacker. The attack, which took place on January 24, involved balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. Lane, who is joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was kicked in the head and suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Despite providing police with video footage and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of the saboteurs, the case has been recorded as undetected due to insufficient evidence. The decision has been met with dismay from Lane, his supporters, and the countryside alliance, who are campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to aid in the identification of criminals.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen and prominent member of Al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was not specifically targeted in the operation. He was born in 1978 and grew up on a farm in rural California. Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and left the United States for Pakistan three years later. In 2006, he was indicted by a federal grand jury in California for treason and material support to Al Qaeda. Gadahn was among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." He rose through the ranks in the tribal areas of Pakistan and became Al Qaeda's chief official English-language propagandist. Gadahn was killed along with another U.S. hostage, Warren Weinstein, in a strike on Al Qaeda.

A five-year-old Chinese boy, Mai Zizhuo, has become an internet sensation due to his exceptional basketball skills, which have drawn comparisons to professional players. The viral video shows him scoring hoops, dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, and maintaining rhythm effortlessly. His skills have garnered widespread praise and admiration, with thousands of comments from netizens expressing disbelief and awe. Some have even expressed a desire to reincarnate to start over and improve their basketball skills.

Tom O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE, formed in 1974, campaigned to legalize sex with children and allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to lobby for the age of sexual consent to be reduced to ten. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The empty pool was used as the unusual catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation, a lifestyle brand headed up by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss. The collection of ten pieces is designed to be worn in 20 different ways and is suitable for day-to-night wear. Guests were treated to nibbles by Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria as they took in the minimalist, androgynous designs. The show took place on an unseasonably warm 28 degrees Celsius day, and beautiful blue sky and sunshine were enjoyed throughout.

Amir Khan, the Bolton-born boxer, spent his Friday at a safari park in northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter, Lamysa. Khan fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent.

A Palestinian teenager's name will be removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism after his family and others complained. Mohammed Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His name appeared on the wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, the site of the national cemetery, as the nation prepared to mark its Memorial Day on Wednesday. Abu Khdeir's family objected to his inclusion on the memorial wall, and a picture on the memorial website for Abu Khdeir shows an Israeli flag with two flowers called "blood of the Maccabees" in Israel, a symbol often used on Memorial Day. Almagor, an organization that works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, also opposed Abu Khdeir's inclusion on the memorial, describing the teen's death as a rogue attack and saying he's not a terror victim. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his father's complaints.

A young boy in California persistently chases his family cat around the garden, attempting to use the cat as a pillow. The cat repeatedly moves to different spots, with the boy following each time. After the cat has had enough, it walks indoors, and the boy later makes up with the cat by feeding it treats.

Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer turned varsity basketball coach, lost his coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying in a police corruption trial in Philadelphia. Kushner, 32, admitted to selling marijuana in the past and testified that some undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. The charges from 2007 were expunged as part of a probationary sentence, but Kushner was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. He also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Despite this, Kushner believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges and never meant to deceive the school where he worked as a seasonal employee.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, caused a fire and injured six people. The blast, attributed to an oil leak, occurred at an oil storage facility, with no reports of toxic chemical spills. Over 600 firefighters were deployed to control the fire, which is now under control. The plant, previously slated for the densely populated city of Xiamen, was relocated to Zhangzhou due to pollution concerns.

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish, known for wearing his socks low, says he will continue to do so due to superstition, despite being told otherwise by referees. Grealish, who made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, wears children's shinpads and has not had a kick on his shin yet. He was pleased to finally make his first start for Villa and hopes to get more starts before the end of the season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Though she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Her father, Bobby Brown, said on stage that she had improved and was watching him, but her grandmother's statement indicated that she remains in the same neurological state she has been in for nearly three months. She does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow a person around the room. She also has a tracheostomy in her throat. Bobby Brown's wife, Alicia Etheredge-Brown, said he was in an "emotional state" when he made the remarks about his daughter being awake.

Russia is on the verge of securing a spot in the Fed Cup final, holding a 2-0 lead over Germany after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova's victory over Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in the second set before winning 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. The result leaves Russia needing just one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage, with another storm predicted to hit later this week. The State Emergency Service (SES) has already received over 24,000 requests for assistance, with more than 4,000 jobs still to be completed. The SES is particularly concerned about the effect of more wild weather on the Hunter region, which suffered through flooding and high winds in the last storm. The SES is urging the community to prepare themselves, their homes, and their families to prevent further loss and devastation. The weather system appears to be moving quickly, and the main impacts of intense rainfall and strong winds are expected to be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coast.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" music video, has denied claims that she attempted to take her own life. She stated that she was treated in hospital for low blood pressure after collapsing at home. Moric posted photographs of her injuries on Instagram, showing heavy bruising on her arms. Italian media had reported that Moric's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested that she had tried to commit suicide. However, Moric clarified that she was at home with her mother when the accident occurred and that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time. She reassured her fans that she was recovering at home and only needed some rest.

Kate and William are expecting their second child, and the British public is hoping for a traditional name. A YouGov survey for The Sunday Times revealed that 12% of respondents preferred the name Diana for a girl, in honor of William's mother, the late Princess of Wales. Alice and Charlotte were the next most popular names for a girl, each receiving 9% of the vote. If the baby is a boy, 13% of respondents preferred the name James, with Alexander as the second most popular choice. The poll also showed that 25% of respondents hoped for a girl, while only 3% wanted a younger brother for George. Additionally, 68% of respondents supported William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded 64, including an Afghan lawmaker, in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday. The attack occurred as the group, led by Humayoon Humayoon, an Afghan member of parliament for Khost province, was on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves, Barcelona's Brazilian right-back, is set to leave the club this summer after rejecting their final contract offer. Alves, who has been with Barcelona for seven years, has won four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, he has been unable to agree on a new deal with the club and will leave the Nou Camp this summer. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves had rejected a three-year contract extension that was dependent on him participating in 60% of the club's matches.

Pablo Osvaldo has recommended that Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti join him at Boca Juniors. The 29-year-old, currently on loan at Boca from Southampton, has praised the duo's abilities and believes they would be a great fit for the Argentinian giants. Osvaldo, who has played with many great players over the years, feels that Pirlo and Totti, with their South American style, would be perfect for Boca and would be hugely popular with the fans at the Bombonera.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, gained internet fame for a spectacular double somersault fall from the favorite, Merrion Square, at Wincanton. Despite the fall, he returned to riding out the next morning with just a cut on his nose. Ferguson described the fall as a blur and expressed gratitude for escaping serious injury. He also joked about considering a gymnastics career after his racing career.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, showcased his inner Iron Man in an Instagram post following the release of the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. Haskell, who returned to Wasps in 2012 after stints with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders, first joined Wasps in 2002 and has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club. The England flanker has also played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, and has earned 57 caps for his country.

The wide-leg trouser is a key trend for SS15, offering an effortless and stylish alternative to the skinny jean. This look, which has made a comeback since the seventies, can be intimidating, especially for shorter individuals. However, the key to pulling off this trend lies in the choice of footwear. High-heeled shoes that expose the top of the foot can elongate the leg, making it easier to wear cropped, voluminous trousers with confidence. Pairing wide-leg trousers with a simple knit, shirt, or tee can keep the outfit in proportion and prevent it from looking like a costume. Denim is an easy way to embrace this trend, with designers like Gucci and high-street brands like Topshop offering wide-leg options. For a dressier evening look, Celine and Stella McCartney showcased classy, wide-leg trousers. To shop for wide-leg trousers and get more inspiration, head to A Style Album.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. The initial decision to cancel the movie was not consistent with the high value the university places on freedom of expression and our respect for the right of students to make their own choices in such matters. The movie will be shown as part of UMIX, a series of social events the university stages for students. A counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider the decision to cancel the movie. The announcement drew praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to make contact with a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, which is the size of a domestic cat, survived but was singed by the flame. The men, aged 18 and 24 and currently living in Cockburn Central, were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

A 102-year-old former dancer, Alice Barker, was shown "soundies," early music videos, from her time as a chorus line dancer in New York nightclubs in the 1930s and 1940s. The videos, compiled by Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers, were shown to Barker at her nursing home. She was delighted to see herself dancing for the first time, exclaiming, "It's just fabulous."

The art of washing one's own car appears to be declining in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never washed their own car. The survey of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do saying they do it regularly. Only 5% of those surveyed said they had ever asked their children to wash the car as a way to earn extra pocket money. Factors behind the decline include shops now opening on Sundays and more live football on TV, meaning more people put off the chore at the weekend. The rise of hand car washes has also been blamed for a decrease in drivers washing their own cars. Cars are most likely to be washed by their owners every week in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since arriving at Liverpool in 2008. Skrtel believes Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world and has set an example during his time at Liverpool. Gerrard, who is set to leave Liverpool for LA Galaxy, will look to lead his hometown side to the FA Cup final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30. Skrtel admits that Liverpool will be a different side without Gerrard but believes the club has potential replacements.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, made a hole-in-one on the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, a remarkable achievement for the greatest golfer of all time. This was his first hole-in-one at Augusta, though he holds the record for the youngest to wear a green jacket and has won six Masters titles. The day saw five hole-in-ones, tying a record from 2002, with Camilo Villegas also achieving two aces. Despite the excitement, Villegas did not win, losing to Kevin Streelman in a playoff.

Several storms brought reports of tornadoes to Kansas and other states on Wednesday night, with tornado sirens blaring in Kansas. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which missed the city but posed potential risks to other communities. Other reports of tornadoes came in from southwestern Kansas, and the Storm Prediction Center reported three sightings near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The National Weather Service indicated a tornado may have touched down in the small town of Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. In addition to tornadoes, there were reports of wind damage, flooding, and hail the size of baseballs in various parts of the region. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Robert Bates, a reserve sheriff's deputy in Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Eric Harris. Bates claims he meant to subdue Harris with a taser but mistakenly shot him with a gun. The judge granted Bates permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, prompting a response from Harris's family, who expressed disappointment and perceived apathy. Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. His lawyer maintains that Bates had proper law enforcement training, while the family's lawyer alleges preferential treatment due to Bates's donations and friendship with the sheriff.

Conor McGregor, who is set to for the challenge feather Jose Aldweighto title on July 11, has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach. The Irishman, who grabbed Aldo's belt during their promotional tour in Dublin, claims he is more motivated to win the title than Aldo is to defend it. The pair have a fractious relationship, and McGregor has already raised the belt in front of 5,000 home supporters.

Tony Abbott has drawn criticism from anti-drinking campaigners for skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, with some claiming he is glorifying binge drinking and associating being a man with drinking alcohol. While drinking is a part of Australian tradition, critics argue that it is dangerous for the Prime Minister to glorify irresponsible drinking practices. However, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating that there was nothing wrong with his actions and that more people should emulate his fitness regimen.

Indiana is experiencing its largest-ever HIV outbreak, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County. The outbreak primarily involves the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana among intravenous drug users. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program on March 26, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected 1,400 used syringes. Despite the program's initial success, its future and the potential for similar programs in other counties remain uncertain due to concerns about promoting drug use and limited funding. The Senate is scheduled to hear a bill on Monday that would allow 23 Indiana counties with the highest rates of hepatitis C to establish needle-exchange programs, but the bill's fate is uncertain.

An Arsenal fan tested his girlfriend's knowledge of the football club by making her take a test, which she passed with an impressive 87% score. The test included questions about the team's history, players, and current season performance. Despite some incorrect answers, her creative responses and overall knowledge impressed her boyfriend, who rewarded her with a high grade and the assurance that their relationship would continue. The story sparked mixed reactions on social media, with some praising the boyfriend's creativity and others criticizing him for taking things too far.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years, providing information that led to the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. In exchange for his service, he was promised U.S. citizenship, but that has not happened. Now retired and in declining health, Toro faces deportation to Colombia, where he fears he would be killed. Despite his efforts to atone for his past, Toro remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or secure a green card or passport. His final temporary visa expired on January 1, and he is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is now in critical condition with 70% burns at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. The incident occurred on Sunday when she went outside her house in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, to relieve herself. Her family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack. On Tuesday, she set herself on fire using kerosene, to the shock of her brother, who doused her with water. The accused men have been arrested. The incident has sparked outrage and protests in India, where there is a heightened sensitivity to the issue of sexual assault.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has revealed he has been dreaming of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford. However, he will have to do so without Robin van Persie, who is not fit enough to play. Van Gaal also ruled out Luke Shaw, who is not yet at the standard of match fitness required by the manager. Despite the absence of key players, Van Gaal is confident that his team can secure a victory, which would be a significant step up the table and potentially lead to a third-place finish. He acknowledged that City will provide a stern challenge but emphasized the importance of controlling aggression and learning from past mistakes. Van Gaal also expressed his appreciation for the support of United fans, who he believes have been supporting the team in a marvellous way.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against rising ticket prices during their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. Supporters from both clubs left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of the game and displayed banners such as "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" to highlight their dissatisfaction with the increasing costs of following their teams. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. The fans expressed their frustration with the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal and the high ticket prices, which they believe are making it difficult for working-class fans to attend matches. They called for tangible reductions in ticket prices to reflect the earnings of ordinary people and warned that the footballing authorities risk losing a generation of fans if they do not address the issue.

A newborn baby named Star Reader, who was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, has been saved after undergoing a transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, noticed that their baby's skin had turned a yellowish tinge shortly after birth, prompting doctors to run tests on her liver. The tests revealed that Star's bile ducts were blocked, a condition that can prove fatal if untreated. After an unsuccessful attempt to unclog the bile ducts, a liver transplant was the family's only option. Both parents volunteered for the surgery but were told neither was a good enough candidate for a partial liver transplant. Shanell Reader, who is Star's maternal aunt, was tested and told that she would give the baby the best chance of survival. Shanell did not hesitate to step forward to save Star, and the transplant was successful. Star has since made a good recovery and is now able to live a normal life, thanks to her aunt Shanell.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. In the first round, they aimed to fire balls into the boot of a car from close range, with Hazard and Ake winning 5-3. The second challenge involved sinking balls into convertible Audis from long range, with Hazard and Ake winning 6-0. The final challenge required players to shoot at cars from long range, with Remy and Willian winning. Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror of one of the Audis during the final challenge.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide in the deaths of a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. He faced 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger, who had a history of health issues, claimed he was not suicidal on the day of the crash, contrary to prosecutors' earlier statements. His wife described him as a man of ethics and integrity who lived with grace and modesty. Dellinger faced a wrongful death lawsuit filed by the estate of Amanda Murphy, the pregnant woman killed in the crash. His defense argued that he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, the effects of a psychiatric drug overdose, and the advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis. The prosecution claimed he was driving around, depressed and loopy, and deliberately turned into the median. Dellinger's lawyer called the state's comments over the top and highlighted his productive and exemplary life. Dellinger took a severance package worth over $1 million in cash plus stocks when he left his job in 2011 due to health reasons. He owned four properties in Sunapee worth $3 million in total.

Lacey Spears, convicted of poisoning her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears with a lethal amount of salt, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed hope that she would be placed in general population and die in prison. The judge who sentenced Spears noted her mental illness but described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill to gain attention and requested the maximum sentence of 25 years to life. Spears' lawyer, Stephen Riebling, called her a hardworking single mother who gave her son unconditional love and said she was innocent. He plans to appeal the verdict.

The arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia has been delayed by a month due to the inclusion of protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter. The modified vaccine will provide protection against H3N2, B/Phuket, and H1N1, and will be available for free to high-risk groups, such as the very young, the very old, and most Indigenous Australians, from April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, who chairs the Influenza Specialist Group, encourages everyone to get vaccinated, as the vaccine will also protect those around high-risk individuals.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could affect the site's management. The tomb, which is a popular tourist destination, was described in the magazine as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." The state of Illinois is also facing a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the site. This has raised concerns among supporters of the tomb, who worry about how it will be run in the future. Despite these challenges, some visitors have praised the site's beauty and historical significance.

The article highlights nine fashion trends from the nineties and noughties that have made a comeback, along with commentary on their practicality and current popularity. The trends include JNCO jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, oversized denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers. The article notes that while some of these trends are being embraced by celebrities and fashion-forward individuals, others are seen as impractical or outdated.

This week's trending stories include:
- Four rainbows appeared in the early morning sky over the New York area after heavy rain.
- Hiring exotic dancers for wakes is a growing trend in rural China, but the practice has been targeted in the country's crackdown on vice.
- Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a Channel 4 interview when asked about his private life.
- The latest trend from the Kardashians is lip plumping, using a jar to suck on to look like Kylie Jenner.
- A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, went back in time with the help of some filmmakers.
- A prom-posal referencing bombs was not allowed, with the prom-poser accusing administrators of racism.
- Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in the upcoming "Beauty and the Beast" movie.
- Johnny Depp is nearly unrecognizable in the "Black Mass" trailer.
- A pregnant woman announced her pregnancy by referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
- A military dad photobombed his son in a creative way.

Serena Williams reached her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, receiving a giant cake to celebrate. The day before, Andy Murray celebrated his 500th win with a similar cake. Williams defeated Sabine Lisicki in three sets to progress to the semi-finals, where she will face Simona Halep. Despite losing her sister Venus to Carla Suarez Navarro, Williams remains focused on the tournament, which is the nearest thing to a hometown event for the world No. 1.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist and cafe owner, was shot dead by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on the topic of enforced disappearances in Baluchistan. Known for her advocacy of free speech and progressive values, Mahmud's killing has been met with grief and gratitude from those who admired her courage and dedication to promoting secular wisdom and social justice in Pakistan.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, fled to Kashmir as a refugee at the age of 14 and has been denied citizenship rights for over 70 years. He and around 100,000 other West Pakistan refugees (WPRs) live in abject poverty in the Jammu region of India's only Muslim-majority state. The WPRs, most of whom have never set foot in Pakistan, have been denied residential rights, including the right to buy land, vote in state polls, or work in the state government, due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance between the Muslim and Hindu populations. However, with the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) winning a share of power in Kashmir, there is hope that the WPRs' status will be normalized. The BJP has joined a governing coalition for the first time and is expected to champion the WPRs' cause.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a potential move to Chelsea, with the Premier League leaders having made an offer believed to be around £4 million. However, Muto is keen to join a club where he will play regularly and develop his potential, rather than being loaned out to Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem. Real Zaragoza boss Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut for FC Tokyo, believes the pacey forward could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge, praising his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence. Muto says he is still thinking about the move, wanting to join a club where he can play and develop.

Australia has dropped its policy of not selecting overseas-based players, recognizing the changing nature of the game and the need to field the best team possible. This decision contrasts with England's stance, which restricts the selection of overseas players, a policy that some argue is outdated and could hinder England's chances in the upcoming World Cup. Key players like Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, and Steffon Armitage have significantly improved since moving abroad, demonstrating that overseas experience can enhance a player's performance. The article advocates for England to adopt a similar approach, allowing coaches the freedom to select the best players regardless of their location, to ensure the strongest possible squad for the World Cup.

Open Garden's Greenstone is a small, egg-shaped device designed to enhance the strength of off-the-grid networks by acting as a beacon or booster for wireless mesh networks. It works in conjunction with Open Garden's Firechat app, which allows users to send messages and photos without the need for a web or mobile signal by creating a local network of devices. Greenstone extends the range of these networks, particularly useful in situations where traditional connectivity is unavailable or unreliable, such as on airplanes, in underground locations, or at large events. The device can hold up to 1,000 of the most recent messages and has a one-year battery life. Open Garden is currently working with manufacturers to bring Greenstone to market.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is on a mission to eradicate the negative connotations surrounding the word "fat" by embracing it as an honest and body-positive description of her physique. In her TED Talk, she revealed that she also calls herself "short" and "wife" because she is 5'3" and married, respectively. Lillian believes that "fat" should not be synonymous with "ugly" and encourages others to view it as a neutral descriptor. She shared her journey of overcoming insecurity about her body and finding empowerment through burlesque, which allows her to showcase a fuller figure in a positive and glamorous way. Lillian also highlighted the importance of exposing people to diverse body types to foster acceptance and tolerance. Despite receiving some negative comments, the response to her TED Talk has been overwhelmingly positive, with viewers sharing personal stories and expressing gratitude for her message.

Theo Walcott has been a regular on the substitutes' bench for Arsenal this season, having been named there for 17 of their 33 Barclays Premier League games. He was pictured in a Lanvin photoshoot with six of his Arsenal teammates, as well as runway model Olga Sherer. The Arsenal first team stars will be dressed in similar attire when they make their way to Wembley Stadium for their FA Cup final encounter against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott, who has spent much of the season on the bench, came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea on Sunday. He will be hoping to make his first Arsenal start since their 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14 when the Gunners face Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

Legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker's Cinovation Studio collection, featuring props and puppets from over 50 productions, will be auctioned on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on Propstore.com. The collection, valued at $746,100, includes items from films like Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. Notable items include the Grinch costume ($8,000), the Harry suit from Harry and the Hendersons ($6,000), and the frozen thug statue from Batman & Robin ($4,000). The auction offers fans a chance to own pieces of Hollywood history.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old boy from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, tragically died in the French Alps while on holiday with his family. Carwyn, described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster, became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland, where he fell over a 164ft drop. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. Carwyn's family has paid tribute to him, describing him as an adorable, caring person who gave so much love and made life full of laughter. They have said that seven years is too short a time to be an angel in the sky and that they are devastated by his loss. Carwyn was a very competent skier and snowboarder who had started skiing at the age of three. The family had been enjoying their last run of the day when Carwyn pressed on ahead, and his mother stopped to help her daughter. When she found he was not there, she returned to the mountain. Carwyn is believed to have been attracted by the ski station that he could see below and was heading for the resort. His body is ready to be repatriated, but his family remains in the Alps.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with her weight. She survived on just one piece of fruit a day and hid food to make it appear as though she was eating more. Her dramatic weight loss led to her collapsing and being rushed to intensive care. Laura spent a week on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital and was then offered support from eating disorder organizations. She has since spoken out about the pressures on young girls to be a size zero and is now in recovery. Laura has also made it to the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls, away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool unveiled their new home kit for the 2015/16 season, designed by new sponsors New Balance, in a ceremony at Anfield. The kit features an all-white design with the new balance logo, the liverbird, and the standard chartered logo. The players, including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, modeled the new kit and expressed their excitement for the upcoming season. Despite recent speculation about Sterling's future, the club is confident he will stay, and fans showed their support by chanting for him to remain at Liverpool. The kit also pays tribute to the Hillsborough disaster with a memorial flame and the number 96 on the shirt.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, a mysterious substance that makes up 85% of the universe's matter. The map, created using data from the Dark Energy Survey, covers 0.4% of the sky and shows clumps of dark matter across the universe. The goal of the survey is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, eventually creating a 3D map of dark matter. The map was released at the April meeting of the American Physical Society in Baltimore, Maryland.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make the 21-year-old winger one of his first signings this summer. Depay, who worked under van Gaal during Holland's successful 2014 World Cup campaign, is enjoying a prolific season with 20 goals in 26 league games and is the Eredivisie's leading scorer. PSV technical director Marcel Brands confirmed that United have made contact, along with Paris Saint-Germain and a third big European club, but noted that the transfer fee would be higher than Tottenham's £15 million offer last summer. Depay, who started his career at VV Moordrecht before joining PSV at 12, made his first-team debut in 2011 and has already made over 100 appearances for the Dutch giants. He scored the winning goal in Holland's 3-2 victory over Australia at the World Cup and was nominated for the tournament's "best young player" award.

Chelsea secured a commanding 3-1 lead in the first leg of the Youth Cup final against Manchester City's young side. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, with Dominic Solanke adding a late goal to seal the victory. The match showcased the talent of both teams, with standout performances from Chelsea's Abraham and Solanke, as well as Manchester City's captain Tosin Adarabioyo and star man Brandon Barker.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes that people are born with a sexual preference but opposes same-sex marriage as a constitutional right. He believes that states should regulate marriage and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio also said that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he did not agree with their decision. He noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio announced his candidacy for president last week and has already received monetary commitments exceeding the $51 million he will likely need to battle through a crowded Republican primary.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, embarked on an open-ended cycling odyssey around the world, quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue their dream of discovering different parts of the planet, one pedal at a time. In 356 days, they have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day. They keep costs down by relying on free accommodation and not needing a budget for transport, camping most nights and occasionally using hosting websites. Food is their only major expense, taking up 2.74 euros each per day. They started in London, heading southeast through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and into Turkey. They plan to continue into Asia, across the Pacific, and along the American continent.

A Texas couple is suing Premiere Photos for allegedly printing a racial slur on photo booth snapshots at their 2012 wedding. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, claims the owner, James Evans, refused to apologize and told them to "sue" him. The couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, says the bride's sister waited to tell them about the incident to avoid ruining their special day. The couple is seeking an apology and is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. The case is set for trial in July if mediation tomorrow does not resolve the issue.

England full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, pulling out of Harlequins' Aviva Premiership clash with Saracens at Wembley last weekend. Brown, who was knocked out cold in England's 47-17 victory over Italy in the RBS 6 Nations, is unsure when he will return to action, having also suffered a headache after the France game last month. He is determined not to suffer an extended break and will not rush himself back to action ahead of time. Meanwhile, Northampton wing George North has been advised by leading medics not to play again this season after suffering four quick-fire concussions, while Ireland's Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks earlier this term.

A leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter, has suggested that smartphone use may be responsible for a drop in the number of times couples are having sex each month. Research has revealed that the frequency with which Britons are having sex has been in decline since the emergence of the internet. It comes after Professor Spiegelhalter revealed in a new book how a typical heterosexual couple was now having sex three times a month. This was compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990, according to research published in Professor Spiegelhalter's book, Sex by Numbers.

Professor Spiegelhalter pointed to a number of possible factors for the decline in sexual activity, with one possible explanation being that more people are living on their own. However, he added that a more realistic explanation is that, as people have become better connected technologically, their lives have become busier with the boundaries eroded between home, work, and the outside world. This has squeezed out the time they would have spent with their other halves. The statistician quotes Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, as saying, "With an increasing number of competing demands on our time, sex just falls down our list of priorities."

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly prized in China and commanding prices up to £1.2 million, have seen a dramatic decline in popularity. This decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made it less acceptable to give such dogs as gifts, and recent bans in several cities on owning dogs over 50 kg. The breed's fall from grace has led to some mastiffs being sent to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used in cheap hotpots and their skin is used for leather belts. Additionally, unscrupulous breeders have been offloading poor-quality dogs, contributing to a glut of such animals. The breed's decline is also linked to urbanization, as more people realize that Tibetan mastiffs are not well-suited to city living.

A survey of 600 women in Paris found that every female user of mass transit has been a victim of some form of sexual harassment, ranging from insults to rape. Half of the women reported experiencing harassment before the age of 18. The poll led to calls for a campaign to stem sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains. The report highlighted the impact of harassment on women's freedom, as they often alter their daily lives to avoid confrontation. The president of the high council for gender equality emphasized the need for women to be able to move about and occupy public spaces without being placed in danger or threatened.

Direct Line's #everydayfix competition invited groups to design products addressing common problems. A survey of 2,000 people identified top emergencies, including not being able to sleep (46%), forgetting to lock the door (37%), and running out of phone battery while out (31%). Three prototypes were shortlisted: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences notifications; Forget Me Lock, a device that reassures you the door is locked; and Nipper, a mini phone charger using household batteries. The product with the most retweets by April 46 will proceed to a Kickstarter campaign and development.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she co-directs with Chief Constable Sue Sim. The funding decision, made after the Home Secretary allowed PCCs to commission services for crime victims, has been criticized as a conflict of interest. Critics, including Labour Chairman Keith Vaz, have described the situation as a "soap opera" and inappropriate. Baird defended the decision, stating that all procedures were followed, while Sim announced her retirement amidst previous allegations of workplace bullying. The MoJ will investigate whether any conflict of interest rules were broken.

A Philadelphia court sentenced three individuals, with two others awaiting sentencing, for their roles in a brutal assault on a man who was beaten, tied to a chair, and subjected to offensive tattoos. The incident, which lasted about 42 hours, occurred in the basement of a rowhouse in Mayfair, North Philadelphia, where the victim was held captive and tortured. The ringleader, Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, believed the victim, Greg Valecce, had hurt his cat and stolen money and drugs. Campbell, along with his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, and friend Carl Halin, 18, took turns punching, slapping, and spitting on Valecce before tying him to a chair. Campbell tattooed 'RIP Pebbles' on Valecce's right arm, along with a smiley face with breasts for eyes and a penis for a nose. Halin then took over the tattoo gun, inking swastikas, stars of David, two variations of the n-word, and a penis ejaculating on a rainbow with the words 'gay pride' beside it. Valecce suffered three busted ribs, two broken wrists, and fractured bones in his face. He escaped on April 1 while the others slept and contacted police. The court heard that Campbell, Ng, and Halin were 'wannabe gangsters' who filmed the abuse. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in state prison, Halin received the same sentence, and Ng was sentenced to 23 months in a state prison. Another man involved, David Thomas, 28, is awaiting sentencing, while another defendant, Jennifer Pratt, 40, is awaiting trial.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make the 21-year-old winger one of his first signings this summer. Depay, who worked under van Gaal during Holland's successful 2014 World Cup campaign, is enjoying a prolific season, having scored 20 goals in 26 league games so far this season. The Dutch league's leading scorer, Depay is a pacy, skillful player with an explosive right foot, capable of playing on the left wing and cutting inside. He has been tipped to become as good as Dutch star Arjen Robben, with one man believing he could one day rival Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay was nominated for the tournament's 'best young player' award but lost out to France midfielder Paul Pogba.

Chelsea secured a commanding 3-1 lead in the first leg of the Youth Cup final against Manchester City's young side. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, with Dominic Solanke adding a late goal to seal the victory. The match showcased the talent of both teams, with standout performances from Chelsea's Abraham and Solanke, as well as Manchester City's Pablo Maffeo and Kean Bryan.

He believes that states should regulate marriage and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio also said that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he did not agree with their decision. He noted that, as a Catholic, he believes divorce is wrong, but he would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio announced his candidacy for president last week and has already received monetary commitments exceeding the $47 million he will likely need to battle through a crowded Republican primary.

In their first year on the road, they have covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, relying on free accommodation and living on less than three euros each per day. Brown, who was knocked out cold in England's 47-17 victory over Italy in the RBS 6 Nations, is unsure when he will return to action and is determined not to suffer an extended break. He will not rush himself back to action ahead of time, acknowledging the long-term dangers of concussion. Brown is also encouraging his teammates to be honest about their symptoms and not to play on if they are showing signs of concussion.

Research has revealed that the frequency with which Britons are having sex has been in decline since the emergence of the internet. It comes after Professor Spiegelhalter revealed in a new book how a typical heterosexual couple was now having sex three times a month. This was compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990, according to research published in Professor Spiegelhalter's book, Sex by Numbers.

Professor Spiegelhalter pointed to a number of possible factors for the decline in sexual activity, with one possible explanation being that more people are living on their own. However, he added that a more realistic explanation is that, as people have become better connected technologically, their lives have become busier with the boundaries eroded between home, work, and the outside world. This has squeezed out the time they would have spent with their other halves. The statistician quotes Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, as saying, "With an increasing number of competing demands on our time, sex just falls down our list of priorities."

Tibetan mastiffs, once highly prized in China and commanding prices up to £1.2 million, are now facing a dramatic decline in popularity. The breed's fall from grace is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made it less acceptable to give such dogs as gifts. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have further impacted their popularity. The breed, traditionally used for herding in Tibet, can weigh up to 80 kg. The dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skin used for leather belts. Some are also stolen and sold to slaughterhouses. Unscrupulous breeders have contributed to the problem by cross-breeding the dogs to make more money, resulting in a glut of poor-quality dogs that cannot be sold. The breed's boom began in 2005, with one puppy selling for £1.2 million just 13 months ago.

Between 29 and 52 Muslims were killed and over 100 others wounded in the Hebron riots.

Qatar Airways, based in Doha, operates a hub-and-spoke network linking over 160 international destinations across multiple continents. The airline's hub is at Hamad International Airport, utilizing a fleet of more than 200 aircraft.

Qatar Airways, based in Doha, operates a hub-and-spoke network linking over 150 international destinations across multiple continents. The airline's hub is at Hamad International Airport, utilizing a fleet of over 200 aircraft.
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China and has been downloaded over 400 million times worldwide.
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China and has been downloaded over 500 million times worldwide.
Over 16,700 people have died and more than 102,000 have recovered from the illness worldwide.
Over 392,000 cases of the illness have been reported globally, resulting in over 17,100 deaths and over 102,000 recoveries.

Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was substituted on with only seven minutes remaining in their 0-0 draw with Burnley on Sunday. Merson initially angered Townsend by writing in his Sky Sports column that 'if Andros Townsend can get in (the England team) then it opens it up to anybody.' Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a stunning equalizer for England against Italy, and he duly accepted Merson's apology. However, Merson couldn't resist taking another dig at Townsend after Tottenham's draw at Turf Moor.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to the Japanese club's president Naoki Ogane. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge this summer. The offer is not connected to the £200 million sponsorship deal Chelsea signed with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber in February. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree two weeks ago, has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and has earned 11 caps for Japan, scoring once. A £4 million deal for the youngster has been mooted, but Muto has not yet decided whether he will join Chelsea despite being pleased with their bid.

A large-scale study conducted by Finnish researchers has found a link between antibiotic use in infants and childhood obesity. The study, which involved more than 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, found that children who had been given antibiotics in the first six months of life were more likely to be overweight or obese by the age of two. Boys were particularly prone to weight gain after being given antibiotics, and repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being a fat toddler. The researchers suggested that antibiotics may be contributing to the obesity epidemic by killing off gut bugs that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study did not prove that antibiotics were causing weight gain, but the researchers warned that the extended use of antibiotics could be an additional contributing factor to the development of excess weight problems.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, much to the shock and amusement of the hundreds of tourists present. The embarrassed soldier quickly scrambled to his feet and continued with his duties, but not before realizing how many people had seen his mishap. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist, who later shared the footage. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E networks are remaking the epic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and had a staggering audience of over 100 million viewers. The new version, set to air in 2016, will be a simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History (formerly the History Channel). LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new miniseries. The remake will draw more from Alex Haley's classic novel, "Roots: The Saga of an American Family," and will consult scholars in African and African-American history for added authenticity. The new version is described as "original" and "contemporary" and will tell the story of Kunta Kinte, an African who was captured, shipped to America, and sold into slavery to work on a Virginia plantation. The remake will encounter a new generation of viewers who have witnessed Barack Obama make history as the nation's first African-American president and "12 Years a Slave" win the Oscar for Best Picture, but also widespread racial unrest over police treatment of black suspects in many U.S. cities.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claimed that he was sexually assaulted on his first day working at Clarence House in 1978. He alleged that he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member, and that he was threatened to keep quiet. Lawler reported the incident to palace officials, but his complaint was ignored for months before the police were finally notified. The police are now investigating the claims, and the Royal Household has stated that they will cooperate fully with the investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which features the couple rapping in a car, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The Meeks shared the news with loved ones living far away and were surprised by the video's unexpected success. They plan to make another video after learning the gender of their child.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, featuring a black zigzag applique, was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett encounters Rhett Butler and is attacked in the shanty town. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over the years. It was part of a collection amassed by James Tumblin, who bought it for $20 in the 1960s. Other top-selling items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh, trousers and jacket from a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The boy's mother was holding him and another child when he slipped and fell between 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises and was in stable condition at the hospital. His leg was injured in the fall, but he was not attacked by the animals. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the boy's mother.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been turned to face a house after being out of service for two years due to outdated technology. The camera, one of around 300 decommissioned in 2013, is being investigated by Birmingham City Council, which plans to remove it.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, expressed his excitement to be part of the team and his readiness to run. He also praised the atmosphere of the event and emphasized the importance of representing Jamaica with pride. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending a Euro League match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. Neymar, who had just led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile, was joined by his sister Rafaella at the game. Despite the victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their division. The Barcelona players will return to La Liga action on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they continue their pursuit of a treble of trophies.

Italy is grappling with a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East seeking to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued, with the Italian coast guard receiving SOS calls from 20 boats in distress on Monday alone. On Tuesday, Save the Children reported that 400 migrants could be missing, citing survivor testimony of a ship carrying 550 people capsizing 80 miles off the Libyan coast. However, the Italian coast guard has not found evidence to confirm this incident. The recent increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy has led to a rise in rescues performed by the Italian Coast Guard. The IOM reports that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued at sea during the first weekend of April in the Channel of Sicily. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean this year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join the Gunners over Liverpool, despite the Reds' interest in the Chilean forward. Sanchez, who has scored 19 goals this season, was courted by several elite clubs last summer but ultimately decided to continue his career under Wenger's guidance. Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to a new environment proves he is one of the best around and has revitalized the team's strengths and dynamics. The Arsenal boss also played down speculation linking him with Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling, who has rejected a new contract offer.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the UCI Hour Record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, who will be 35 on April 28, will attempt to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. Wiggins, whose track pedigree includes three Olympic gold medals, is expected to set a mark that will last for some time. The current Hour record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins will hope for a capacity 6,000 crowd to spur on his attempt, with tickets going on sale from April 19. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams expressed that her struggle to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday was a real 'eye-opener' as the claycourt season gets into full swing. The US were beaten 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske being thrashed 6-0 6-3 in the doubles rubber by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams, who has won 19 singles grand slams, said the tough weather conditions made it difficult for both players, and she realized she was not as ready for the claycourt season as she thought she was. She said she has to be ready to hit a thousand shots if necessary. The US captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, said they have to work harder and need to just keep plugging away.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009. Falcao has struggled during his loan spell at Old Trafford, scoring only four Premier League goals, and it is uncertain whether United will exercise the option to keep him or whether he will return to Monaco. River Plate vice president Matias Patanian expressed the club's desire to bring Falcao back, stating that the doors are open. Falcao has been in good form for Colombia recently, scoring three goals in two games to equal the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the X Factor finalist and pop star, has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles, including a glossy, wavy style and a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership between Henderson and Batiste, the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand, was facilitated by the MILES agency. The international campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man. Henderson has expressed her excitement about working with Batiste, a brand she uses regularly. The campaign images showcase Henderson in glamorous outfits, including a black lacy dress with sheer panels.

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler, has sparked outrage among Siler's family and friends in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, expresses gratitude to the community for its support. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful and are calling for its removal. The shooting occurred after Siler, who was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant, armed himself with a weapon following a vehicle and foot pursuit. The investigation into Siler's death continues, while the investigation into Torres' shooting of Terry Knight, a suicidal man armed with two knives, was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan, with three militants also killed. The incident occurred in the southeastern town of Negur, with the militants reportedly crossing into Iran from Pakistan. The Sunni Muslim group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack, which targeted Shiites and aimed to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iranian authorities have asked Pakistani authorities to catch the surviving assailants, with the Pakistani government condemning the attack and pledging to apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan.

The classic video game "Space Invaders" was developed in Japan in the late 1970s, and now its real-life counterparts are the topic of an earnest political discussion in Japan's corridors of power. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani revealed that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. However, former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki claims to have seen a UFO with his own eyes, although he admitted that he didn't know personally if aliens existed. Inoki also asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. In 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba pondered the legal ramifications, under Japan's pacifist constitution, of a defense against an invasion from outer space.

A man in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China broke a toilet he was squatting on, resulting in deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. The man, Jin Pai, was worried about the cleanliness of the toilet seat and chose to stand on the rim, which caused the toilet to tip over and shatter, leading to his injuries. He initially told his friends he was squatting, but later changed his story to avoid paying compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and have reminded people to sit on the toilets instead of standing on them.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The investigation began when the girl found a hidden camera under the sink in a bathroom in her home. She told investigators that Rebbie had been watching her for years when she was undressing and when he believed she was asleep. She also said that Rebbie had been molesting her since she was nine years old until she was 13. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and had purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showered. He is being held on a $500,000 bail, and his preliminary hearing is on May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The daughters are shown in casual clothing, standing po-faced, while their fathers, dressed in sharp suits, perform energetic poses, often with expressions of pain. The images are part of Aoyama's latest book, roughly translated as Daughter and Salary Man, and are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks. The series allows fathers to express their fun side, embodying the role of a hero jumping through the sky with excitement and hope. The photos have garnered significant online interest for their curious and unique nature.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has raised the possibility of Kevin Pietersen's return to the England cricket team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up. The batsman was in a jovial mood as he posed for the Surrey team photo before the start of the County Championship season, but also took a moment to reflect ahead of the new campaign. Pietersen's last appearance for England was during the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia last year, where he suffered a whitewash series defeat. With England hoping to regain the urn this summer on home soil, Pietersen's return to the international set-up is a potential step closer.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, have dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, was initially fired on Wednesday after a poor run but was reinstated the next day. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday, he angered owner Angelo Massone again, leading to his dismissal. Ze Maria, who replaced Florin Marin in January, will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco team-mate, Nabil Dirar, believes that Falcao must be regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan last summer but has struggled to hit the heights he achieved before suffering a serious knee injury. United will have to pay £46 million to make Falcao's transfer permanent, but having only scored four goals all season, it is unlikely that they will take up that option. Dirar revealed that Falcao was not happy in France but thinks he would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, making off with the till and about $1500 in cash. The offender, described as being very tall, was captured on security footage wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and an oversized mask. Police were called to the Union St dairy at about 12.30pm after receiving reports of a masked man demanding cash from the owner's daughter. The robber threw the cash register to the ground and fled with the till drawer. Police are appealing to the public for information that may help to identify the person responsible and are asking anyone with information to call Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or to message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice in March 2022 for inappropriate relationships with underage students. The first arrest occurred on March 19, 2022, after she admitted to kissing a 15-year-old student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail but was arrested again on March 24, 2022, for having sex with another 15-year-old student on two consecutive nights in January. Both incidents allegedly took place in her car late at night. Granado was suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave by school officials. She posted a $50,000 bail and was released from jail. The school district has reassured families that they took immediate and appropriate action to address the situation.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws has gone viral, amassing over half a million views. The large crocodile calmly carried the lifeless dog, which belonged to the owner of a local bike shop, for hours before taking it to a nearby crocodile sanctuary. The incident occurred when the dog approached the water's edge, and the crocodile seized the opportunity to attack. Social media users have expressed horror at the video, with some calling it 'horrible' and others expressing hatred for crocodiles. However, crocodiles are a common sight in Puerto Vallarta, as the resort is built among mangroves that have been home to the creatures for centuries.

Hull City, under manager Steve Bruce, are battling to avoid relegation from the Premier League. Despite a strong start to the season, they have managed just six wins and are now relying on nine or eight points to secure survival. Key players have been sidelined with long-term injuries, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, Bruce remains confident that Hull can stay up, citing the team's positive attitude and the return of injured players.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he altered the answers on his students' SATs exams, invalidating the entire school's results. Guffick, who taught at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, allowed students to change their answers after the exam session had ended and also altered some answers himself. The school's results were annulled by the Department for Education after an investigation by the local education authority. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. He was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United's goalkeeper, is enjoying a happy personal life despite limited playing time. He married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year, and they have a son together. Lindegaard, who has struggled for minutes at United, posted a photo of himself and Beqiri on Instagram, calling her his "sunshine." Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, regularly posts modeling photos on Instagram, where she has over 17,000 followers. Despite his limited playing time, Lindegaard has been linked with a move to FC Midtjylland, but the two clubs could not agree on a price.

Reggie Jackson, a Hall of Famer for the New York Yankees, purchased the iconic 13-letter signage that once hung over Yankee Stadium in 2008. He hoped to sell the letters at a Sotheby's auction on Wednesday to a new generation of owners. However, the only bid was from a Sotheby's employee, who offered $260,000, well below the estimated value of $300,000 to $600,000.
