Janelle Monáe Robinson, born on December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song "Love or Lust," featured in the film Deep Cover, and for singing choruses on classic West Coast rap songs, including Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride."
The University of Mississippi has about 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent overall from Mississippi, with 23 percent being minorities. International students come from 90 nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet -- Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy is an actress known for her roles in various television series. She starred in the main role of Jenny Matrix in the web series Video Game High School from 2012 to 2014. In 2015, she co-starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime dark comedy-drama series Unreal. Currently, she is starring as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller Quantico.

Martin Van Buren was an American politician who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. A member of the Democratic Party, he also served as the eighth Vice President from 1833 to 1837 and the tenth Secretary of State from 1829 to 1831 under Andrew Jackson. Van Buren was a major supporter and organizer for Jackson in the 1828 election and ran for Governor of New York to boost Jackson's campaign. After serving as governor for two months, he resigned to become Jackson's Secretary of State. In 1831, following his resignation as Secretary of State, which aided Jackson in resolving the Petticoat affair, Jackson gave Van Buren a recess appointment as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey, is home to Rutgers University-Camden, founded as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States. It is the tenth most populous state and has the 11th most extensive total area, making it the largest state east of the Mississippi River. Michigan is the only state to consist of two peninsulas, which makes it a leading U.S. state for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by introducing inexpensive paperbacks sold through high street stores like Woolworths for sixpence, making high-quality paperback fiction and non-fiction accessible to the mass market.
Australia (2008 film) was produced in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who helped make country music a worldwide phenomenon. Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. Excuse My French is a 2014 Egyptian film comedy directed by Amr Salama, based on Salama's own experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after his return from Saudi Arabia. The film was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board, and Salama was forced to adjust the script while trying to preserve the film's core concept of religious discrimination.
Derek Hough starred in Make Your Move, a Romeo and Juliet-inspired South Korean-American independent dance film, in 2013.

Lady Gaga's "Bad Romance" is a song from her third extended play, The Fame Monster (2009). After an illegal demo leak, she premiered the final product at Alexander McQueen's show during Paris Fashion Week in October 2009, followed by the release of the single's cover art. The song achieved worldwide success, topping charts in various markets and selling 12 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling singles of all time. Additionally, there is a 2011 independent drama film titled "Bad Romance" (French title: Les Mauvais Romans).

DreamWorks Animation is a studio that has released 34 feature films, including popular franchises like Shrek, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls. They have also produced other successful films such as Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. Additionally, DreamWorks Animation created Trollhunters, an American computer-animated fantasy television series for Netflix in collaboration with Guillermo del Toro and Double Dare You.

Christopher Livingstone Eubanks, known as Chris Eubank, is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Christopher Livingstone Eubanks Jr., born in 1989, is also a professional boxer. He has held the IBO super-middleweight title since February 2017, the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015, and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, he is ranked as the world's fifth-best super middleweight by BoxRec, the seventh-best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and the eighth-best by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.
Sophia Anna Bush is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist. She is known for her film roles in John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the chairman and acting CEO of Fox News. He is an Australian, British, and American businessman, and the younger son of media mogul Rupert Murdoch. He is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc. Rupert Murdoch had full control as chairman and CEO of global media holding company News Corporation, which is now the world's second-largest media conglomerate. News Corp and 21st Century Fox were created after the conglomerate split on June 28, 2013.
Gal Gadot was ranked as the second highest earning actress/model in Israel in 2013, behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka. The majority of her income came from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, or CCR, was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are detected through a radiographic examination, commonly referred to as an "x-ray."
The South Wales Coalfield is a significant coal-rich region in south Wales, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental football club competition organized by CONCACAF for the top football clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was first organized in 1962 and was originally known as the CONCACAF Champions ' Cup.

Mary of Teck, after the death of her husband George in 1936, became the queen mother when her eldest son, Edward, ascended the throne. However, Edward abdicated later that year to marry Wallis Simpson, a twice-divorced American socialite. Mary then supported her second son, Albert, who became George VI, until his death in 1952. She died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
Poseidon grossed $181,674,817 worldwide on a $160 million budget.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton hold the record for the most wins, each with three.

Human trafficking involves the trade of humans, primarily for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates that forced labor alone generates $150 billion in profits annually as of 2014. Of this, 14.2 million (68%) were exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) were sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10%) were subjected to state-imposed forced labor.
Rio is a 2011 animated film that follows the adventures of a domesticated macaw named Blu. A sequel, Rio 2, was released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I (Franz Stefan, François Étienne), born on December 8, 1708, and died on August 18, 1765, was the Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany. His wife effectively executed the real powers of those positions.

Francis I (François Ier), born on September 12, 1494, and died on March 31, 1547, was the first King of France from the Angoulême branch of the House of Valois, reigning from 1515 until his death. He was also known as François au Grand Nez (``Francis of the Large Nose''), the Grand Colas, and the Roi-Chevalier (the ``Knight-King'') for his personal involvement in the wars against his great rival, the Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain, Charles V. When this was unsuccessful, he formed a Franco-Ottoman alliance with the Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent, a controversial move for a Christian king at the time. The Italian war of 1536-1538 was a conflict between King Francis I of France and Charles V, King of Spain and Holy Roman Emperor.

Peking University, abbreviated as PKU and known in Chinese as Běidà, is a leading Chinese research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League. Established in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, or Imperial Academy, and initially served as the highest education administration in China. It is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his appearance, including his friendly mutton chops, his distinctive gravelly voice, and his unique bass playing style.
Global warming poses significant threats to humans, including declining crop yields that jeopardize food security and rising sea levels that force people to abandon populated areas.
Australia is a 2008 romantic historical adventure drama film directed by Baz Luhrmann, starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.

Michael Dwayne Vick, born on June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the National Football League, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and traditional practices like food-making and craft-making. It includes oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films, which were both informative and entertaining. The unit also produced training films and trained combat cameramen.

James Jones is a writer and a basketball player. The writer won the 1952 National Book Award for his first novel, From Here to Eternity, which was adapted for the big screen and later made into a television series. The basketball player, on the other hand, averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He has won three NBA championships, two with the Heat and one with the Cavaliers. In 2017, he and teammate LeBron James reached the NBA Finals for the seventh consecutive year. He finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-08 season and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is the process of creating animated images. Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE, effective January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for his portrayal of the fourth Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, a longer tenure than any other actor. He has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site is a location in the United States that hosts a commercial nuclear power plant, the Columbia Generating Station, and various centers for scientific research and development, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who acts as a spokesperson for the U.S. government administration, particularly regarding the President, senior executives, and policies. The Press Secretary is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the President and does not require Senate confirmation. Despite not being a Cabinet position, the role is prominent due to the frequent briefings given to the media, which in turn inform the public.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State," is famous for its fertile soil, horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, historic sites, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken. The Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky houses major cities like Louisville and Lexington.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, who also appeared in The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and Broken Bridges.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born on March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, formerly known as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, both an electronic version produced by American trio Major Lazer and Colombian DJ MOSKA and an urban version produced by Sky were released.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event broadcast via closed-circuit and pay-per-view television from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). In 1987, the WWF scheduled a pay-per-view, Survivor Series, on Thanksgiving night and demanded exclusivity from cable providers on carriage of the event. From 1987, Starrcade was broadcast on pay-per-view, the first NWA event to do so. The 1985 event aired live on closed-circuit television. In 2014, the WWE Network included the previous Starrcades (1983-1986), which had been transmitted via closed-circuit television, alongside the rest of the Starrcades in the pay-per-view section and rated the show as TV-MA due to the amount of violence in the matches, particularly the "I Quit" match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum, T.A. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual Starrcade professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for CBS All Access and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise concluded in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, as well as in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. It is also the title of a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on Salama's experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.
A floppy disk is a type of disk storage composed of a thin, flexible magnetic storage medium encased in a rectangular plastic carrier lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century, followed by a bloody civil war from 1960 to 1996 between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, including genocidal massacres of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects. Outside of medicine, they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The Closer, a popular cable drama, began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011. The show concluded its sixth season as the highest-rated drama on cable.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the protagonist of the TV series Lost, played by Matthew Fox. Lost aired on ABC from 2004 to 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes. The first season averaged 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew McConaughey is an American actor known for his dramatic roles in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones.

Robert Palmer is a writer known for his books, music journalism, and contributions to blues recordings and film soundtracks. He gained recognition for his book Deep Blues and his work with the New York Times and Rolling Stone magazine. Additionally, he played the clarinet in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum, known as Lincoln Borglum, was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer. He is best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, passed away in 1941. The project, which began in 1927, was led by Gutzon Borglum until his death, at which point Lincoln took over as the project's leader.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha, as they return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on Dr. Abby Griffin, Marcus Kane, and Thelonious Jaha.
The Concert for Bangladesh, a pioneering humanitarian aid project, successfully generated awareness and funds, providing valuable lessons and inspiration for future initiatives like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is an influential Indian filmmaker credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and transforming the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine, articulated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois, was a response to the issue of slavery. The debates, known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven discussions between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton drew large crowds as the issue of slavery was of significant importance to citizens across the nation.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her career with the publication of Interview with the Vampire in 1976 and wrote sequels in the 1980s. Her works gained more critical and popular acclaim in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at the age of 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 United States Census. It is the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. At the beginning of the twentieth century, Camden's population was mostly made up of European immigrants. A city is a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis is the author of the screenplay for the 2013 film The Canyons, an original work that he also wrote. The Canyons is an American erotic thriller-drama film directed by Paul Schrader.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates were held in seven towns in Illinois.
Homer is the name attributed by the ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are central to ancient Greek literature.
Christopher Scott Kyle (1974–2013) was a U.S. Navy SEAL veteran and sniper. He was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-piece band that included Soundgarden's Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk, known for his work with Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave, started his career with Greta in 1990 and helped co-found Rage Against the Machine in 1991. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consists of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her critically acclaimed first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, a concept album sequel to her first EP, which was released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town in East Carroll Parish, Louisiana, and serves as the parish seat. It is located in northeastern Louisiana. The University of Mississippi has a diverse student body, with 55% of undergraduates and 60% overall coming from Mississippi. Additionally, 23% of students are minorities, and international students come from 90 different nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season, which is set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr was a prominent figure in early American politics, serving in various roles. He was elected twice to the New York State Assembly, appointed as New York State Attorney General, and chosen as a U.S. senator from New York. His most notable achievement was serving as vice president.

The Soyuz spacecraft, designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s, is a series of spacecraft used in the Soviet space program. It was initially built for the Soviet manned lunar programs and succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft. The Soyuz has been in service since its inception and has been used for both unmanned and manned missions, with the first manned launch occurring after 8 unmanned test flights.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine, a rap metal band, released their fourth studio album, Renegades, on December 5, 2000, under Epic Records. The same year, growing tensions over the band's direction led to de la Rocha's departure, resulting in the band's breakup. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the rest of the band formed the rock supergroup Audioslave with Chris Cornell, formerly of Soundgarden. Audioslave recorded three albums before disbanding in 2007. In 2007, Rage Against the Machine announced a reunion and performed together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a free-float market-weighted stock market index of 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Tata Motors is one of the companies listed on the BSE and is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is a Southeast Asian country bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. With an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, it is the world's 14th-most-populous country and the ninth-most-populous Asian country. Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been among the highest in the world, and in 2011, it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who, through his dramatic acts of violence against the British and execution at age 23, became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Aamir Khan's "Dangal," a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I was King of Scotland as James VI from 1567 and King of England and Ireland as James I from 1603 until his death in 1625. He was a major advocate of a single parliament for England and Scotland.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand stage and screen actress known for her roles in various television series and films. She was a core cast member of the soap opera Shortland Street and has appeared in Xena: Warrior Princess, The Cult, and Legend of the Seeker. Her film credits include Separation City, and she has also starred in the Australian series Rake. Cormack portrayed Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor and is best known for her role as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, which she starred in for four years before leaving in 2016.
Rob Sheridan is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, best known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor known for his roles in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, released in 2015, is a comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and co-written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Artpop is Lady Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the United States, debuting at number one on the Billboard 200 with first-week sales of 258,000 copies and selling 757,000 copies. The album received mixed reviews but was commercially successful, selling 2.3 million copies worldwide and becoming the ninth best-selling album of 2013.
John Frusciante was the guitarist for the Red Hot Chili Peppers, and Stadium Arcadium, released in 2006, was his fifth and final album with the band. He left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, a controversial yet influential figure in British history, implemented policies known as Thatcherism during her time as Prime Minister. She is regarded as one of the most significant politicians in British history, with ongoing debates about her policies.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. In addition to his musical career, McKagan has established himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns on various topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor known for his acting roles and for narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, the capital of the Valencian Community, is Spain's third-largest city and metropolitan area, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative center and a metropolitan population of 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers, portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series, is the central character in the Buffy the Vampire Slayer franchise.
The series "Make It or Break It" ended on May 14, 2012, after three seasons. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that develops methodologies and technologies for recognizing and translating spoken language into text by computers. It incorporates knowledge and research from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of SR include voice user interfaces, call routing, domotic appliance control, search, simple data entry, preparation of structured documents, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft. The field has seen significant advancements evidenced by the surge of academic papers and the widespread industry adoption of deep learning methods in designing and deploying speech recognition systems. Major players in the industry include Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, many of which have publicized the core technology in their speech recognition systems as being based on deep learning.

Richard Alf was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman beginning in 1970. The convention was founded as the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970 by a group of San Diegans that included Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry; later, it was called the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy, who is third in the world, is one shot behind after carding a third straight five under-par 67. McIlroy's round included an eagle on the 12th, and he is aiming for his first title since May. McIlroy had a rough start to the day, dropping shots on the third and 10th holes, but he bounced back with a birdie on the 11th and an eagle on the 13th. He is targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leads England's Danny Willett by 271, 214 points with three events remaining.

Sheikh Ali Salman emphasized the need for meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, highlighting the importance of concrete solutions and the involvement of reformist figures like Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa. He expressed hope in the new US Secretary of State, John Kerry, for more active support in promoting human rights and democratic practices. Salman also criticized the UK's approach, urging public pressure on Bahrain's government to address violence and human rights abuses. He reiterated al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations and called for the release of opposition leaders and human rights activists, emphasizing their crucial role in the success of any dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music movement exponent, died at his home in Cambridge following an illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it across six continents for some 30 years. The AAM made over 200 CDs, including the first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood's most famous recording is the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, named by BBC Music Magazine as one of the top 20 recordings of all time. He studied keyboard at Cambridge University and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. Hogwood held various positions, including artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University in the US. He was described as a great ambassador for historically informed music and a genial person.

The report Homicide in Scotland revealed that 57 victims of homicide were recorded in the year to the end of March, the lowest number of recorded homicide cases for a single 12-month period since 1976 and half the figure of nine years ago. As of 31 March 2016, only one case of homicide recorded in 2015-16 was unresolved. The majority of the accused had an unknown status for alcohol and drugs, but 31% (20 people) were identified by the police as being under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs. A sharp instrument remained the most common method of killing in Scotland and accounted for 51% of homicides (29 cases) in 2015-16, with nearly all of these cases (26 out of 29) involving a knife. The Justice Secretary Michael Matheson said that while it is encouraging to see continued falls in homicide cases alongside the long-term decline in violent crime, the sustained efforts that have helped achieve this - through education and enforcement - must continue, because each of the lives lost is one life too many.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but Sunderland responded with goals from Victor Anichebe and Jermain Defoe. Despite being down to 10 men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, Bournemouth was unable to find an equalizer. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration with the team's inability to convert chances, noting that they had enough opportunities to win three games.

Australia's policy on asylum seekers who arrive by boat involves detaining them and sending them to offshore processing camps, a policy described as "brutal" and "inhumane" by the New York Times. Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended the policy, stating that it was necessary to prevent deaths at sea. Abbott also compared the Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, a comparison that was criticized by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry. Abbott later clarified that he was not in the "business of ranking evil."

The United States has suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia regarding the cessation of hostilities in Syria, citing Russia and the Syrian government's intensified attacks on civilians. The US had warned it would halt the talks unless Moscow stopped bombing Aleppo, where hundreds of people, including children, have died since government forces launched an offensive to take full control of the city after the week-long truce lapsed. The main trauma hospital in the rebel-held eastern part of the city was hit in an air strike for the third time in a week, according to activists. The US also accused Russia and Syria of targeting critical infrastructure such as hospitals and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching civilians in need. In response, Russia regretted the US move, accusing it of shifting the blame for the collapse of last month's truce and failing to divide jihadist groups in Syria from the moderate opposition. The two sides will continue to talk about counter-terrorism operations in Syria to avoid unnecessary clashes.

Downing Street supported a Policy Exchange report advocating for the sale of high-value social homes upon vacancy to fund the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 social homes annually. Labour opposed the proposal, citing concerns about displacing low-income families and breaking up mixed communities. The report estimated that selling 28,500 properties annually could generate £5.5 billion, with £4.5 billion remaining after debt repayment. Policy Exchange's director, Neil O'Brien, argued that the move would create the largest social housing program since the 1970s and reduce the social housing waiting list by 500,000. Critics, including the National Housing Federation, warned of the potential for segregated communities and the displacement of low-income families.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died last week at his home in Swansea, a city at the center of an epidemic of the disease which has reached 942 cases. An inquest will be opened and adjourned on Tuesday to allow further tests to determine the cause of death, as the examination was unable to establish whether measles was the main cause. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have needed hospital treatment for the illness. Mr. Colfer-Williams' mother, Angela Colfer, said her son had recently been treated at Swansea's Morriston Hospital for asthma. A few days after he was discharged, he became unwell and developed a rash. Mrs. Colfer said her son went to see an out-of-hours GP on 17 April with a rash "from head to foot" but not on his arms. The following morning, Mr. Colfer-Williams was found dead at his flat. Public Health Wales said on Friday that laboratory tests confirmed a diagnosis of measles but further tests were needed to determine the cause of death. The family said they had no idea how Mr. Colfer-Williams got measles, as no close family member has it, including his three-year-old daughter who has been vaccinated.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical sexual offence against a boy under the age of 16, reported to have occurred in 2001. He is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley played to a 1-1 draw in a National League match. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when James Hurst squared to Jake Lawlor, who scored into an empty net. Gateshead's Liam Hogan blocked Jordan Preston's effort, and Guiseley's Jonny Maxted saved a shot from Wesley York just before halftime. In the second half, Gateshead leveled the score when Derek Asamoah slipped, allowing York to curl the ball into the top-right corner. Substitute Michael Rankine replaced Jordan Preston for Guiseley, while Luke Hannant came on for Gus Mafuta for Gateshead. Adam Boyes replaced Jake Cassidy for Guiseley, and Derek Asamoah came on for Kevan Hurst.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of Bristol City Football Club, plans to replace two stands at its current stadium to increase capacity. This proposal is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed due to an application for a town green. The club's majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, confirmed that work would begin after the judicial review period, provided there are no legal challenges by March. The redevelopment plans were approved by Bristol City Council in November, and the club will sign the section 106 agreement soon.

Cuadrilla, the firm conducting shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire, has suspended operations following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) reported that the April tremor occurred 1.2 miles from the drilling site and shared a similar location and mechanism with the previous tremor. Both events were small, and the BGS is monitoring the situation as a precaution. Cuadrilla will examine the data collected by the BGS before deciding whether to resume operations.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015. He was cleared of two other counts by a jury at Liverpool Crown Court. Carpenter, who usually wears a kilt and piper's regalia when he performs, was accused of giving the impression he was collecting cash for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign. In his defense, he said he had piped for the charity in the past but was simply busking on this occasion. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, Kenneth Derbyshire, said he had given Carpenter permission to design and display a banner featuring the eternal flame and the word justice but had made it clear he was not to use it to collect funds for the charity. Carpenter told the court the banner was a tribute to the victims, not an attempt to deceive anyone. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town secured a comfortable 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers in the Championship, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. QPR's keeper, Alex Smithies, made a costly error for the second goal, but Ipswich could have scored more, with several chances missed. The win lifted Ipswich up four places to 14th, while QPR slipped to 15th. QPR boss Ian Holloway expressed disappointment with his team's performance, particularly the second goal, and called for his players to be mentally tougher.

Wells, a 23-year-old player, performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds secured a second consecutive win by defeating Chinnor 29-12, with standout performances from Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams. The front row and front five made over 70 tackles, contributing significantly to the victory. The Reds face seven teams below them in the next eight games, including league leaders Old Elthamians. While the performance against Chinnor was not perfect, it was emotionally strong, and the team aims to build on this success.

The police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata after fleeing to Bangladesh. The incident caused outrage in India and led to street protests in many cities across the country. This marks the sixth arrest in the crime, with two suspects still at large. All five previously arrested suspects have named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on a tip-off that Nazu was returning to Kolkata by train. During the attack, money was stolen from the convent school, the building was ransacked, and the nun was raped.

The passage discusses an interactive video by Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging, and Advertising in London. The video explores why consumers change what they buy, highlighting the impact of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports on UK consumer preferences. It also examines the changing ownership and ranking of top UK brands. The video is best viewed in full screen and links to additional non-interactive information are provided.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills and a woman in Stranraer were scammed by callers claiming to be from BT technical support. The Sandyhills incident occurred on 15 September, and the Stranraer con took place seven days later. The Stranraer victim lost money after the caller gained remote access to her computer. PC Siobhan Pellett warned people to be cautious when answering cold calls that attempt to gain remote access to their computers and to never give out banking details or account numbers over the phone.

Duffy, a former player and Scotland assistant coach, has joined Featherstone Rovers as head coach on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Mark Campbell, Featherstone's chairman, praised Duffy's coaching abilities and credited him for his efforts at Swinton. Duffy has been replaced by his former assistant, Stuart Littler, at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic, and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The crew treated a female rider with head injuries and hypothermia before she was flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system to improve the current system, which relies on ground-based radars and leaves around 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The decision was prompted by the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014, which highlighted the weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The new system will enable satellites to receive transmissions from aircraft, allowing for real-time tracking of planes anywhere in the world. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed the boy's identity after a tip on October 30. His mother has been notified of his recovery.

Firefighters were at the site in Duncan Street for several days following a fire on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire, and the firm has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills related to the situation in Ukraine, particularly in the Crimea region. The first bill allows for the annexation of territories whose people express a clear desire to join Russia, even if the neighboring state is disintegrating. The second bill simplifies the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, allowing them to apply at Russian diplomatic missions before August 1 and become citizens after two months, instead of the usual year. The bills are seen as a response to the crisis in Ukraine, where pro-Russian feelings are strong, and many Russian citizens already reside.

McLaren, a Formula 1 team with a rich history of success, is currently facing a significant slump. The team, which has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is struggling with a poor car performance and engine issues. The decline began in 2013, and despite having two world champions in their cars, the team has not been able to replicate their past successes. The current focus is on improving the Honda power-unit, with hopes that the team can return to their winning ways. The team's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, and they are optimistic about making a comeback.

Thomas Baker, 44, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January and later died in hospital. Three men from Liverpool, aged 29 and 32, were arrested and remain in police custody. Merseyside Police said Baker had left Phoenix Gym shortly before the shooting and was getting into his car when he was attacked. Detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. A silver VW Polo was seen leaving the scene at speed and is being sought by police. Additionally, several people captured on CCTV near the meat market have yet to come forward, and their information could be crucial to the investigation.

The passage discusses various online and digital initiatives aimed at celebrating Christmas in a spiritual yet modern way. It highlights the virtual church service by Everyday Church Online, which streams recorded sermons and has a global congregation. The Star Wars-themed sermons are a unique feature, with the message of hope resonating with the Christmas spirit.

The article also mentions the fantasy game Guardians of Ancora, developed by the Scripture Union, aimed at children to rediscover Bible stories and light up the fictional world of Ancora. It notes the success of Viral.de's digital nativity video and the Churches Advertising Network's modern-day nativity ad, which faced challenges in gaining widespread screening due to its religious content.

Next Manga's app and e-book versions of the nativity story in Manga form are highlighted, with a significant distribution to Syrian and Libyan refugees. The article also mentions the use of social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram by churches to connect with their communities and share spiritual thoughts during the festive season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land for a circuit development. Backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, have offered around 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting accounts from experts over claims the circuit would damage habitats and plant life by building on the common land. Natural Resources Wales said it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value, but it was not opposing the development overall. However, an ecology report presented by the developers said there would be a "net gain" in biodiversity because the plans included work to enhance other habitats nearby, which the Gwent wildlife trust argued against. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, before Welsh government ministers have the final say on whether the plans can go ahead.

Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April and said that a report by Novaya Gazeta had insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, warning of retribution. The report, published on 1 April, stated that more than 100 people had been detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, describing torture and beatings at a prison near Argun. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya. The Chechen spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, confirmed the resolution's adoption and warned of retribution. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor, Dmitry Muratov, defended the report and urged dialogue. The LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution and plans to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute anyone.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, have been criticized for their involvement in housing homeless men in London. The arrangement involves finding properties for single homeless men over 35, with Investing Solutions claiming housing benefit for each tenant. The company passes most of the rent to private landlords, while Fresh Start refers clients to both Investing Solutions and other private landlords. The relationship has been criticized as "a new low" by a homeless group, with concerns raised about the suitability of the housing provided. Investing Solutions has defended its practices, stating that the majority of the rent is passed on to private landlords and that it is concerned about the allegations of poor housing conditions. The Department for Communities and Local Government has emphasized the responsibility of local authorities to safeguard taxpayers' money and ensure the private rented sector is safe and secure.

GB's men's basketball team, led by coach Joe Prunty, lost a close warm-up game against the Netherlands despite leading for most of the first three quarters. Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points, and Ben Gordon, who missed out on the London 2012 Olympics, added 13 points, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. The Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, made a strong comeback in the fourth quarter, scoring the first 10 points to take the lead and hold on for the win. Prunty emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity and focus throughout the game, acknowledging that his team lost some of their fire in the final warm-up match before the Eurobasket qualifying campaign begins.

Conor McGregor submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) on Wednesday, hours before the deadline, to use 8oz gloves in his upcoming boxing match against Floyd Mayweather. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, expected the request and will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision. Mayweather had previously stated he would wear 8oz gloves, but had not submitted the necessary waiver at that stage. The NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, has never seen a move to 8oz gloves at 154lbs before, as rules state that 10oz gloves are used from 135lbs upwards. However, bouts between 135lbs and 147lbs can use 8oz gloves if waivers are signed and the NAC feels the move is justified. McGregor, who has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career, welcomed Mayweather's Instagram post last week, stating, "I am coming sprinting at you with bricks. Know that. Brittle hands." The NAC will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision.

The passage provides a nostalgic look at the history of Fleet Street, once the epicenter of British journalism. It highlights the street's evolution from a hub of print journalism to its current status as a symbol of a bygone era. Key points include the transition from manual typewriters and hot metal printing to computerized systems, the move of major newspapers to Wapping in the 1980s, and the subsequent repurposing of Fleet Street's historic buildings. The personal anecdotes from veteran journalists Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, as well as Liz Hodgkinson, add a human touch, illustrating the vibrant, alcohol-fueled culture of Fleet Street in its prime. The passage concludes with a reflection on the enduring legacy of Fleet Street and the bittersweet feelings of those who were part of its final chapter.

J.K. Rowling faced criticism on Twitter for donating £1 million to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum. She revealed that she had been called a traitor for her political views and had blocked some abusive Twitter users who she believed were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Rowling also shared that she had responded to other SNP supporters and discussed how much she had in common politically with many of them. She joked that she would bring marshmallows after a Twitter user suggested her books should be burned in public. The SNP won 56 of the 59 seats in Scotland in Thursday's election and is now the third-largest party in the UK.

The study by the University of Edinburgh's School of Law, published in Scottish Justice Matters, found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime as better-off children. Poverty increases the risk of violence among both boys and girls, and a history of police trouble is the strongest predictor of being not in education, employment, or training by age 18. Poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their wealthier counterparts. Household poverty increases the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors are considered. The study also found that people in extreme poverty are more likely to be victims and perpetrators of crime, with boys three times more likely than girls to engage in violence. Girls from poorer backgrounds are twice as likely to be involved in violent crime. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and was funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Nuffield Foundation, and the Scottish government. The recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefited areas with the most chronic crime rates, with victims of the most crime found in the most deprived communities. Half of the communities with the highest crime rates are in the top 20% of areas with the highest levels of chronic health problems, and a third are in the top 20% of areas with the highest levels of unemployment. The Scottish government has a long-standing record of protecting the poorest and most vulnerable in society and is tackling poverty and inequalities head-on through various initiatives, including a £296m investment to limit the damaging effects of UK government welfare cuts.

Mr. Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee in the early hours of Sunday. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody to appear in court next week. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged that Mr. Walsh was one of three people who entered the Marian Estate in Kilkee shortly after 01:00 on Sunday and called to houses in the estate looking for Mr. Haugh. It is further alleged that while in the estate, the accused and the two males came across Mr. Haugh and another man, and a fight ensued where weapons were used. During the course of the altercation, Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Garda arrived at the scene where knives and golf clubs were recovered. Mr. Haugh was brought by ambulance to Limerick University Hospital where he was pronounced dead at 06:00 local time. A knife handle and a blade were recovered at the scene of Mr. Haugh's death, with the blade having blood on it. A judge said the state had given evidence of tension in the area of Kilkee as a result of the killing and remanded Mr. Walsh in custody until 14 August.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted that Tom Elliott, who served in the UDR for 10 years, should reveal how many people he harassed and shot. The tweet was deleted within an hour, and Flanagan apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue and without foundation. The High Court heard that the insurance firm indemnifying MLAs at Stormont refused to cover Flanagan in respect of any compensation and costs in the case. Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, stated he was disappointed it took so long to get to this stage but was delighted with the result.

Hawick Knitwear, a Scottish knitwear company established in 1874, has increased its production of sweaters to 9,500 per week, up from 7,500 last year, to meet growing demand. The company, which employs over 230 staff, has seen a surge in orders for both its private label clients and its own brand, which launched in January. The firm sells its products in Europe, the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The increase in production is a testament to the company's dedicated staff and its successful expansion into new markets.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady with 20 years of experience, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun and accepted he had struck Mrs Blackburn but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr Wright's eyes. Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. The trial continues.

The passage describes a NATO exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities in response to increased Russian submarine activity. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, as well as anti-submarine warfare helicopters and underwater drones. The focus is on locating a German U-boat, U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf, which is tasked with avoiding detection and targeting a command ship and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights the challenges of anti-submarine warfare, particularly for NATO members like the UK, which lacks maritime patrol aircraft and relies on allies for aerial surveillance. The passage also underscores the growing concern over Russia's military strength, particularly its advanced submarine fleet and significant investment in defense, in contrast to European nations that have been cutting their defense budgets.

South Sudan, the world's youngest country, is on the brink of genocide and ethnic cleansing, with violence spreading from Juba to previously peaceful southern Equatoria states. Over 340,000 people have fled to Uganda, the largest refugee influx this year, surpassing Syria's 200,000. Daily, an average of 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees, with reports of killings, rapes, and ethnic targeting. Nelson Ladu Thomas, a refugee, described the violence in his hometown of Yei, where Dinka tribesmen killed his brother and targeted Equatorians and Nuer. Despite the challenges, Uganda, with aid agency support, is providing refugees with land and resources to start anew. However, the influx is straining resources, particularly water supply. The international community is urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to end the violence.

McKenzie, a former professional footballer, became a boxer in 2013 and has a record of eight wins and one draw from his nine fights. He will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital is set to receive £33 million in funding as part of the coalition's £330 million investment in new NHS facilities across England. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is cramped and outdated, and the new facility is expected to be completed by autumn 2014. The remaining balance will be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, Sheffield, close to the city center. Witnesses reported that the victim was either in or near a black Mercedes car he had been driving when the incident occurred. The man was taken to the Northern General Hospital but succumbed to his injuries. The shooting took place in a residential area where a family celebration was happening, and many relatives came out to help the victim after hearing the shot. The incident occurred in an area that has not been previously affected by the recent spate of shootings in Sheffield, which have mostly occurred in the north of the city.

The passage describes the activities of three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukrainian conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their extensive use of DDoS attacks and hacking into Russian servers and email accounts. They also monitor public CCTV systems in rebel-held areas and have hijacked network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, on the other hand, is a staunchly anti-Western group that hacks Ukrainian government websites and spreads propaganda. They claim to have retrieved confidential documents from a member of Joe Biden's team and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems in Ukraine. Anonymous International, known for leaking Kremlin documents, also covers Ukraine and has published letters and emails that provide insights into the conflict. The passage highlights the diverse tactics and objectives of these hacker groups, from spreading propaganda to gathering intelligence and disrupting operations.

The passage describes the emotional farewells of three MSPs—Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie—as they prepare to leave the Scottish Parliament. Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, used his final speech to highlight the need for accountability and scrutiny in the parliament, drawing lessons from Westminster. Alex Salmond, the former First Minister, delivered a valedictory address emphasizing Scotland's diversity and the need for greater responsibility in governing Scotland. He also joked about the competition from the UK budget announcement and wished good luck to those standing in the forthcoming election. Annabel Goldie, a Scottish Conservative MSP, joked about her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney and expressed her fondness for the political process. Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was visibly moved by the speeches, particularly those of Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is seeking experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people and those who care for them, highlighting the positive impact of high-quality care and expressing concern about unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While the review is supported by Care Forum Wales, its chair, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that the advisory panel does not include a provider expert.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to the end of June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates a network of 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, attributed the profit growth to international sales growth in Europe and new markets. The company also noted the challenging agricultural industry and the uncertain impact of Brexit, but expressed confidence in its position to navigate future challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. The investigation is still in its early stages, but the death is being treated as murder. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft (1.8m) tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build. He is believed to have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, highlighted the risks to the global economy in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington on Tuesday. He noted that the IMF's latest assessment of the global economy indicates a weakening baseline and a delicate juncture. This follows weaker-than-expected trade figures from China, where exports plunged by a quarter from a year ago. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it releases its next economic predictions in April. This dismal picture has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that have bet on China's growth story.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing at Cowes would be free until July 2 to acknowledge the issues and gather feedback. A review of the project has been ordered by auditors due to the problematic start of the ferry service, which has included breakdowns, groundings, training issues, and vehicle damage. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on local businesses, asking if they would receive compensation similar to that provided for damaged vehicles. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the challenges but emphasized that the ferry is a prototype and that teething problems are expected. He noted that electrical issues have been resolved, ramp extensions have been authorized to prevent vehicle scraping, and seamanship issues have been addressed.

A 32-year-old man was killed in a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at about 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening while officers investigated the scene.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, has faced criticism for its discriminatory hiring practices. The agency advertises for roles based on physical appearance, such as a personal assistant with "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver" to drive a Porsche Cayenne. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has called these practices "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women" and plans to write to Matching Models to clarify their hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners have also criticized the agency, with Sam Smethers of the Fawcett Society stating that the ads are "straight out of the 1970s" and a "timely reminder" of the ongoing battle for gender equality.

The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practices, stating that "looks are important" to their clients and that they understand the importance of having the right people representing a company. However, employment lawyer James Lynas has stated that the use of phrases such as "beautiful and attractive" could be interpreted as code for "young" and discriminatory against older women. He also pointed out that a male driver who genuinely wanted the job could sue for sex discrimination if rejected, with compensation being unlimited.

Matching Models' clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods. Jansen also mentioned that MTV wanted models with tattoos and piercings, highlighting the agency's willingness to cater to specific client requests.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to a private school in Bangalore city, India, where an office assistant named Mahesh allegedly shot and killed an 18-year-old student named Gautami and severely injured another student named Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and is currently remanded until April 12. The motive for the shooting is unclear, and incidents of gun crime at schools and colleges in India are rare. India has strict gun control laws, although a large number of feuds are settled with firearms.

Glaad's Where We Are on TV study found that there were 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters on shows aired between June 2016 and May 2017. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off or met violent ends, including Poussey Washington in Orange is the New Black and Bea Smith in Wentworth. The study also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis said it was "heartening to see progress being made" but emphasized that numbers were "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced his decision to step down ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The BBC reported that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished. Mackintosh, who was the leader of the borough council at the time, was criticized over the loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land. About £10.25m of that money is now missing and the loan is subject to a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities". The football stand remains half built. When contacted by the BBC last week, a majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him. Mackintosh had previously said he intended to stand for re-election but in a statement, he said, "It has been a huge honour to be the member of Parliament since 2015, but I now feel it is the right time for my constituents to have a new representative."

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was charged with murder and aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official after fatally shooting 15-year-old Jordan Edwards and injuring four other teenagers with his rifle. The incident occurred in Balch Springs, Texas, when police responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Oliver was fired from the police force for policy violations. The case is being prosecuted by the Dallas County District Attorney's office, and no trial date has been set. If convicted, Oliver could face up to 99 years in prison, which would make him the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. The Edwards family's lawyer expressed caution about the outcome, citing the rarity of police officer convictions in Texas.

The passage discusses the decision of Melania Trump, the incoming First Lady, to delay moving to the White House until her son, Barron, finishes the school year. This move is unusual, as most First Ladies have moved into the White House immediately after their husbands' inaugurations. The article also explores the historical context of First Ladies and their roles, highlighting that only two other First Ladies in U.S. history have not lived in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. It also mentions the responsibilities and public roles of First Ladies, including their support for various initiatives and causes. The article concludes by noting that the White House can be a "normal" family environment, as seen with previous First Families.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October, and the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been asked to investigate the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is fully cooperating with the investigation and awaits its findings. A report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) in due course.

A yellow warning of wind has been issued, with gusts of up to 75mph expected locally, particularly to the west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction could add to the impact of the winds, with disruption to travel on roads and at sea likely. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree was brought down by gusts overnight in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing one of the main routes into the town. The council said Telford Road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday to allow clean-up work to be carried out.

The Giants secured a short-handed opener through player-coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal to make it 2-1, with Andy Bohmback equalizing. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle, and James Desmarais made it 4-2 before Nottingham's David Ling got one back. The teams will meet again on Saturday night in the second match of their double-header. Nottingham leads the league on 28 points, with Sheffield Steelers on 27 and Belfast on 25.

The Chinese Grand Prix saw a dramatic start with multiple collisions on the first lap, leading to the introduction of the safety car. World champion Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one and had to make five pit stops. Despite colliding with his team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, Sebastian Vettel finished second. Raikkonen fought back to fifth place, passing Hamilton in the closing stages. Hamilton expressed confidence in eroding Rosberg's points lead but faces an uphill battle to stop Rosberg from winning his first world title this year.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, becoming the most prominent footballer to do so. His announcement was met with widespread support from fellow players, football administrators, and politicians, who praised his courage and called it an important step in the fight against homophobia in football. Hitzlsperger's decision is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football remains a significant issue. The German Football Association is now urged to encourage active players to follow Hitzlsperger's example and break down the taboo surrounding homosexuality in football.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played a key role in Brighton's promotion to the Premier League, making 32 Championship appearances this season. With his contract expiring at the end of the campaign, he is hoping to sign a new deal to continue contributing to the team's success in the top flight. Sidwell has previously played in the Premier League with several clubs and believes he deserves another opportunity to play at the highest level. He has expressed confidence in Brighton's ability to stay in the Premier League and is eager to secure a new contract to be part of the team's future.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in a match that saw both teams have their chances to win. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized from a corner just five minutes later. The game was evenly matched, with both teams creating several opportunities. Blackpool should have won it late on, but Tom Aldred missed a free header from a corner. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The 29-year-old player, who has had spells with Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. They could make their debut for the U's in the EFL Cup first-round tie against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5m towards the construction of a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, to honor the courage and sacrifice of over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial, expected to be completed by 2019, will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to the families of fallen officers, with the names of loved ones as a personal memorial. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial, which is intended to become a lasting tribute to the vital contribution of policing to society and the courage and sacrifice of those who have paid the ultimate price.

Manchester United maintained a 15-point lead at the top of the Premier League table with eight games remaining after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on the upcoming matches, particularly the derby against Manchester City, despite their commanding lead. The club has won 50 of the last 54 points in the Premier League and is aiming to surpass Chelsea's record of 95 points in a season. Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea. Despite these setbacks, Ferguson expressed confidence in the team's ability to handle the challenges ahead.

Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, which it claims was the legally required amount. The company routes most of its UK sales through Ireland to minimize its tax liability. Google Chairman Eric Schmidt has argued that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where economic activity and risks are conducted, rather than where products are consumed. He has also called for a debate on international tax reform and suggested that politicians, not companies, should set the rules. The European Union has agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities.

NHS Improvement is urging the NHS to make more progress in reducing its agency bill, which reached £3.6bn last year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far, limiting non-senior staff pay to 55% above normal shift rates. However, the NHS is 10% short of its target, and it's unclear if spending on other parts of the pay bill has increased. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables of trust performance and investigate high agency staff earnings, including examples of hospitals being quoted double the capped rates.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a hub of commerce during Ireland's economic boom, now symbolizes the downturn following the Celtic Tiger's collapse. Local businesses, such as Matt O'Brien's men's clothing shop, have faced significant challenges, including a 30% drop in revenue and staff layoffs. However, O'Brien reports a recent uptick in business, attributing this to diversifying offerings and adapting to market demands.
