Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked information about the US National Security Agency's (NSA) mass surveillance programs, including Prism, which grants access to user data from major technology companies. The NSA's eavesdropping operations have helped keep Americans secure, but the extent of the surveillance has raised privacy concerns. Different countries have varying data protection laws, but these typically regulate company data handling rather than government activity. The US Patriot Act of 2001 gave American authorities new powers over European data stored in the US. While some experts question the true powers of Prism, others, like Privacy International, express concerns about the violation of privacy. Edward Snowden, the source of the leaks, acted out of concern for privacy and the potential societal implications of mass surveillance.

OpenAI is a research venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aiming to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity. The organization plans to focus on research that positively impacts humans, free from financial obligations. While some experts warn about the potential risks of AI, OpenAI believes that AI should be an extension of individual human wills and distributed as broadly and evenly as possible. The organization has pledged $1 billion, with only a small fraction to be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June in Doncaster. Despite his injuries, he has received thousands of requests on Facebook, but the site limits friend associations to 5,000 per personal page. L/Bdr Parkinson's nomination stated that his brain injury took his speech but not his personality and sense of humor. He now speaks unaided and spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, walking with crutches. He also raises money for military charities and is the patron of his beloved Pilgrim Bandits. L/Bdr Parkinson's mother Diane said the responses had been phenomenal and that Ben was really buoyed up by the support and friendship he had been shown. She said that the amount of post the family had received had also increased, and that Ben's page had had 19,000 hits just on an update.

The poverty rate in the U.S. remained at 15% in 2011, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. Real median household income dropped by 1.5%, and income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6%, the first annual rise since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%. The poverty rate reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, moved to Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and has signed a new deal that will keep him at the club until 2019. He is known for his fast scoring in one-day internationals, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan last year. Buttler's presence in the T20 Blast final at Edgbaston last year was a factor in Lancashire's victory, and his experience at the international level benefits the squad. He is currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians but will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships. The BBC understands that no proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Those who have registered an interest are finalizing their bids, with viewings set to take place in late February and March. A final decision is not expected until the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority, which is handling the sale, wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to determine the capacity of the UK's industry in the field. Penny Mordaunt, Conservative MP for Portsmouth North, said it was important for UK recyclers to have the chance to prove themselves in the field, but she was also keen to see at least one of them saved from the scrapyard. She added, "For anyone that has served on a ship, it's your home, you've literally been through the wars with it... and you want them to have a noble second life." Mordaunt's preference is for the frigates to be turned into a reef and diving attraction, which she believes would generate income for part of the country through tourism. The Ministry of Defence has previously said it will "consider all options" for the frigates to ensure "best financial return for the taxpayer." A spokeswoman would not comment on the number or nature of the bids received due to "commercial sensitivity."

Fiji has faced significant political and racial instability since 1987, marked by coups, economic challenges, and international isolation. The 1987 coup by indigenous Fijians overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition, leading to a series of adverse events, including the introduction and withdrawal of a constitution enshrining indigenous Fijian political supremacy. A 2000 coup, led by businessman George Speight, further exacerbated tensions and economic harm, particularly in the tourism industry. The continuing tensions culminated in a bloodless military takeover in 2006. In 2009, Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth over its lack of progress towards democracy. The government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, prompting the restoration of diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand. Following the elections, Fiji was re-instated as a member of the Commonwealth. The population, divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, is marked by minimal mixing and informal segregation. The economy, heavily reliant on sugar and tourism, faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making Fiji one of the world's largest per capita recipients of aid.

Syria is facing challenges in meeting the deadlines for destroying its chemical weapons stockpile, as outlined by Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad in an interview with the BBC. The country has shipped two batches of chemical weapons to the coast, but the second shipment was attacked by terrorist groups. Mekdad emphasized that Syria is committed to fulfilling its obligations under the agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council, despite the difficulties posed by the ongoing conflict. He also criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, stating that the Syrian government is defending its people against terrorist attacks. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in Aleppo in the last five days due to barrel bomb attacks. The Observatory also reported that rebels, including the Islamic Front coalition and the al-Nusra Front, have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, although the Syrian state television denied these reports.

The Booker Prize, now in its 46th year, is open to all authors writing in English for the first time. The shortlist includes six novels: The Lives of Others by Neel Mukherjee, J by Howard Jacobson, How To Be Both by Ali Smith, To Rise Again at a Decent Hour by Joshua Ferris, We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves by Karen Joy Fowler, and The Narrow Road to the Deep North by Richard Flanagan. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on naming him in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal and, if so, whether to allow or dismiss it. PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, had engaged in occasional sexual encounters with another person, referred to as AB, starting in 2009. In December 2011, they discussed a "three-way" with AB's partner, CD, and the three met for a three-way sexual encounter. In January, the two other parties approached the Sun On Sunday with the story. A High Court judge refused to impose an injunction barring publication, but PJS appealed and two appeal court judges ruled in his favour, preventing him from being identified in publications in England and Wales. Lawyers for News Group Newspapers, publishers of the Sun On Sunday, then asked the Court of Appeal to lift the ban, arguing that the story had been published in the US, Scotland, and elsewhere, and had spread across the internet and on Twitter. PJS opposed the application and said the ban should stay. On Monday, the judges ruled that PJS was unlikely to be able to get a permanent injunction, as details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost."

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was purchased in August for £345.5m. Plans are underway to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners have met with Blaby District Council to address "potential planning questions." Ernie White, leader of the council, views the purchase as an investment to improve the gateway to the city, noting that the current view of the park's rear sheds is less than ideal. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to address parking and congestion issues, as well as the quality of common areas and facilities to enhance the overall experience at Fosse Park.

The live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast has sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving LeFou, who struggles with feelings for Gaston. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a "minor edit" but has not announced a new release date. The decision to review the film has been criticized by netizens, who have called it "stupid and laughable" and compared it to "nonsense Malay movies with no moral values." The film has been granted a "P13 parental guidance classification."

Southampton City Council estimated there were 1,500 unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in the area. Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people are required to apply for an HMO license, which can cost up to ??1,000. Despite facing fines of up to ??20,000, some landlords have resisted applying for their licenses. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for failing to comply with the licensing regime. HMO tenants frequently express concerns about fear of eviction and living in poorly maintained properties. Nationally, mandatory licensing for HMOs applies to houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licenses affect properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1 - introduced in 2013) and in Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2 - introduced in 2015).

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are working to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but won't support a program for government. Water charges are a major obstacle to reaching an agreement, with Fianna Fáil pushing for their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is one proposal being considered. Fine Gael has 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7 following the election almost two months ago, but no party has been able to form a majority government and TDs have failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ferry en route to Valencia, caught fire on one of its car decks about 27km from Mallorca. The passengers were evacuated onto lifeboats and later rescued by another ship, the Puglia. At least three people were injured, with one in serious condition, and were airlifted to hospital. The cause of the fire is unclear, and the ship may sink. The rescued passengers are being returned to Palma de Mallorca, where psychologists will be available to provide counseling.

The passage discusses the issue of duplicate voter registrations in the UK, highlighting concerns raised by the Electoral Commission and political parties. It notes that a record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June 2017 general election, with 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. However, concerns about duplicate registrations, particularly among students and those with second homes, persist. The Electoral Commission calls for better integration of electoral registers and online registration systems to reduce duplicate entries and prevent double voting. It also suggests a verification function and clearer information on registration sites. Labour's shadow minister for voter engagement, Cat Smith, emphasizes the importance of not making it harder for young people and students to register to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, was found dead in his prison cell on Wednesday, with officials believing he took his own life. Phillips, who was serving a sentence of over 30 years, had a troubled past both on and off the field. He was convicted of assault for driving his car into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend. Phillips had been placed in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate. Despite his troubled past, his former coach, Tom Osborne, described him as an intelligent person with good qualities, but also someone who struggled with anger issues and couldn't overcome his demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to lance corporal in the Mercian Regiment for good behavior. He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams that dates back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. Private Derby XXX has been with the regiment since February 2014 and has his own army number, gets paid to buy his rations, and takes his holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. He has also helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial commemorating the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-finals, with Dejan Lovren scoring a last-minute winner. The match was marked by an incredible atmosphere at Anfield, with Liverpool coming back from a 2-0 deficit to win the game. Jurgen Klopp's touchline demeanor and the team's refusal to give up were key factors in the victory. The win puts Liverpool in the semi-finals of the Europa League, where they will face either Sevilla, Villarreal, or Shakhtar Donetsk. The victory also keeps Liverpool's hopes of returning to the Champions League alive.

The UK government held a meeting with the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to discuss how to work together to get the best deal for the whole of the UK following the Brexit vote. Mr Davis, the UK government's Brexit Secretary, said that the UK government would keep the devolved administrations up-to-date about negotiations and hold monthly meetings to share analysis and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views. However, Mr Russell, the Scottish government's Brexit Minister, said that the UK government had not made its strategic intentions clear and called for greater clarity and transparency on its intentions. He also stressed the importance of membership of the single market for Scotland's economic prosperity.

A veterinary surgeon examines Daisy, one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, to assess her health and detect signs of disease or osteoarthritis. The study, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and are healthy. The fate of cloning science may depend on the results. The cloned sheep are subjected to a comprehensive set of tests, including joint manipulations, X-rays, and full-body fMRI scans. The study focuses on three co-morbidities associated with aging: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results, which could have significant implications for the future of cloning, will be published soon.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won the Musidora Stakes at York, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three-quarters. Shutter Speed is now set to race in the French Oaks at Chantilly, while Gosden's other top contenders, Enable and Coronet, will compete in the Epsom Oaks. In the Duke of York Stakes, Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won comfortably with Jim Crowley aboard, finishing ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden expressed concerns about the ground for his colt, Cracksman, in Thursday's Dante Stakes and will decide whether he runs in the Derby trial after walking the course.

The currency initially slipped against the dollar and euro, only to start recovering in mid-afternoon trading before falling again. Meanwhile, the "volatility index" - a measure of investors' uncertainty - has hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226. Against the euro, sterling was down 0.6% at €1.2605 and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to just over 151. Investors have been spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen, although markets have also been rattled by global economic worries. With 10 days to go before the referendum vote, two polls at the weekend put the Leave camp ahead, while betting firm Betfair said the implied probability of a vote to Remain had now fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier. How trade and the UK's economy are affected by membership of the EU. "We expect incoming polls to move the pound more aggressively than before," said Charalambos Pissouros, senior analyst at IronFX Global. "If new polls continue to show a tight race between the two campaigns as we approach the voting day, the outcome is likely to become even more uncertain and hence, volatility in sterling is likely to heighten further." BBC economics editor Kamal Ahmed said hedge funds had been placing bets - short-selling - on expectations that the value of sterling will sink further. "The bears are in town," he said. Joe Rundle, head of trading at ETX Capital, said the markets were now on full Brexit alert. "Polls show it's now too close to call and markets are responding with some very twitchy activity. Sterling has shed more than 2% in two sessions to retrace its April lows." Worries about the economic impact of leaving the EU were also blamed for a big fall in Asian stock markets. Japan's Nikkei index closed 3.5% down, while Hong Kong's main index slid 2.5%. The reaction on London's FTSE 100 was muted initially, with the index down 0.3% in morning trading. However, the FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points, with Lloyds Banking Group the biggest faller, down 4.2%. On Sunday, Leave campaigner Nigel Farage told BBC1's Andrew Marr Show that sterling had recently been strengthening. "Sterling is up since March. Since Brexit became a possibility, sterling is up and FTSE is exactly the same level it was in March," he said. He also pointed out that a weaker pound was good for UK exporters. Last week, official figures showed that the UK trade deficit narrowed in April on the back of a jump in exports.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. They recently lost to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Despite the loss, Braintree's manager, Cowley, remains positive and emphasizes the challenges of being a part-time team in the National League.

The passage discusses a significant change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where local councils will take over most planning decisions from April 2015. This shift is seen as a move towards democratization, with elected politicians making the final decisions on developments. However, concerns have been raised about the potential for favoritism and discrimination in the allocation of planning permissions, as well as the need for transparency and a strict code of conduct to ensure fairness. The passage also highlights the importance of public knowledge about political donations, especially in the context of potential conflicts of interest between developers and political parties.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was found injured by her owner in NiddryView, Winchburgh, after being shot three times with an airgun. The cat was taken to the Scottish SPCA, where her left back leg had to be amputated due to the severity of the injuries. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to contact them, and they are calling for the Scottish government to implement a licensing regime for airguns to prevent similar incidents in the future.

Liverpool have signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for a fee of £32.5 million, making him their second most expensive signing. The Belgium international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after signing from Genk for £7 million in 2012. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup in Brazil with an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October and scored 15 times to help Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has added Benteke to revive the Reds' attack, following the sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49 million. Benteke is Liverpool's seventh summer signing, and he is expected to lead the forward line.

The study, commissioned by education technology charity Tablets for Schools, found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. However, it highlighted the rapid growth of tablet computers in schools, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them to some extent. The highest use was in academy schools, and 45% of schools not currently using tablets reported plans to introduce them. While researchers couldn't definitively link tablet use to improved results, they noted a positive impact on motivation and family involvement. The study also found that touch-screen computers were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read.

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing the lives of children over more than 100 years, providing a snapshot of lost days of childhood and a thought-provoking social history of life in Liverpool through the decades. The photographs span the period from the 1880s to the 1990s, illustrating how life for a child has changed and how special occasions were marked on the city's streets. The exhibition includes a portrait of the Rollo children, who lived in a large home with four servants, and a nervous-looking young maid, reminding us that many youngsters were sent out to work. The exhibition was curated by Kay Jones, who selected the images to tell the experience of childhood, both good and bad.

Barrow center-back Anderson, 27, has left by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. He has played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Striker Keating, 21, has joined Torquay United, recommended by Micky Adams. He has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Torquay United is four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

Bolivia has passed a new law permitting 12-year-olds to work for others with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic needs and setting harsher punishments for violence against children. The law, signed by Vice President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, includes a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide and aims to help eradicate extreme poverty. While the International Labour Organisation (ILO) recommends a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, it does not permit work for children under 15. The ILO is currently reviewing the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

Rosie O'Donnell experienced a heart attack and shared her story on her blog. She searched for "women's heart attack symptoms" online, which included sudden nausea and aches, and took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist. A stent was inserted into an artery that was 99% blocked. O'Donnell warned her readers to know the symptoms of a heart attack and to call 911. She did not call emergency services herself. O'Donnell has acted in several films and TV shows, including Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck. She recently hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, but it was canceled due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington, was stabbed to death in an alleyway in Kenton, London, following a fight with a group of youths who tried to gain entry to a party he had been invited to. Although he was not involved in the initial altercation, he was targeted later and pronounced dead about an hour later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A third boy, aged 14, is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark introduced a new approach to cancer diagnosis to address poor survival rates and long waiting times. The system includes fast-track routes for patients with alarm symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with undiagnosed symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The changes have improved survival rates and better organization of resources. The system has also fostered better collaboration between GPs and specialists.

The UK government has disbanded the OFT, and Powys has won the competitive bidding process to take over its services. Powys will receive £170,000 annually to carry out the work. Complaints about estate agents will still be directed to local authority trading standards departments, which will prosecute offenders if necessary. However, cases that involve breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, hopes that this new role will pave the way for Powys to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the healthcare workforce, allowing nurses to take on additional tasks with further training. A Nuffield Trust review found examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. However, unions have warned against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems. The report highlighted that the healthcare workforce, which includes 1.3 million staff, could be reshaped to address gaps in junior doctor rotas and GP struggles with patient numbers. The Nuffield Trust admitted that money would need to be set aside to ensure the changes happen.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT, and investigations are ongoing. First reported that while parts of its services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal.

Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) is developing a £1.3bn tidal lagoon project in Swansea, which is being reviewed by the UK government for its viability. NRW, Wales' environmental regulator, has estimated that the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year as they migrate to and from local rivers. TLP has disputed these figures, claiming that they have no clear scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating them. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and maintains that its figures are based on the best available evidence. The Welsh Government is supportive of the scheme but is seeking clarity on the UK government's position.

Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster announced the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will play a pivotal role in providing strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The move is seen as a significant and exciting opportunity for the Northern Ireland agri-food industry to work together for the benefit of the entire sector. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, highlighting the importance of the agri-food sector in delivering export-led economic growth for the north.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a project to plant 40,000 native trees in Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. The project is part of a larger initiative to plant millions of trees across the UK, and the trust is inviting local people and visitors to participate in the tree planting. The aim is to create a living, growing tribute to the people from Ireland who played a part in the war, and the trust hopes that as many people as possible will join in and plant a tree. Volunteers are advised to wear welly boots or stout footwear, and limited parking is available for those taking part.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate on Thursday for her book, Someone Else's Skin, a thriller that tackles domestic violence and so-called honor crime. The book, which is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome, was praised for its finely written and tightly written prose, as well as its well-done and well-plotted subject matter. US author Sara Paretsky, who created detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about the female private investigator from Chicago. The other books on the shortlist were also praised for their strong subject matter and well-plotted stories.

Worcestershire County Cricket Club has re-signed New Zealand all-rounder Mitchell Santner for the 2017 season, following an injury-plagued 2016 campaign. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, broke his finger in only his second game for the county, which was a major blow to their hopes of qualifying for the next stage of the competition. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed his excitement about Santner's return, stating that he was very unlucky last summer and that his presence would have been a significant bonus for the team. Santner, who is also a left-arm batsman and spinner, is expected to rejoin the Rapids following the ICC Trophy in England. In August, Worcestershire also signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats of the game.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in a staged hit-and-run accident in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than him, was believed to have been involved in his death to inherit his money and property. Ziuzina, who was a lap dancer and stripper, sold Pring's Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. The Ukrainian police closed an inquiry into his death but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son Charlie, who has been ill since the age of three, urgently needs T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after the last transplant failed. The family, from Litherland, Merseyside, was left "heartbroken" when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, which his parents described as "completely overwhelming" and "extremely grateful." The treatment will start as soon as possible, and the family is awaiting confirmation of the date.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification system for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access to users' accounts. This system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after typing in their username and password on a new device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases on iTunes, iBooks, and the App Store are blocked. Users can regain access to their accounts using a 14-character recovery key, which they are advised to keep in a safe place. While the system is an opt-in choice, some experts suggest that Apple should make it the default option to enhance security.

Billericay Town, an Isthmian League Premier Division club, is reportedly in talks with former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here runner-up and non-league footballer, Mark Wright, to purchase a 20% stake in the club. The finer details of the deal are yet to be released, but it is reported that Wright will become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the league, three points adrift of a play-off place. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has stated that he is "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week. Billericay has also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr Ashley has been asked to provide evidence about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the working practices at his Derbyshire warehouse. He has been invited to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook by the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright. Mr Ashley has not accepted any of the offered dates for the meeting and has not agreed in principle to attend. The committee has warned that if he fails to agree to attend on one of the offered dates, they reserve the right to take the matter further, including seeking the support of the House of Commons in respect of any complaint of contempt. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for a comment.

The report, Putin. War, compiled by Ilya Yashin and colleagues of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. The report, based on facts from Russian and foreign media, details the human and economic cost of the conflict and presents evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment playing a decisive role in the separatists' key successes in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report also highlights the financial cost of the conflict, estimated at 53bn roubles (Â£665m; $1bn). Despite the evidence, many Russians are aware of their country's involvement in eastern Ukraine and find it acceptable, believing Moscow is supporting those who wish to be independent of the government in Kiev. The report's authors hope to extend the initial print run of 2,000 copies but acknowledge the challenges of publishing and distributing such material in Russia.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. A post-mortem revealed that the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration with the UK government's handling of the Article 50 letter, which he did not see before it was published. He criticized the lack of consultation with the devolved administrations and the UK government's stated aim of developing a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's actions, emphasizing the need to act in the interests of the whole of the UK. The letter mentioned Wales and promised a significant increase in decision-making power for each devolved administration, but it did not specify which powers would be devolved. The UK government's approach to EU funding in Wales has raised concerns about the future of regional aid beyond 2020.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. The Assistant Chief Constable, Stephen Martin, expressed his dismay at the mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were carrying out their duties when attacked. The post also appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr Charney, the founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The board does not expect him to return to the firm. The court filing includes evidence of illicit emails sent to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, in response to Mr Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The board states that Mr Charney repeatedly violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. American Apparel was granted a restraining order preventing him from making negative statements about the company and from trying to remove board members.

The GB men's basketball team will face Greece at the Copper Box in London on Sunday, with the game broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Greece won their previous encounter in Patras, but three of their players will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. The game is GB's only home game before EuroBasket 2017, which starts in September. After the Greece game, the team will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland for their final warm-up games.

The passage recounts the transformative impact of the iPhone, launched by Steve Jobs in 2007, on photography and various other activities. It describes the author's initial skepticism about the iPhone's significance, which changed after witnessing its revolutionary features. The author compares the iPhone's impact to the Model T Ford, highlighting its role in putting powerful computers in the hands of over two billion people and disrupting various industries. The passage also reflects on the iPhone's role in changing how we think about photography and other activities, emphasizing its user-friendly interface and the convenience it brought to mobile computing.

The RSPCA is investigating the suspected deliberate or accidental poisonings of several cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire. The most recent case involved a seven-month-old cat named Meereen, who died on Monday after ingesting antifreeze. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, found her cat behind the sofa, foaming from the mouth and trying to be sick. The RSPCA is appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely, especially with the use of antifreeze in cars during the winter months.

The passage discusses the political and economic situation in Greece, highlighting the lack of public protests despite the Syriza government's agreement to implement more austerity measures. It notes that Greece's tourism industry is thriving, with Athens airport expecting a significant increase in arrivals. The author speculates on the reasons for the absence of protests, suggesting that the public may be waiting for more details on the new bailout deal and that the near-death experience of the Greek economy in July has led to a change in Syriza's stance. The passage also points out the dual nature of austerity in Greece, both fiscal and monetary, and the challenges faced by Greek businesses due to the lack of credit. It concludes with the suggestion that for the new bailout to be successful, creditors will need to ease the burden of Greece's unsustainable debt and avoid triumphalism.

EastEnders is bringing back Grant Mitchell, played by Ross Kemp, for a brief return to film emotional episodes surrounding the death of Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor. Grant, who was last seen in 2006, will reunite with his brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden, and their mother Peggy, who is dying of cancer. The Mitchell brothers will come face to face again, facing the loss of their mother, in what is set to be classic EastEnders episodes.

Alice Ruggles was fatally attacked by her stalker, Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, described the moment they were informed of her death by two Northumbria Police officers. Despite signs of Dhillon's obsession, neither Alice nor her family realized the seriousness of the situation. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison. Alice's parents have since set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking and to honor her vibrant personality.

The Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project in Somerset, UK, has faced significant delays and uncertainties. Despite EDF's approval of the £18bn project, the UK government has launched a further review, causing EDF executives to cancel a trip to the site. The project, which is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement, has faced concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign government involvement. EDF's financial capacity has also been questioned, with shareholders approving plans to issue new shares to raise €4bn (£3.4bn) to help pay for the project. The project has been in the works since 2006, with construction approved in 2013 and an investment agreement with China General Nuclear Power Corporation (CGN) signed in 2015.

The new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse has committed adultery with, a change from the previous form that left space for a "co-respondent" to be named. Family lawyers, including Margaret Heathcote and Georgina Hamblin, express concerns that this change will increase conflict and complexity in divorce proceedings. While the form's guidance states that it is "not normally necessary" to name the third party, the new form's explicit request for the third party's name may lead to more people naming them, potentially complicating the proceedings. The Ministry of Justice has stated that there is no obligation to name the third party, but the form's design may encourage people to do so.

The passage discusses the forestry industry in Wales, highlighting the tension between environmental and commercial interests. While the industry contributes over £450m annually to the Welsh economy and ministers encourage investment in woodland creation, there is concern over the loss of commercial forests since 2001. The industry faces challenges such as bureaucratic hurdles, conflicts with environmental policies favoring native broadleaf species, and difficulties in accessing and harvesting timber. The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social considerations through initiatives like the Glastir scheme, but the current system is criticized for being too bureaucratic and insufficient to meet long-term targets.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck by a vehicle on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge. Emergency crews were called to the scene at around 16:40, and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow. His condition is believed to be serious.

The Arctic Convoys were a vital maritime campaign during World War II, where vessels traveled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. Despite constant threats from German U-boats, aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice floes, the convoys played a crucial role in the war effort. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy sought to honor the veterans with the Medal of Ushakov, symbolizing Russia's gratitude. However, the Foreign Office initially blocked the move due to rules against foreign medals for acts more than five years old. After a long campaign, the British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012, and the Foreign Office eventually allowed an "exception to the rules," enabling the veterans to receive the Ushakov medals.

HM Inspectorate of Probation identified delays in starting offenders' unpaid work and lenient handling of non-attendance, with one offender completing only 16 hours in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice, which oversees the "community payback" scheme, accepted the Inspectorate's 15 recommendations for improvement, including better alignment of work objectives with offenders' circumstances and reducing instances of offenders being turned away from work. The Inspectorate praised high-quality work and offender views that the sentences positively influenced their behavior, but emphasized the need for urgent remedial action to enforce court-ordered sentences effectively.

The article discusses comedian Russell Brand's campaign for economic and political revolution to help poorer people, despite his wealth and luxurious lifestyle. Brand has been criticized for this apparent contradiction, with accusations of hypocrisy often made against him. The article highlights Brand's response to these criticisms, including his explanation that he is aware of the charge of hypocrisy and that he believes in personal change. It also mentions Brand's past explanations of his wealth and his acknowledgment of the need for systemic change. The article concludes by noting that Brand has been condemned as a hypocrite before and that he has used the hashtag #TheSunLogic to respond to the accusations.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, revolutionized the field of genomics through his ambitious and often controversial projects. He played a key role in the Human Genome Project, but his competitive approach and commercial ventures, such as Celera Genomics, were met with criticism from the scientific community. His work led to significant advancements in decoding genes and the creation of synthetic life forms, including Synthia. Venter's efforts have been driven by a sense of urgency and a desire to make a meaningful impact on science and society.

A survey conducted by the England's School Food Trust found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The survey also found that school meals in England now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines, and about four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. The move included an option for Real to buy him back for up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata has scored three times for Spain at Euro 2016 and has won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias with Juventus. He scored 27 goals in two years for the Italian club and played in back-to-back Champions League finals, scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. Morata made his first-team debut for Real Madrid at 18 and scored 10 goals for the La Liga side.

Robert Wilson, a 30-year-old midfielder, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 but has been without a team since being released in May. He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club prior to signing for Celtic. Wilson has also had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant, has agreed to sell its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. The deal will see around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees transfer to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m, and if Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Tesco will incur a £150m cost to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand, but part of that is a loan that may be paid back. The remaining 50 shops will be closed. Fresh & Easy, which operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been losing money since opening in 2007. Tesco's first fall in annual profits for 20 years was reported in April of this year.

The passage describes an athlete's journey from experiencing racial abuse to targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Initially, the athlete faced racial abuse but overcame it and briefly considered representing France before deciding to target a medal at the Rio Olympics.

The passage provides an overview of the retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the past 40 years, based on a new inventory produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues. The study found that the total glacial area decreased from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s, representing an average loss of 26% over the last 40 years. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses seen in the southern sectors, such as the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs. In contrast, the northern Alps, including the Mont Blanc Massif, have experienced less significant retreat. The study highlights the importance of manual inspection of satellite data to accurately assess glacial coverage, as automatic delineation methods can be affected by factors such as debris cover and deep shadows.

The Scots are on the verge of qualifying for the Women's Euros, needing just one more win to secure their place. They face Iceland, who are also unbeaten, in what is expected to be a decisive match. Scotland's players, including Bayern Munich's Lisa Evans, believe that having more players in top leagues like the Bundesliga and NWSL has improved the national team's performance. Evans, who recently won the Bundesliga title, also spoke about the emotional significance of qualifying for a major tournament after previous play-off losses.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish blogger and campaigner for Scottish independence, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London about harassment that allegedly took place over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, said the allegations concerned some tweets and insisted they were not threatening. He accused the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations." The blogger, who was born in Stirling but lives in Bath, launched the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011. On Friday, he tweeted that he would be posting less frequently than usual because of "reasons totally outwith my control (don't ask)."

Skegness's Jolly Fisherman mascot, created in 1908 to promote seaside train travel, is under scrutiny from PETA, which suggests replacing him with a fish mascot to reflect modern animal-friendly values. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, appreciates PETA's suggestions but believes the Jolly Fisherman is well-loved and doesn't portray animal cruelty. He states that the mascot will be considered by the council but won't be changed if it's not broken.

Scotland secured a convincing win over Georgia, with a strong first-half performance setting the tone. Key moments included early tries from Vasil Lobzhanidze and Tommy Seymour, followed by a penalty try and scores from Sean Maitland and Stuart Hogg. Georgia's second try came from a dominant scrum, but Scotland's counter-attacking prowess, led by Hogg's second try, sealed the victory. The match highlighted Scotland's effective possession and territory control, with Greig Laidlaw's conversions and penalties playing a crucial role.

Widnes secured a 38-28 victory over Castleford in a closely contested match. Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge gave Widnes a 14-6 half-time lead. Paddy Flynn, on loan at Castleford from the Vikings, scored two tries, but Widnes extended their lead with further tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Castleford made a late comeback with tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick score, but Widnes held on for the win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth place.

Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti national, was released from the Guantanamo Bay detention facility after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat." He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. Mr. Odah challenged America's right to detain him in the US Supreme Court. He was released after Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board determined that his continued detention was not necessary to protect against a continuing significant threat to the security of the United States. However, he will spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait as part of the release terms. Mr. Odah's release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148. The US opened the facility in January 2002, following the 11 September 2001 attacks in America.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, was marked by a service at Westminster Abbey and a parade at the Cenotaph, where up to 400 people participated. The national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung at the service, which also featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. The eight-month campaign on the Gallipoli peninsula in Turkey was one of the bloodiest of the war and an attempt to force the Ottoman empire out of the war.

David Clarkson, a 30-year-old midfielder, has rejoined Premiership Well for a second spell and could make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been a substitute for most of this season. Clarkson has been fit and training hard, playing for the U20s to maintain his match fitness. He has been capped twice for Scotland and has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level, including stints at Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of bottom-placed Alloa.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Unite regional officer Steve Harley said that productive talks were held and guarantees were given that all current agreements would be honored. Unite said it understood that the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004 and that its members presently have an alternative pension scheme which is unaffected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under the new ownership. Harley met with representatives from Boparan at the Great Witchingham headquarters and was told that the new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business. This would be achieved by greater investment in the business, cost savings, and utilizing the present spare capacity at Bernard Matthews to process chicken as well as turkeys.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the ferry crossing at Cowes would be free until July 2 to acknowledge the issues and gather feedback. A review of the project has been ordered by the council, as the ferry has faced multiple problems since its late launch on May 14, including breakdowns, groundings, and training issues. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency suspended the ferry due to training issues, and cars have been damaged during boarding and disembarkation. Shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the impact on local businesses, while transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the teething problems and announced that compensation for local businesses is under discussion.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry, highlighting both opportunities and challenges. It notes that the industry, which contributes minimally to GDP and employs a small workforce, may be a low priority for the government but should not be marginalised in Brexit negotiations. The report from the House of Lords EU Committee emphasises the need for continued market access, which may require concessions such as allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. The report also stresses the importance of retaining elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and ensuring that quotas are based on scientific advice. Additionally, the report highlights the potential for different fisheries management regimes in the UK's constituent nations post-Brexit. Despite these concerns, many in the industry view Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation, as evidenced by recent increases in allowable catches under the CFP. The government spokesperson reiterated the commitment to ensuring maximum freedom to trade with and operate in the single market while reviewing fisheries management to ensure fair access to quota, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, was found guilty of downloading and possessing child sexual abuse material over a decade, from April 2004 to February 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order and placed on the sex offenders register. In February, he was removed from the General Teaching Council Scotland register after a hearing found his conduct fundamentally incompatible with teaching. The panel concluded that Geaney had failed to uphold the profession's standards and that his behavior was a pattern, not an isolated incident. He was deemed unfit to teach and prohibited from reapplying for two years.

Firefighters were at the Duncan Street site for several days following a fire on 2 March, which reduced train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire, despite the company being "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. The fire service raised concerns to the EA in February about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, which will take effect on 7 August, meaning the company will no longer be able to operate from that site. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria is facing challenges in meeting the deadlines for destroying its chemical weapons stockpile, as outlined by Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad in an interview with the BBC. The country has shipped two batches of chemical weapons to the coast, but the second shipment was attacked by rebel forces. Mekdad emphasized that Syria is committed to fulfilling its obligations under the agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council, despite the difficulties posed by the ongoing conflict. He also criticized the US for supporting terrorist elements in the country and condemned the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which has resulted in significant civilian casualties. The Syrian government has denied reports of rebels seizing control of Aleppo's central prison, asserting that security forces have thwarted the attack.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, winning by an innings and 55 runs to level the four-match series. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also contributed with four catches and a wicket. England's total of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared set up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Pakistan struggled with their batting, scoring only 198 in the first innings and 234 in the second, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq reaching 50 runs. The third Test is set to begin on August 3 at Edgbaston.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is seeking experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people and those who care for them, highlighting the positive impact of high-quality care and expressing concern about unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales. The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While the review aims to give a voice to older people and their families, the chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that the advisory panel does not include a provider expert, which he believes misses an opportunity for partnership working and full engagement of the sector.

Former Dons midfielder Sheerin, 39, has been appointed as the new player-manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin, who has been with Arbroath since 2010, guided them to their first national trophy in history by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011. Despite Arbroath's relegation to Scottish League Two in 2013-14, Sheerin's impressive track record caught the attention of Aberdeen's chief executive Duncan Fraser, who described the appointment process as "comprehensive." Sheerin, who also featured for Östersunds in Sweden and won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, expressed his desire to return to Aberdeen, and Arbroath chairman John Christison was understanding of his decision.

Swansea City, currently facing relegation from the Premier League, have appointed Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams to manage the team temporarily following the sacking of Bob Bradley. The club is looking to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement as their top choice. Curtis believes that the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and emphasizes the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local area. He also highlights the potential challenges of returning to the Premier League if relegated, given the competitive nature of the Championship. Curtis also reflects on the club's history and the impact of managerial changes, noting the loss of the 'Swansea Way' that characterized the club's earlier success under managers like Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, revolutionized the field of genomics through his ambitious and often controversial projects. He played a key role in the Human Genome Project, but his competitive approach and commercial ventures, such as Celera Genomics, were met with criticism from the scientific community. His work led to significant advancements in sequencing technology and the creation of Synthia, the first synthetic life form. Venter's focus on practical applications, including the potential for synthetic microbes to revolutionize industries and combat environmental damage, underscores his impact on science and society.

The Sutton Trust report highlights significant issues with the quality and quantity of apprenticeships in England, contrasting them with the more robust systems in countries like Germany and Switzerland. Key points include:

1. Quality and Quantity: Only 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeships in England are rated at level three (A-level equivalent), with the majority aimed at older workers.

2. Employer Participation: Just 20% of English employers offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany.

3. Duration and Level: The report recommends prioritizing level three apprenticeships and discourages the proliferation of low-level qualifications.

4. Reform Efforts: The Department for Education is reforming apprenticeships to improve standards, including minimum durations and mandatory English and math components.

5. Recommendations: The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with up to 300,000 new starts annually, focusing on higher-level qualifications and reducing low-level courses.

6. Challenges: Implementing such a large-scale expansion poses significant challenges, especially given the current shortage of apprenticeship places for younger individuals.

7. Careers Guidance: The report emphasizes the need for improved careers advice and guidance to better inform young people about vocational training options.

Dame Sarah Storey won the women's C5 time trial at the Para-cycling Road World Championships in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. This victory brings her closer to a 17th title, with the road race scheduled for Saturday. Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, has won 22 medals, including 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. She has also won 21 world titles across both sports, with four golds at the 2012 Games in London. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United, a football club in the Conference Premier, faced severe financial difficulties following their relegation from the Football League in 2012. Despite efforts by fans and other clubs' supporters to raise funds, the club's debts mounted, leading to a series of events that culminated in their expulsion from the Conference Premier. Key events include:

1. Hereford's financial troubles became public, with debts totaling £225,000, including £148,000 owed to football creditors.

2. The club was given multiple deadlines to pay its creditors, which it failed to meet.

3. The Conference Premier board, after extending the deadlines, decided to expel Hereford United from the league.

4. The club's average attendance had dropped significantly, from 3,270 in League Two five years prior to 1,758 in the 2013-2014 season.

5. Hereford's Supporters' Trust made an offer to buy the club for £1 and clear its debts, but this was not accepted.

6. Tommy Agombar took over as the new owner of Hereford United, but the club was still unable to meet the financial requirements set by the Conference Premier.

7. Former Hereford manager Martin Foyle, now managing Southport, signed two players from Hereford's team, including keeper Dan Lloyd-Weston, who was still owed part of his salary.

8. The Conference Premier board voted to expel Hereford United from the league on June 10th.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after winning 61 caps for England. He made his senior debut in 2009 and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music movement founder, died at his Cambridge home following a months-long illness. He was influential in the early-music movement and founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it across six continents for three decades. Hogwood's recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, named one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. He studied at Cambridge University and later with Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt. Hogwood held various positions, including keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, founder member of the Early Music Consort of London, artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell University. He was remembered for his generosity, academic brilliance, and ability to make music speak for itself.

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs has been out of school since June due to his parents' decision to remove him from mainstream schooling. His parents requested a place for him at a special school, but they are still waiting. In September, the family was informed that all the special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full to capacity, with no time frame given for when a place would become available. The boy's mother expressed concern that the system has isolated her son and worries that other families may face similar situations. The Education Authority has stated that they are reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and are working to ensure that places are available close to where the children reside.

The passage discusses the potential takeover of the Newport Gwent Dragons by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) and its implications for Newport County AFC, who also use Rodney Parade as their home ground. The WRU has expressed a desire to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County's lease agreement with the ground is until 2023, with primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover of the Dragons will be voted on in early May. Newport County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two with two games remaining, and survival could be secured this weekend.

The passage describes the experiences of a man who was kidnapped and trained as a child soldier during Sierra Leone's civil war, which ended in 2002. After escaping and finding his way to the capital, Freetown, he met a preacher who helped him turn his life around. The man later became involved in the fight against the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, where he and others worked to educate the public, provide support to affected communities, and set up an Ebola treatment unit. Despite the challenges and dangers they faced, they were able to save many lives and make a positive impact on the country.

The Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, faced the potential auction of its 80,000-piece collection to help pay off a pension debt. A public fundraising campaign, led by the Art Fund, successfully raised the necessary funds in just a month. The collection, which includes works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, will remain on display at the museum and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The sale was finalized on Monday, with administrators expressing satisfaction and gratitude for the support received. The collection is considered significant for Staffordshire and for charting Britain's cultural development over centuries.

Billericay Town, an Isthmian League Premier Division club, is reportedly in talks with former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here runner-up Mark Wright about purchasing a 20% stake in the club. The finer details of the deal are yet to be released, but The Sun reported that Wright, who played non-league football for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds, will become a club director. Billericay is currently eighth in the league, three points adrift of a play-off place. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has invested £10,000 a week into the club. Billericay has also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool and Colchester United played to a 1-1 draw in a match that saw both teams have their chances to win. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalized from a corner just five minutes later. The game remained tense, with both teams creating opportunities, but neither could find a winner. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off in injury time for a bad tackle.

The disused Fawley power station chimney, located on the western shore of Southampton Water, is set to become the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The 198-meter-high chimney, which dominates the Solent skyline, will be the centerpiece of a £1 billion development that includes a marina, housing, and restaurants. The power station, which was commissioned in 1971, was capable of powering one million homes and was fueled by the nearby Esso refinery. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, and outline planning permission is expected to be submitted later this year. The chimney, which is already a significant piece of infrastructure, will be transformed into a petal-shaped glass structure, with fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The development is expected to start in 2018.

The British cycling team achieved a bronze medal in the men's points race at the Hong Kong championships, with Matthew Latham securing the third place. In the men's team pursuit, the team finished fourth, losing to Italy in the bronze medal race. Joe Truman, the sole British rider in the men's keirin, was eliminated in the semi-finals. In the women's team pursuit, the team finished fifth in the heats and did not qualify for the bronze medal ride. Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman praised Matthew Latham's performance, noting his strategic approach and strong finish. Six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy also commended Latham's race management and sprinting ability. The young women's team pursuit squad, featuring Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker, finished fifth overall, with Barker expressing optimism about the team's potential and future improvements.

EastEnders is bringing back Grant Mitchell, played by Ross Kemp, for a brief return to film "classic EastEnders episodes" as part of the storyline surrounding the death of Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor. Grant, who was last seen in 2006, will reunite with his brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden, and their mother Peggy, who announced her character's cancer has returned and will be killed off in emotional scenes to be screened in the spring. The Mitchell brothers will come face to face again to say goodbye to their mother, with executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins stating that the return of Grant Mitchell, one of the soap's most memorable characters, will allow Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden to showcase their talent.

Spurs suffered a disappointing defeat at Anfield, with Sadio Mane scoring twice in quick succession. Manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed frustration with his team's lack of desire and inability to cope with the pressure, stating that it is difficult to challenge for the Premier League if they continue to show such a lack of readiness to fight for the title. Spurs have struggled on the road, winning just twice since September, and have won only once in their past 17 meetings with the other top-six sides away from home. Former Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized the team's performance, particularly their defensive record, and suggested that they should have stuck with a back three formation against the big sides.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in the Saturday elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. The APC, led by Muhammadu Buhari, who defeated President Goodluck Jonathan, also won in key northern states and Lagos, Nigeria's commercial hub. The PDP, which lost the presidential poll last month for the first time, won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The elections, marred by violence and ethnic differences, were more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes for Nigeria's democracy. The PDP will need to go through a period of introspection and rebuild under a new leader, as voters felt it was time for change.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented reality experience through an app that triggers online information from signs and posters on the site. This feature allows visitors to view videos and band interviews on their phones and tablets, providing a unique festival experience. The app will also enable people worldwide to interact with the festival and capture its atmosphere at any time. The message will be updated in the run-up to HebCelt and during the event, allowing instant access to information, interviews, and ticket purchases.

The Ofsted reports on Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock schools in Birmingham have led to significant concerns about the management and educational standards in these institutions. Park View and Nansen Primary are facing funding agreement terminations due to inadequate performance and concerns about promoting spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock have also been warned about potential funding cuts unless specific issues are addressed.

The reports highlight a culture of fear and intimidation in these schools, with head teachers facing challenges from parents and external speakers with extremist views. Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw emphasized the need for improvement, particularly in safeguarding and curriculum balance. The Department for Education is taking steps to address these issues, including the potential removal of the Park View Educational Trust from managing the affected schools.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution alleges that the conduct of eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, was so far below the expected standard it was "criminal." Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter. The prosecution's case is that Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the routine test and refer him for further investigation. This failure led to a build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution argues that Rose's conduct was so bad in all the circumstances that it fell far below the standards expected of a competent optometrist, making it criminal. The trial continues.

Clive Weatherhogg was convicted of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with another man, filming the encounters, and sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. He was also found guilty of causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. Weatherhogg, a first-time offender, was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending. He was placed on the sex offenders register and his case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers. The judge, Lady Wolffe, stated that the sentence would reflect society's abhorrence of such conduct.

Ireland made 165-5 in their T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson scoring 56 and Gary Wilson and William Porterfield adding valuable runs. However, Afghanistan chased down the target with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Ireland's innings got off to a poor start with the dismissal of Paul Stirling for a duck, but Thompson and Porterfield steadied the innings before Wilson helped the Irish to a competitive total. Afghanistan's opening stand of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai set the tone for their victory, with Amir Hamza taking 2-23 for Afghanistan.
