Ireland's captain, William Porterfield, expressed disappointment with their bowling performance, while also acknowledging the loss of paceman Boyd Rankin for the T20s due to a back problem.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost of Neymar, including signing-on fee, wages, agents fees, and this latest tax payment, is £106.8m. Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money, and a judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona denies any tax-related crime and has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56. The case has not been dropped, and Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

Two British tourists, David Miller and Hannah Witheridge, were found murdered on a beach in Koh Tao, Thailand, on 15 September. Thai police arrested two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the killings. However, concerns were raised about the handling of the investigation, particularly regarding the verification of DNA evidence and allegations of mistreatment. A team of UK detectives visited Thailand to review the investigation and will now compile a report to update the families of the victims. The suspects, aged 21, are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty.

The Scots are on the verge of qualifying for the Women's Euros, needing just one more win to secure their place. They face Iceland, who are also unbeaten, in what is expected to be a decisive match. Scotland's players, including Bayern Munich's Lisa Evans, believe that having more players in top leagues like the Bundesliga and NWSL has improved the national team's performance. Evans, who won the Bundesliga in her first season at Bayern, also highlighted the importance of having the support of fans at home games.

Apple has introduced a two-step verification system for iCloud to prevent unauthorized access to users' accounts. The system requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app after typing in their username and password on a new device. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud and purchases on iTunes, iBooks, and the App Store are denied. Users can also use a 14-character recovery key to regain access to their account in case their trusted device is lost or stolen. However, the recovery key must be kept in a safe place to avoid being locked out. While the two-step verification system was previously available, it did not apply to the back-up service, allowing attackers to download a complete back-up of users' data using Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The new system guards against this technique, and Apple plans to more aggressively encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

UKIP, the Tories, the Lib Dems, and Labour were the top four spenders in the May European election campaign, with UKIP spending £2,956,737, the Tories £2,980,815, the Lib Dems £1,580,575, and Labour £1,027,339. UKIP's campaign spending was 68p per vote, Labour's was 26p per vote, the Conservatives' was 79p per vote, and the Lib Dems' was £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. Including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning. All but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Barrow center-back Anderson, 27, has left by mutual consent to join their National League rivals. He has played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Striker Keating, 21, has joined Torquay United, recommended by Micky Adams. He has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Both players could feature against their old clubs.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a severe pulmonary hemorrhage, a rare incident that can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite showing symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, Many Clouds had never collapsed before and had shown no symptoms on Saturday. The horse had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime."

The passage describes the emotional farewells of three MSPs—Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Tricia Marwick—as they prepare to leave the Scottish Parliament. Duncan McNeil, a Scottish Labour backbencher, used his final speech to highlight the need for accountability and scrutiny in the parliament, drawing lessons from Westminster. Alex Salmond, the former First Minister, spoke about Scotland's diversity and the need for greater responsibility in governing Scotland. He also joked about the competition from the UK budget announcement and wished good luck to those standing in the forthcoming election. Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was visibly emotional during both speeches.

A live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast is set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Luke Evans will play Gaston, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father, and Bill Condon will direct. Filming is set to begin at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough Stadium disaster, in which 96 football fans were fatally injured. The decision follows new inquests that concluded the fans were unlawfully killed and the referral of evidence files to the CPS in January. The families of the victims, who have been waiting for accountability, will be informed of the decisions at a private meeting in Warrington.

Chelmsford Prison has reported numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with a former inmate describing the jail as notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice has acknowledged the issue and is exploring ways to enhance security measures. A local resident has witnessed packages being thrown over the wall four times in two weeks, although she does not feel frightened. The Ministry of Justice has introduced laws that impose up to two years of imprisonment for individuals caught smuggling contraband into prisons.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady with 20 years of experience, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun and accepted he had struck Mrs Blackburn but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving. The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr Wright's eyes. The trial continues.

Laura Muir, a middle-distance runner, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, with a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m. Muir plans to return to university next week to complete her final year and is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March. She expressed disappointment at missing the Commonwealth Games but emphasized the importance of her degree. Muir believes she has at least two to three more Olympics ahead of her and is excited about the future.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search of a three-acre wooded area in Chapelizod, Dublin, began on Saturday morning, involving excavations expected to take several weeks. Earlier this year, a team of six detectives conducted a complete review of Mr. Deely's disappearance, enhancing CCTV footage that shows him talking to a man in black outside his workplace and later being followed on Haddington Road. The man in the footage has not been identified, and gardaí renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a four-set match at Wimbledon, marking his return to Grand Slam play after a two-year absence due to injury. Del Potro will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. In another match, Nick Kyrgios came back from two sets to one down to defeat Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match. Kyrgios will next play Feliciano Lopez, who also came back from two sets down to win. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga both won their matches in straight sets.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until apologizing to Caf for complaints it lodged against the organization during this year's Nations Cup. Morocco, meanwhile, was only able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on its participation. Both countries are now preparing for a future full of good things for both Africa and Morocco. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. Should Tunisia reach the 2017 finals in Gabon, it will reach its thirteenth straight Nations Cup, which would be a record.

McLaren, one of Formula 1's most successful teams, has experienced a significant decline in performance since 2013. The team, which has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently struggling with a Honda power-unit that is not up to par. Despite these challenges, McLaren has two world champions in their cockpit, including Fernando Alonso, who is considered one of the best drivers on the grid. The team's last constructors' title was in 1999, and they have been involved in several scandals, including the 'lie-gate' incident in 2009. McLaren's current predicament is not surprising, as their history has been a cycle of triumph and decline. However, team principal Ron Dennis insists that success will return, and the team is in the process of arresting the slide. The team's current struggles are a far cry from their previous era of dominance, which included a season sweep in 1988 with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost.

A sudden death occurred at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found several people still at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. O'Neill, the license holder, had an "appalling record" and was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit six three-pointers before halftime and eight overall, teaming with Klay Thompson to bring the Warriors back from a 13-point deficit. Curry also added nine assists, while Thompson scored 26 points. Lamarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists for the Blazers, who have already secured the Northwest Division title.

In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds, while Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scored 14 points for the Bulls, who were outscored 33-12 in the second quarter but went on a 39-8 run to open the second half. Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for the Heat, while Dwyane Wade scored nine points on 4-for-20 shooting. The Heat were outscored 57-27 in the second half.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic received an unexpected surprise when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood. The players were led to believe that van Velzen was a competition winner who had won the opportunity to meet the Anfield stars and receive a dead-ball masterclass. However, van Velzen showcased his skills in front of goal, leaving the Liverpool stars in awe. The players, including Balotelli, took turns trying to replicate van Velzen's free-kick skills, with Balotelli eventually succeeding in executing a perfect free-kick. The experience was described as amazing, with van Velzen expressing his excitement at meeting Balotelli and the other Liverpool players.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed, according to a study. The study found that oophorectomy was associated with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death in women with a BRCA1 mutation, but not in those with a BRCA2 mutation. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The study also found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The authors called for follow-up studies on women who undergo oophorectomy as part of their initial treatment, particularly those who had the surgery within a year of finding out they have breast cancer.

An Amtrak train struck and killed a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, as they lingered on the tracks. The train, headed from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes but continued its route after the accident. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. According to a man who met the couple while collecting scrap metal, they may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship. Now 66, he faces deportation after retiring due to health issues, as the DEA has refused to help him secure citizenship. Toro, who fears for his life if deported to Colombia, has provided information that led to the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, he remains in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or secure a green card or passport.

ICANN, the U.S. body that regulates internet addresses, is looking to crack down on a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., using the new '.sucks' domain name to extract exorbitant sums from celebrities and companies. ICANN sent a letter to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions were illegal. The advisory body has recommended charging $2,499 a year for the privilege, and according to Vox Populi CEO John Berard, most of the names have been sold by resellers for around $2,000 a year. Berard has said the domain name is meant to create destinations for companies to interact with their critics and called his company's business "well within the lines of ICANN rules and the law." ICANN said in its letter that if Canadian or U.S. regulators find Vox Populi's actions are illegal, it could declare the company in breach of its contract and seek to change the registry's behavior.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The body was exhumed, and DNA samples led the police to the mother. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide, but the charge was dropped after she explained that the baby was stillborn and that she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. The woman revealed that she had placed her dead baby in the pond, which was discovered a few days later by teenagers. The baby was originally buried without a name but was later named Peter after the church where he was buried. A support group for parents of stillborn children raised the money for a new headstone. The case has now been closed, with police satisfied that nobody else was involved.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was found to have unlawfully imprisoned a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from the moving vehicle. The incident occurred in Bath, Somerset, five years ago when Mr. Young mistakenly believed Mr. Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the rank to teach him a lesson. Mr. Hicks, who was 23 at the time, jumped from the vehicle while it was traveling at over 20 mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries that left him requiring round-the-clock care from his mother. The judge ruled that Mr. Young had unlawfully imprisoned Mr. Hicks and was therefore entitled to damages, which are set to be around 50% of what the family had requested and thought to be "hundreds of thousands of pounds." The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided, and both sides were given permission to appeal.

Several storms brought reports of tornadoes to Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night, with tornado sirens blaring in Kansas. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, Kansas, which is less than 15 miles west of Wichita. The storm moved to the northeast, missing the city but posing potential risks to other communities. Other reports of tornadoes came in from southwestern Kansas, and the Storm Prediction Center reported three sightings near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The National Weather Service indicated a tornado may have touched down in the small town of Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. CNN affiliate KMOV reported that it had received reports of wind damage and flooding in the town. Aerial footage showed damage to roofs and one street overtaken by water. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight clash in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold, who has won his last three fights, is looking to secure a title shot with a victory over Machida. He plans to be the "bull" to Machida's "matador," cutting him off and dominating the fight. Rockhold respects Machida's skills but is confident in his ability to impose his style and win. Machida, on the other hand, is also confident in his ability to win and earn a title shot. He believes he can exploit Rockhold's weaknesses and is well-prepared for the fight.

A light general aviation aircraft approached the Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, and touched down without its landing gear deployed, causing the plane to skid along the runway on its belly. The plane's propellers ricocheted off the ground, and the wings bounced up and down from the impact. The pilot re-engaged the engines and took off again, with the damaged propellers making a second impact with the runway. Despite the damage, the engines stayed on, and the pilot managed to regain control and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted he is disappointed in Yaya Toure but vowed to back the midfielder until the end of the season. Sportsmail revealed that City would listen to offers for the Ivorian as they look to overhaul an ageing squad at the end of a faltering campaign. Toure is determined not to be forced out but the Chilean, speaking ahead of Sunday's visit of West Ham, acknowledged the midfielder had underperformed and dismissed claims he should be given a rest. Meanwhile, City will also face the Hammers without captain Vincent Kompany, who could miss the rest of the campaign with a muscle injury.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the Godfather of Uxbridge, will be allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence for being a member of the Cosa Nostra expired. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was convicted in his absence in Italy in 1999 and was given a seven-year sentence. In February, he lost his year-and-a-half battle against extradition and was told he must return to Italy to serve his sentence. However, it has now emerged that his case expired last October, and his European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, said that the Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish the conviction based on the fact that the conviction was too old to sustain a prison sentence. The Italian government is expected to withdraw their application for a European arrest warrant, and Rancadore will be discharged from the proceedings.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The Paul Nicholls-trained horse will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, as he announced his intention to quit riding after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. The seven-runner line-up also includes Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville. Other runners include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos. Charlie, who died in 1989, wanted their last memory to be of her running in and out of the house. Ritter declined to see the photos for several decades, not even after Barrett was convicted 33 years later. However, last year, she asked Mickey Miller, the lead investigator who worked on the case, if she could see them. She viewed them on his laptop, and she now regrets not seeing them earlier.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters tournament and complete the career grand slam. He views his final-round collapse at Augusta National in 2011 as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons about himself and his game. McIlroy believes that winning the Masters is a career-long goal and something that only a handful of players have achieved. He hopes to use the golf course as a sanctuary to escape the hype and pressure surrounding Augusta. McIlroy's extraordinary success last year came despite personal distractions, and he hopes to continue his winning streak at the Masters.

This week's trending stories include:
1. Four rainbows appeared in the early morning sky over New York after heavy rain.
2. Hiring exotic dancers for wakes is becoming popular in rural China, but the practice is now being targeted in a crackdown on vice.
3. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during a Channel 4 interview about his private life.
4. The latest beauty trend involves using a jar to plump lips, inspired by Kylie Jenner.
5. Filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker revisit her past through old footage.
6. A school rejected a prom-posal referencing bombs, leading to accusations of racism from the prom-poser.
7. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in the upcoming "Beauty and the Beast" movie.
8. Johnny Depp's transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer has generated interest on social media.
9. A creative pregnancy announcement referenced "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air."
10. A military dad photobombed his son in a memorable way.

Last year, 272 children in England were hospitalized due to foetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. This could be just the tip of the iceberg, as research suggests that one in 100 babies in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure. Niamh Brown, a 15-year-old with foetal alcohol syndrome, requires assistance with daily activities and will never be able to live independently. Her adoptive parents, Julia and Simon, established the Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust to help others affected by the condition.

A masked man, identified as Shaun Andrew McKerry, attempted to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham, armed with an axe. The shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry, causing shelves and produce to fall. McKerry's wife, Sam, joined the fray, hitting McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. The police arrived minutes later and arrested McKerry, who pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was sentenced to six years in jail. McKerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" in his youth, had a history of shoplifting and other crimes, earning him the nickname due to his frequent returns to his hometown after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks. The accused, Joshua Finbow, 23, Simon Radford, 31, Craig Stoner, 24, and Darren Smalley, 35, appeared in court in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, where they were granted bail under unusual conditions. They were required to surrender their passports, live at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, and continue to work for the Royal Navy while drawing their current pay. The alleged sexual assault occurred on April 10 after the sailors had returned to the barracks from a hockey game. The victim, a woman in her early 20s from Halifax, had accompanied a friend to the party. The four men were ordered to return to court on May 27 and were forbidden to contact the victim and six witnesses. They must remain employed by the Navy and must not resign without the court's permission. The commander of the British High Commission described the alleged offenses as "serious" but stressed that they were still only allegations.

A mother, Mrs. Jackson, was reported to the police for child abuse after a stranger mistook her son's rare skin disease, Netherton's syndrome, for signs of abuse. The syndrome causes the skin to appear red and scaly, and Mrs. Jackson has to regularly apply creams to prevent it from drying out. Despite her efforts, she has faced taunts from strangers and has even been denied entry to play centers. One incident involved armed police being called on her while she was applying cream to her son's skin in a Walmart. The police officer apologized after she explained the situation, but the incident highlights the extent of people's ignorance. Mrs. Jackson hopes that as her son grows, his condition will be better known.

Protein World's controversial "Are you beach body ready?" advertisements, featuring a bikini-clad model, have been removed from the London Underground after a Change.org petition against them attracted over 50,000 signatures. The posters, which have been defaced by bloggers and sparked over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority, were criticized for promoting an unhealthy body image and suggesting that only women who look like the model are beach-ready. Protein World defended the campaign, stating that it aimed to encourage fitness and health. The advertisements have also led to a planned protest in Hyde Park.

Rail firms have faced criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87%, just ten days after the general election, despite promises from party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has written to First Great Western, requesting an urgent review of their decision to almost double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route. The planned changes have angered Cameron's constituents, prompting him to personally intervene. The Prime Minister's spokesman told The Sunday Times that Mr Cameron has written to First Great Western and asked them to urgently review their decision.

John Young, a 66-year-old retired HGV driver and former soldier, was blinded in one eye after being struck in the face with a brick hurled through his front door by vandals. Mr. Young and his wife, Elaine, 54, were writing thank-you cards for their wedding gifts when thugs began pelting their front window with stones. When one brick smashed the glass, Mr. Young opened the front door to confront the attackers, only to be struck in the left eye by another brick. Despite undergoing emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight, leaving him blind in one eye. The attack occurred just three weeks after the couple, who have no children, got married. Police have launched an investigation but have yet to establish a motive, suspecting it may have been a case of yobs "messing around."

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract extension after making a successful return from injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 campaign due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident in which his father Keith died last April. He underwent ankle surgery but made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton's character and hard work in his recovery, and the club hopes the new contract will give him the confidence to excel this summer.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. Harley's bravery and creativity during his treatment, including wearing a superhero mask and costume, captured the attention of hospital staff and the media. After a year-long battle, Harley has been declared cancer-free. His story has also raised awareness and funds for child cancer research.

Jack Grealish must prioritize his Aston Villa career over his international future, according to Tim Sherwood. Sherwood has been impressed with the 19-year-old, who starred for Villa in their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool on Sunday. Sherwood wants Grealish to focus on continuing to force his way into the Villa first team, stating that it's up to Grealish where he wants to go. Sherwood also advised Grealish to go with his heart when making the decision, just as Nabil Bentaleb did when choosing between France and Algeria. Grealish's dad, Kevin, agreed with Sherwood's advice, stating that his son must concentrate on his club football first.

The text discusses the high landing fees charged at airports for private jets, highlighting the significant cost differences between various airports. The most expensive airports for landing fees are primarily in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo leading at £4,559 ($6,850) per landing. Narita International Airport in Tokyo and Kansai International Airport in Osaka follow, charging £3,728 ($5,600) and £3,594 ($5,400), respectively. Other notable airports include Dublin Airport in Ireland at £2,729 ($4,100) and LaGuardia Airport in New York at £2,630 ($3,950). The text also mentions that the UK's Bristol Airport is the only British airport in the top 10, charging £2,929 ($4,400) per landing.

A woman named Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her two dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy licked her ice cream slowly, Cooper devoured his in one bite. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, says Cooper always eats very quickly, so she makes sure Daisy gets her fill first. The video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched more than seven million times. Some viewers have deemed the scene "cute" and "hilarious," while others have criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs the creamy treat. However, Gallegos insists that it's perfectly fine, as Cooper is a healthy athlete. She also shared that she lost her previous dog, Sammy, at 19 years old, and he also had ice cream once a week. Gallegos also posted another video of the duo visiting a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," where Cooper again devoured the entire cup in one go.

Gary Locke has been appointed as Kilmarnock's permanent manager after a successful interim spell. The 41-year-old, who joined the club as assistant boss to Allan Johnston last summer, took control of the team when his ex-Tynecastle team-mate quit in February. Locke has lost just once in seven games since taking over at Rugby Park and has now signed a three-year deal with the club.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused her five-year-old autistic son Logan's school of threatening to suspend him due to the essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, are applied to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. Despite using the oils all year, a teacher's aide recently complained about the smell, leading to a warning from the school. Kemp received a letter from the local school board stating that the oils had created a problem for staff and students. However, the Lake County School District later clarified that Logan would not be suspended, describing the issue as a health matter. Kemp remains committed to fighting the decision, believing the oils have a positive impact on her son.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons was destroyed by a fire that started on Wednesday afternoon. The intense flames melted the paint off nearby buildings and were so strong that 12 fire crews could not enter the building. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, but it is believed to have started near a car parked by the complex. The building manager, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything in the fire.

The Queen, who will soon turn 89, enjoys a ride in the spring sunshine on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, joined by a groom on another of her fell ponies. Despite her age, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne, breeding fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud and taking a keen interest in all her horses and ponies. Her love for horses began at the age of four when she was presented with a Shetland pony named Peggy. Over the years, she has owned several horses, including Betsey, a black farm-bred horse, and Surprise, a grey gelding. Although she has cut back on riding in recent years due to a niggling knee injury, she continues to breed and ride horses, including her grandchildren. The Queen is famous for her love of horses and has never worn a riding helmet, preferring instead to ride in a silk headscarf.

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels resulted in one man's death and the other being charged with manslaughter. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly killed by a single punch to the head from 28-year-old Phillip Pama during a row in front of their North Brisbane homes. Mr. Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise in his yard at around 9 pm on Thursday night, which disturbed Pama, who works a 3 am shift at a nearby warehouse and was sleeping at the time. Pama's defense lawyer, Bruce Peters, said that Mr. Yeaman was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling at "the world at large." Pama then confronted Mr. Yeaman, and it was at that point that the situation escalated. Mr. Peters said his client grabbed Mr. Yeaman by the hand and hit out "blindly." "He was being pushed at the same time he was throwing the punch," Mr. Peters revealed during a bail application for Pama. "He did n't see it connect but he felt it connect." Paramedics were unable to revive Mr. Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene at around 11 pm on Thursday night. Neighbors described Mr. Yeaman as kind and generous, while his friend John Fisher told ABC Radio that he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed playing loud music. Pama, who has no history of violence, was reportedly "beside himself" with grief. The case is due to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, was arrested after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15-year-old ex-lover, Damian Vanya. Simonova, who had showered Vanya with gifts during their year-long relationship, offered 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400) to an undercover police officer posing as a hitman. She instructed the officer to break Vanya's arms and legs, damage his kidneys to cause slow bleeding, and then "finish him" together. Simonova was arrested after handing over some expense money and now faces up to 15 years in prison on charges of attempted murder. Vanya, who ended the relationship with Simonova to be with a classmate, expressed relief at her arrest.

Chelsea Football Manager Jose Mourinho has revealed that he speaks to God every day but never discusses football. The father-of-two, who has been an ambassador against hunger with the World Food Programme, said he tries to separate his professional and family life. Mourinho admitted to having a strong faith in God and prays every day but only goes to church regularly in Portugal. He only prays for things in his personal life, never about Chelsea. Despite his intense persona on the sidelines, Mourinho claims he is a good person and a good family person.

Bob Barker, the former host of "The Price is Right," returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1. At 91 years old, Barker hosted the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over hosting duties to Drew Carey. Despite being away from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker did not miss a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning after allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. Baldwin, who works in the Foreign Missions branch, was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Metropolitan Police Department reported that Baldwin was arrested by officers returning to the scene of the alleged crime on the 3200 block of D Street SE. The Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave following his arrest. Baldwin's arrest comes two days after a high-ranking supervisor was also placed on leave after being accused of misconduct. The Homeland Security Department's inspector general is investigating both incidents.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away. Saeed was in Lahore's safari park when he spotted the male lion in the distance. He got out of his car and crept up towards the lion, armed only with a camera, and fired off a few frames. Saeed crept to within 10 feet of the hungry lion before leaving the safety of his car to lie on the ground. Unfortunately, the clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion to Saeed's presence, and he was forced to retreat rapidly from just 10 feet away from the lion. Saeed said, "I was sitting in front of him just near my car and the door of my car was open. I was sat on the ground a few feet away, so he was treating me like his prey. I was thinking - I must show the character and status of the lion, and this was the only way I could think of to achieve this. The story finished in a few seconds as the lion aggressively jumped towards me, and I just about scrambled into my car."

The NYPD is seeking the public's help in identifying a woman who died on a Brooklyn street last month. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. She had no identification on her, but she had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg. The tattoo is a heart with the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon, topped with a rose. The NYPD has released images of the tattoo in hopes of identifying the woman. Anyone with information is asked to contact the NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning to New Zealand from the UK. The project, which took a year and a half, was driven by their desire for a cozy, affordable home and their inability to purchase a full-sized lot. The home features wood and steel construction, a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and a loft that serves as a spare room for their cat. The couple's ingenuity and resourcefulness allowed them to create a nearly self-sufficient home, with most of their electricity coming from solar panels and water sourced from a nearby spring. The total cost of the project was approximately $25,000.

Kindergarten children who shared iPads in class significantly outperformed their peers who used the devices individually or not at all, according to research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University. The study involved 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district and found that shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher on literacy tests than those who used the devices alone or not at all. Blackwell suggested that the collaborative learning around the technology, rather than the technology itself, was the key factor in the improved performance.

A piglet born without hind legs in Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its front trotters. The heartwarming video shows the piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," balancing on its front legs and foraging for food. Despite occasionally losing balance, the piglet always regains it and happily mixes with its siblings. The farmer, Ms. Duan, discovered the piglet's condition while feeding and has since become a local attraction.

A pit crew member was injured during the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana when he was struck by a car. Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was hit by Francesco Dracone's car as he exited the pit box. Dracone spun while exiting, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center, where he received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released. Dracone did not finish the race and wound up 23rd. Many cars struggled with traction during the race after hours of rain leading up to the green flag.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally attacked his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, in their Rio de Janeiro apartment. CCTV footage shows him smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the crime, citing jealousy as his motive. He was apprehended after a car chase and faces life in prison.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, has opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, revealing she came close to taking her own life. In a candid interview, Wilson explained how anxiety drove her to believe she had reached a stage in her life where she "couldn't see the point of continuing." She said that a combination of issues, including mounting stress, anxiety, her thyroid disease, and distant family, drove her to believe her life was no longer worth living. Wilson also revealed that she felt increasingly isolated, as she had not found a husband or had children. She now accepts that she is an "anxious person" and believes that anxiety is quickly becoming the "new depression." Beyond Blue reports that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and while depression and anxiety are two different conditions, one can often lead to the other.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven months pregnant at the time, was charged with second-degree assault after she struck her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin came home to find her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom. When Curtin asked her to leave and she refused, Curtin beat her with a crowbar. Curtin was set to go to trial this week, but prosecutors dropped the charge on Monday, citing that Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents. The ex-girlfriend has a history of harassment and threats against Curtin, as well as stealing from her and plotting to drag her boyfriend back into addiction. The ex-girlfriend and boyfriend have a five-year-old child together, and the boyfriend has not been a part of his new child's life. If Curtin had gone to trial and been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

Gemma the pit bull, who lives in California with two children, was filmed being fed treats, including a broccoli spear. She reacted with disgust and spat it out. Hopefully, the children will not follow her lead and will learn to love their greens. When she is not eating, Gemma enjoys sleeping and hanging out with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, which has since been removed, was on the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which were scrapped in 2011. The organizers allowed the registration of the page to expire, and a porn site took over the address. HSBC has denied any association with the external site and apologized to the public for any inconvenience caused. The bank's website remains secure, and its internet banking service allows customers to check their account balances, transfer funds, and apply for loans and insurance, among other services.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom after a fire broke out on the first floor of their home in Clinton on Sunday morning. Marcus, who stayed calm throughout the 11-minute 911 call, provided the dispatcher with instructions on how to reach their room and soothed his sister after she blurted out, "We're going to die." Firefighter Lt. Kenny Ward entered the room, handed Marcus out the window to another rescuer, and gave his gas mask to the little girl after she tugged on his leg. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the three other family members were taken to MedStar Hospital after escaping on their own.

Blue fluorescent algae have illuminated Australia's east coast, with images taken in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. The neon glow, described as a "beautiful supernatural scene," is caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The algae, Noctiluca scintillans, is a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in the spring and autumn and gives off a luminous glow as a defense mechanism. The display is similar to one seen in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and there is no need to be concerned about the algae.

Breast cancer patients may be able to avoid chemotherapy thanks to new tests that identify genetic markers in tumors and assess their aggressiveness. After surgery, cancer cells are sent to a lab for screening, and women can be informed within days of their risk of recurrence. The Endopredict test, for example, can accurately determine a low risk of recurrence, as low as five percent, which is comparable to or better than the odds of those who undergo chemotherapy. While most breast cancer patients are given chemotherapy to prevent recurrence, the side effects can be difficult to live with. The newest tests, such as Endopredict, can help patients make informed decisions about their treatment.

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with at least one case from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew before it was decommissioned last year. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. The data comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims she had a sexual relationship with a member of her crew. An unnamed captain was appointed in her place, and a military investigation was launched into the 42-year-old's conduct. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female. Last May, three women made history by becoming the first female submariners to serve in the Royal Navy.

A drone carrying traces of the radioactive material cesium was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House on Wednesday, raising concerns about terrorism. The discovery came on the same day a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, which has been controversial among many Japanese due to safety concerns following the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push to restart the reactors is unpopular, and the discovery has raised concerns about potential terrorism attempts at future events such as the Olympics and G7 summit. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports, but there are no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including the prime minister's residence and local and federal government buildings.

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure she doesn't fall off. Lu's mother used to get lost when left alone, so he decided to take her with him to work after his father passed away earlier this year. His wife works in a different city, and his son is still in school. Lu's employers, a bank, have given his mother her own room to ensure she doesn't wander off. He checks on her throughout the day to make sure she is safe. Lu says he feels a duty to care for his mother after she devoted her life to caring for her children.

The article discusses a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, which found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, with the increase largely due to rising rates among women. The study, the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, also found that binge drinking rates increased more among women than men. The article notes that public health experts attribute the increase in excessive drinking to changed social norms, increased affordability of alcohol, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The article also highlights the economic and cultural factors contributing to the increase in drinking, such as the influx of wealthy professionals in cities like San Francisco, San Jose, and Oakland, and the changing social norms that have made it more acceptable for women to drink the way men traditionally have.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk. The WHO says the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary, as it can lead to infections and even death. In England, just over a quarter of women now have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The WHO recommends that the rate should ideally be between 10% and 15% due to the dangers and costs involved. The procedure can lead to significant complications, disability, or death, and diverts precious money away from the needs of other patients. The WHO's statement sharply contradicts current NHS guidelines, which say the procedure should be offered to women even when there is no medical justification.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after the owner of a summer home in Edgartown, Massachusetts, found her sitting in his living room. Filkins was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She had allegedly been living in the home for at least a week, during which time she sold or gave away items from the home in a yard sale. Filkins fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when the owner called the police, but she was arrested several hours later after attempting to re-enter the home. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

A lost iPhone was returned to its owner, Bella Crooke, after police at the Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border posted a series of humorous photos and updates on her Facebook page. The phone, which was handed in on Sunday morning, was found unlocked, allowing officers to post selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the station. The posts included humorous comments, such as "You should probably put a password on your phone" and "It is a great 'cell' phone." Bella, who had lost her phone at a friend's birthday party the night before, was recognized by the officers when she came to collect her phone. She praised the police for their sense of humor and for returning her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed in a fight between two adult hippos in Isimangaliso Wetland Park, South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged through the water before dying of its injuries. The mother stayed with her herd, possibly believing it safer to stay out of harm's way. The calf stood no chance against the two adults as they brawled in the muddy waters of the nature reserve.

A three-bedroom apartment in the upscale Knightsbridge area of London has been listed for £575,000. This "bargain" property comes with a catch: it has just three years left on the lease. The cost of extending the lease could be between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease, which would bring the total cost to around £6 million. The property is in need of renovation, with the current freeholder thought to be the Welcome Trust. The phone has been ringing constantly with interest from locals, developers, and end users. The property is described as "bright and well-proportioned" with 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and a utility room. It also features a lift, parking, and a communal garden. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson for £575,000, the same price as a three-bedroom house in Stanmore, Middlesex.

Starbucks announced late Friday night that a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada has been resolved. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, began in the early evening on the east coast and in the late afternoon on the west coast. The company did not explain exactly what caused the outage. The potentially costly tech snafu comes just one day after the Seattle-based global coffeehouse chain, which had 21,366 locations in 65 countries last year, posted record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorist activities have been reported in rural areas of west Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. These locations are being used for radicalization and training of Muslims, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. The rugged terrain of these areas is also used by the British military for training, including elite forces like the SAS. In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed white water rafting in Bala, north Wales. In 2010, three would-be terrorists from Cardiff were arrested as part of an Al-Qaeda-inspired gang that plotted a "Mumbai-style" series of terror attacks on Britain. Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is understood to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead, near Llanybydder. Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai, and Abdul Miah were also photographed holding secret meetings in a country park in Wales. Community intelligence is crucial in combating terrorism, as these individuals often participate in seemingly ordinary activities but have ulterior motives.

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, feared to be extinct, was found washed up on a remote beach in Exmouth, Western Australia, after Cyclone Olwyn. The discovery of the 5.68m juvenile female was initially challenging for the Department of Parks and Wildlife staff, who confirmed the species through DNA profiling. The whale's discovery is highly significant for whale scientists due to the limited knowledge about the species. The Omura's whale is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation and possible public display in museums.

A female businesswoman in Texas, Cheryl Rios, has expressed the view that Hillary Clinton should not be president because her hormones might make her irrational and lead to unnecessary wars. Rios believes that women are not suited for leadership positions due to their hormonal differences. However, studies show that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts. Rios's comments have sparked a debate about the role of women in leadership and the ongoing bias against women in the workplace. Despite the progress women have made in education and employment, gender bias remains a significant barrier to their advancement to leadership positions. The article also highlights the benefits of gender equality, including better financial performance, happier and more successful children, stronger marriages, and more effective corporate teams. The author emphasizes the need to challenge gender stereotypes and biases to create a more equitable society.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques, which includes more than 200 items he has collected over his career. The sale, which is expected to fetch around £100,000, includes a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow made from yew with a mother-of-pearl handle, and a portrait of Hardy holding the bow. The auction also features paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and a fine collection of crystal chandeliers. The actor, who is a keen military historian and has written two books on the history of the longbow, is selling the items to downsize his home. The auction will take place on Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a Florida man wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead in their shared home in Winter Garden on Saturday. He is on the run from police after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. Shemansky is already on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. His estranged wife has filed a domestic violence injunction against him and is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home. Authorities have the murder weapon but will not yet confirm how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Anyone with information as to his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene, USA, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council, who bypassed the usual bidding process due to what they saw as a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council emphasized the importance of this opportunity to access a key market and develop the sport globally. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, targeted professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, after spotting him flashing a roll of £50 notes at a casino in London's West End. She used her good looks to befriend Hassan, who showered her with gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. Granger, from Gillingham, Kent, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter, while co-defendants Kyrron Jackson, 28, and Nicholas Chandler, 29, were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years. The court heard that Granger and her accomplices tied up Hassan and kicked him to death as they ransacked his home to find his hidden winnings. Granger's phone records were examined, leading to the arrest of the killers.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season. Despite a strong start, his form has dipped, and he has only managed one assist in his last five games. Fabregas captained Spain in their recent 2-0 defeat by Holland, but he was given a low rating by a Spanish newspaper. His former club, Barcelona, released a statement pointing out his traditional post-Christmas slump. However, with nine games remaining, Chelsea still has to face six opponents against whom Fabregas has laid on goals. If he can find his form again, he could help Chelsea secure the Premier League title.

West Ham United is in talks to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial with the club's academy. Beckford, a 17-year-old from Montego Bay United, has also received offers from clubs in Belgium. Additionally, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will be priced as low as £289 to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium when they move there for the 2016-17 season.

Wiltshire Police have dropped their investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, despite a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of a suspected attacker. The attack, which took place on January 24, involved balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. Lane, who is joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was kicked in the head and suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Despite providing police with video footage and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of the saboteurs, the case has been recorded as undetected due to insufficient evidence. The decision has been met with dismay from Lane, his supporters, and the countryside alliance, who are campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to aid in the identification of criminals.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen and prominent member of Al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, was not specifically targeted in the operation. He was born in 1978 and grew up on a farm in rural California. Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and left the United States for Pakistan three years later. In 2006, he was indicted by a federal grand jury in California for treason and material support to Al Qaeda. Gadahn was among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." He rose through the ranks in the tribal areas of Pakistan and became Al Qaeda's chief official English-language propagandist. Gadahn was killed along with another U.S. hostage, Warren Weinstein, in a strike on Al Qaeda.

A five-year-old Chinese boy, Mai Zizhuo, has become an internet sensation due to his exceptional basketball skills, which have drawn comparisons to professional players. The viral video shows him scoring hoops, dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, and maintaining rhythm effortlessly. His skills have garnered widespread praise and admiration, with thousands of comments from netizens expressing disbelief and awe. Some have even expressed a desire to reincarnate to start over and improve their basketball skills.

Tom O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE, formed in 1974, campaigned to legalize sex with children and allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to lobby for the age of sexual consent to be reduced to ten. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to create a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The empty pool was used as the unusual catwalk setting for the Ten Pieces presentation, a lifestyle brand headed up by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss. The collection of ten pieces is designed to be worn in 20 different ways and is suitable for day-to-night wear. Guests were treated to nibbles by Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria as they took in the minimalist, androgynous designs. The show took place on an unseasonably warm 28 degrees Celsius day, and beautiful blue sky and sunshine were enjoyed throughout.

Amir Khan, the Bolton-born boxer, spent his Friday at a safari park in northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter, Lamysa. Khan fed a rare white tiger and posed with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent.

A Palestinian teenager's name will be removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism after his family and others complained. Mohammed Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His name appeared on the wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, the site of the national cemetery, as the nation prepared to mark its Memorial Day on Wednesday. Abu Khdeir's family objected to his inclusion on the memorial wall, and a picture on the memorial website for Abu Khdeir shows an Israeli flag with two flowers called "blood of the Maccabees" in Israel, a symbol often used on Memorial Day. Almagor, an organization that works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, also opposed Abu Khdeir's inclusion on the memorial, describing the teen's death as a rogue attack and saying he's not a terror victim. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his father's complaints.

A young boy in California persistently chases his family cat around the garden, attempting to use the cat as a pillow. The cat repeatedly moves to different spots, with the boy following each time. After the cat has had enough, it walks indoors, and the boy later makes up with the cat by feeding it treats.

Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer turned varsity basketball coach, lost his coaching job at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying in a police corruption trial in Philadelphia. Kushner, 32, admitted to selling marijuana in the past and testified that some undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. The charges from 2007 were expunged as part of a probationary sentence, but Kushner was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. He also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Despite this, Kushner believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges and never meant to deceive the school where he worked as a seasonal employee.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, caused a fire and injured six people. The blast, attributed to an oil leak, occurred at an oil storage facility, with no reports of toxic chemical spills. Over 600 firefighters were deployed to control the fire, which is now under control. The plant, previously slated for the densely populated city of Xiamen, was relocated to Zhangzhou due to pollution concerns.

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish, known for wearing his socks low, says he will continue to do so due to superstition, despite being told otherwise by referees. Grealish, who made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, wears children's shinpads and has not had a kick on his shin yet. He was pleased to finally make his first start for Villa and hopes to get more starts before the end of the season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Though she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Her father, Bobby Brown, said on stage that she had improved and was watching him, but her grandmother's statement indicated that she remains in the same neurological state she has been in for nearly three months. She does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow a person around the room. She also has a tracheostomy in her throat. Bobby Brown's wife, Alicia Etheredge-Brown, said he was in an "emotional state" when he made the remarks about his daughter being awake.

Russia is on the verge of securing a spot in the Fed Cup final, holding a 2-0 lead over Germany after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova's victory over Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in the second set before winning 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. The result leaves Russia needing just one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage, with another storm predicted to hit later this week. The State Emergency Service (SES) has already received over 24,000 requests for assistance, with more than 4,000 jobs still to be completed. The SES is particularly concerned about the effect of more wild weather on the Hunter region, which suffered through flooding and high winds in the last storm. The SES is urging the community to prepare themselves, their homes, and their families to prevent further loss and devastation. The weather system appears to be moving quickly, and the main impacts of intense rainfall and strong winds are expected to be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coast.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" music video, has denied claims that she attempted to take her own life. She stated that she was treated in hospital for low blood pressure after collapsing at home. Moric posted photographs of her injuries on Instagram, showing heavy bruising on her arms. Italian media had reported that Moric's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested that she had tried to commit suicide. However, Moric clarified that she was at home with her mother when the accident occurred and that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time. She reassured her fans that she was recovering at home and only needed some rest.

Kate and William are expecting their second child, and the British public is hoping for a traditional name. A YouGov survey for The Sunday Times revealed that 12% of respondents preferred the name Diana for a girl, in honor of William's mother, the late Princess of Wales. Alice and Charlotte were the next most popular names for a girl, each receiving 9% of the vote. If the baby is a boy, 13% of respondents preferred the name James, with Alexander as the second most popular choice. The poll also showed that 25% of respondents hoped for a girl, while only 3% wanted a younger brother for George. Additionally, 68% of respondents supported William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded 64, including an Afghan lawmaker, in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday. The attack occurred as the group, led by Humayoon Humayoon, an Afghan member of parliament for Khost province, was on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves, Barcelona's Brazilian right-back, is set to leave the club this summer after rejecting their final contract offer. Alves, who has been with Barcelona for seven years, has won four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, he has been unable to agree on a new deal with the club and will leave the Nou Camp this summer. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves had rejected a three-year contract extension that was dependent on him participating in 60% of the club's matches.

Pablo Osvaldo has recommended that Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti join him at Boca Juniors. The 29-year-old, currently on loan at Boca from Southampton, has praised the duo's abilities and believes they would be a great fit for the Argentinian giants. Osvaldo, who has played with many great players over the years, feels that Pirlo and Totti, with their South American style, would be perfect for Boca and would be hugely popular with the fans at the Bombonera.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, gained internet fame for a spectacular double somersault fall from the favorite, Merrion Square, at Wincanton. Despite the fall, he returned to riding out the next morning with just a cut on his nose. Ferguson described the fall as a blur and expressed gratitude for escaping serious injury. He also joked about considering a gymnastics career after his racing career.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, showcased his inner Iron Man in an Instagram post following the release of the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. Haskell, who returned to Wasps in 2012 after stints with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders, first joined Wasps in 2002 and has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club. The England flanker has also played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, and has earned 57 caps for his country.

The wide-leg trouser is a key trend for SS15, offering an effortless and stylish alternative to the skinny jean. This look, which has made a comeback since the seventies, can be intimidating, especially for shorter individuals. However, the key to pulling off this trend lies in the choice of footwear. High-heeled shoes that expose the top of the foot can elongate the leg, making it easier to wear cropped, voluminous trousers with confidence. Pairing wide-leg trousers with a simple knit, shirt, or tee can keep the outfit in proportion and prevent it from looking like a costume. Denim is an easy way to embrace this trend, with designers like Gucci and high-street brands like Topshop offering wide-leg options. For a dressier evening look, Celine and Stella McCartney showcased classy, wide-leg trousers. To shop for wide-leg trousers and get more inspiration, head to A Style Album.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. The initial decision to cancel the movie was not consistent with the high value the university places on freedom of expression and our respect for the right of students to make their own choices in such matters. The movie will be shown as part of UMIX, a series of social events the university stages for students. A counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider the decision to cancel the movie. The announcement drew praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to make contact with a quokka on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, which is the size of a domestic cat, survived but was singed by the flame. The men, aged 18 and 24 and currently living in Cockburn Central, were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty. They are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

A 102-year-old former dancer, Alice Barker, was shown "soundies," early music videos, from her time as a chorus line dancer in New York nightclubs in the 1930s and 1940s. The videos, compiled by Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers, were shown to Barker at her nursing home. She was delighted to see herself dancing for the first time, exclaiming, "It's just fabulous."

The art of washing one's own car appears to be declining in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never washed their own car. The survey of 1,100 adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do saying they do it regularly. Only 5% of those surveyed said they had ever asked their children to wash the car as a way to earn extra pocket money. Factors behind the decline include shops now opening on Sundays and more live football on TV, meaning more people put off the chore at the weekend. The rise of hand car washes has also been blamed for a decrease in drivers washing their own cars. Cars are most likely to be washed by their owners every week in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least likely in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since arriving at Liverpool in 2008. Skrtel believes Gerrard is still one of the best players in the world and has set an example during his time at Liverpool. Gerrard, who is set to leave Liverpool for LA Galaxy, will look to lead his hometown side to the FA Cup final against Arsenal on his birthday, May 30. Skrtel admits that Liverpool will be a different side without Gerrard but believes the club has potential replacements.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, made a hole-in-one on the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, a remarkable achievement for the greatest golfer of all time. This was his first hole-in-one at Augusta, though he holds the record for the youngest to wear a green jacket and has won six Masters titles. The day saw five hole-in-ones, tying a record from 2002, with Camilo Villegas also achieving two aces. Despite the excitement, Villegas did not win, losing to Kevin Streelman in a playoff.

Several storms brought reports of tornadoes to Kansas and other states on Wednesday night, with tornado sirens blaring in Kansas. Spotters reported a tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which missed the city but posed potential risks to other communities. Other reports of tornadoes came in from southwestern Kansas, and the Storm Prediction Center reported three sightings near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The National Weather Service indicated a tornado may have touched down in the small town of Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis. In addition to tornadoes, there were reports of wind damage, flooding, and hail the size of baseballs in various parts of the region. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Robert Bates, a reserve sheriff's deputy in Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Eric Harris. Bates claims he meant to subdue Harris with a taser but mistakenly shot him with a gun. The judge granted Bates permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, prompting a response from Harris's family, who expressed disappointment and perceived apathy. Bates's preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.
